business.start.para: Mr SPEAKER (Rt Hon. Ian Sinclair) took the chair at 9.30 a.m., and read prayers.

subdebate.1.para: Bill presented by Mr Costello, and read a first time.

talk.start.para: â€”I move:

speech.para: That the bill be now read a second time.

The purpose of this bill is to establish a framework for the provision of financial assistance by Australia to countries that are undertaking economic adjustment programs with the support of the International Monetary Fund.

The current financial crisis in Asia has led a number of countries in our region to undertake such programs. The International Monetary Fund generally seeks to supplement the assistance it provides from its own resources to member countries in such circumstances with support from multilateral development banks and from other countries that are prepared to help. This extends the effectiveness of the fund's assistance. It can also provide additional assurance to financial markets that a country's adjustment program has broad international support.

The magnitude and character of the current crisis have required assistance on a very substantial scale. Over recent months, the fund has requested Australia to participate in support arrangements for Thailand, Indonesia and the Republic of Korea. The government has agreed to do so, subject to certain conditions, for an amount in each case of up to $US1 billion.

The government's decisions to provide support reflect the importance of economic and political stability in the region for Australia and the Australian economy. It was apparent that a crisis in one country could spread and set off further crises elsewhere. And the more severe the crisis became, the greater the risks to Australia, to Australia's export industries and to Australian jobs. It is important that governments are able to act swiftly in such circumstances to help mobilise international support to deal with a crisis and to provide commitments on our own participation.

At present there is no legislative framework for handling these situations, which have in the past been dealt with in an ad hoc manner. In 1995, when Australia was requested to assist a fund-supported adjustment program in Papua New Guinea, a government-to-government loan was put in place without specific legislation using funds obtained initially from the Minister for Finance's Advance. When the support arrangements for Thailand were agreed last year, the funds were required quickly and went well beyond what was available through the Minister for Finance's Advance. Our assistance was therefore provided by way of a currency swap between the Reserve Bank of Australia and the Bank of Thailand.

However, it would be inappropriate to continue to draw on the balance sheet of the Reserve Bank for such arrangements, which are properly matters for governments and should be reflected in the government's accounts. The bill provides a new framework for handling them.

Under the bill, the Treasurer may, on behalf of Australia, make agreements for the provision of financial assistance for countries undertaking fund-supported adjustment programs. Such agreements must meet some important conditions. There must be a request by the International Monetary Fund for Australian assistance and the agreement must allow Australia to require repayment if the fund program is suspended or prematurely terminated. This is to ensure that Australian assistance is provided only where a fund program is in place and continues to be adhered to by the recipient country.

The Treasurer must also be satisfied that other countries or international organisations will also be providing support to the recipient country as part of the fund program. This is to ensure that Australia is not alone in providing any assistance under the bill, but that it is part of an international effort.

It is normal in international arrangements in support of fund programs for the participants to coordinate their efforts to ensure broad consistency in the terms of their assistance and in its timing. In particular, it is established practice for such support to be provided at a cost to the recipient country which at least covers the lender's costs of funds and often with a margin to allow for at least part of the risk involved. Such terms need to be negotiated in individual cases and cannot be prescribed in advance in legislation. However, it is the firm intention of the government to continue to adhere to this practice in any support arrangements that may be undertaken under the bill. This will ensure that these arrangements do not impose direct costs on Australian taxpayers and that there is scope to earn some income to offset risk.

It also means that any support provided by Australia under the bill will not be counted as overseas development assistance and will not constitute part of Australia's aid program. The purpose of the transactions involved is to provide balance of payments support to the recipient country, in order to boost market confidence and help stabilise financial flows across the country's exchange markets and reduce volatility in its exchange rate. They are one-off transactions to provide temporary assistance to deal with financial crises; unlike official development assistance, they do not provide continuing transfers of real resources to the recipient country.

The bill provides for support to be given either through loans or currency swaps. The government intends to provide its assistance to Indonesia and Korea by loans, which is the simpler arrangement. Loans may be made in Australian dollars or in another currency. For example, the loan to Korea is expected to be made in United States dollars.

Currency swaps are now also widely used as a means of providing emergency support. They involve a temporary exchange of assets on agreed terms. Under a currency swap, Australia would receive currency of the other country to hold in return for the funds provid ed by Australia. Some countries are providing their support by way of currency swaps and the bill provides flexibility for Australia to use them if this appears warranted in particular circumstances.

Detailed terms and conditions for loans or swaps in agreements under the bill will need to be negotiated in the individual circumstances of each case. The bill also makes provision to cover the government's commitments to Indonesia and Korea if agreements with these countries are reached prior to the commencement of the act.

Last year the parliament agreed to amendments to the International Monetary Agreements Act 1947 to ratify Australia's participation in the International Monetary Fund's New Arrangements to Borrow. Those arrangements have not yet come into effect, as several participants are still to complete their ratifications. When they do, the fund's access to resources in crisis situations will be substantially enhanced. The increase in fund quotas agreed to by fund governors last month will also expand the fund's capital base. Together, these steps will enable the fund to continue to play its central role in the handling of international financial crises.

However, circumstances are likely to continue to arise, from time to time, when Australia will be asked to participate in support arrangements for fund programs. It is to be hoped that such calls for assistance will be rare, exceptional events. Nevertheless, when they do occur, governments must be in a position to respond quickly. This bill will allow Australia to play its part in international cooperation efforts when necessary to safeguard and promote Australian interests.
Financial Impact

The bill appropriates the funds required by agreements to which it applies. Loans to Indonesia and Korea could amount to up to $US2 billion, but detailed arrangements have yet to be agreed. The extent of other transactions under the bill will depend on what requests may be made of Australia in future years. Details of the budget treatment of transactions under the bill are set out in the explanatory memorandum. I present the explanatory memorandum for the bill and I commend the bill to the House.
Debate (on motion by Mr Martyn Evans) adjourned.

debateinfo.title: HEALTH LEGISLATION AMENDMENT (HEALTH CARE AGREEMENTS) BILL 1998

subdebate.1.para: Bill presented by Dr Wooldridge, and read a first time.

talk.start.para: â€”I move:

speech.para: That the bill be now read a second time.

This bill shows the government's commitment to retaining Medicare as a system, ensuring that all Australians can gain access to health services they need and ensuring that Australians enjoy a world class health system. This bill provides the basic framework for agreements between the Commonwealth and states for the provision by the states of acute health services to public patients in return for Commonwealth financial assistance.

The Australian health care agreements, as they will be known, will provide financial assistance fairly and equitably and will introduce new measures that will alleviate some of the problems that have been experienced in past agreementsâ€”problems such as cost shifting between levels of government and artificial barriers to care.

As well as providing for ongoing financial assistance, the legislation that I am introducing today provides special assistance for national health development initiatives. This assistance will provide support for major projects to enhance and improve the acute care system, improving the efficiency and effectiveness of health care delivery, improving patient outcomes in relation to the delivery of these services and addressing the factors that lead to avoidable or unnecessary hospitalisation.

The Commonwealth will not be imposing uses for this money on the states but will instead be inviting proposals from the states as to how the money might be best spent. I envisage that many projects would seek to improve the integration of the acute care sector with the wider health care system or improve the linkage of information technology across the system.

This legislation also provides for the retention of important features of previous agreements. These include agreed principles for the provision of services. States will be required to put in place arrangements to ensure equitable access to services for all eligible persons regardless of their geographic location. The legislation also retains the need for states to make available a public hospital charter and an appropriate complaints mechanism. Funding under the agreement is dependent on the services being available to the public.

As I said earlier, one of the most significant issues that has dogged current agreements has been that of cost shifting. The Commonwealth believes that the states have shifted services from public hospitals that they fund on to the Medicare benefits and pharmaceutical benefits programs that we fund. The states, on the other hand, argue that if services can be funded under Commonwealth programs, then they ought to be.

The legislation being introduced today will address this issue by establishing a health care information commissioner as a statutory authority responsible for the collection, analysis and dissemination of de-identified patient level data from the Commonwealth and the states. The commissioner will identify the movement of services around the health care system and report on how these services are funded. The commissioner's reports will be made available to all parties. The agreements will make it absolutely clear that the Commonwealth will be unable to make adjustments to states' funding except on the basis of a report from the commissioner. Subject to the agreement of the states and territories, it is possible that the functions of the commissioner will be assumed by the Health Insurance Commission. In any event, the same stringent privacy requirements that presently apply to the HIC will apply to the commissioner.

The legislation and the agreements will maintain the fundamental principle of universal access to acute health services on the basis of need, delivering on our commitment to maintain Medicare. But equally as important, agreements made under this legislation will lead to a reformed acute health care system, with better integration of different types of care, improved patient outcomes and more appropriate types of care. The agreements will provide appropriate adjustments for growth and the demand of the health system over the next five years while providing funding to restructure the system to meet demand into the longer term.

This bill will maintain Australia's reputation as having one of the best health care systems in the world and will continue to do so well into the 21st century. I commend the bill to the House. I present an explanatory memorandum to the bill.
Debate (on motion by Mr Martyn Evans) adjourned.

subdebate.1.para: Bill presented by Mr Miles, and read a first time.

talk.start.para: â€”I move:

speech.para: That the bill be now read a second time.

The Child Support Legislation Amendment Bill 1998 contains substantial measures which form part of the major reform package to the child support scheme announced by the government on 30 September 1997.

The reform package underscores the fundamental principle that parents are primarily responsible for the financial support of their children. The government, through these measures, will not intrude unnecessarily into people's lives. Rather, it will provide a safety net to ensure children are adequately supported and that the community is not asked to carry an undue burden. The package addresses most of the concerns raised by the Joint Select Committee on Certain Family Issues.
Parents' capacity to provide financial support

The administrative formula will be modified by increasing the liable parent's exempted income, including an allowance for a shared care child and reducing a carer's disregarded income. Child support payable by a liable parent with a subsequent family will reduce the income used in calculating their entitlement to family allowance.

The bill will amend the basis of the administrative formula by increasing a parent's taxable income by adding back rental property losses and including exempt foreign employment income. It will also provide for a more accurate assessment through using the most current taxable income, thereby eliminating the requirement to apply an inflation factor.

Assessments are to be modified to take into account certain kinds of parents' agreements as to care arrangements, both factual and lawful daily care of a child and a step-child where a liable parent has a legal duty to maintain the step-child.

The bill will extend the date by which a person may lodge an estimate of income up to 31 July. The Registrar will be able to reject an estimate where it does not reflect the person's income. The bill will reduce the complexity of the departure from assessment process, clarify the rights of parents to exchange information and the circumstances under which hearings will be granted. The Registrar will have the right to initiate a departure when satisfied that a parent's financial circumstances are not accurately reflected in their child support assessment.
Parents' rights and responsibilities
The bill will provide the following rights:
. either parent may apply for an administrative assessment of child support
. the Registrar may suspend payments of child support where the Family Court has been asked to make a decision

. parents may move from child support collection of child support to private collection by agreement at any time and the Registrar may require parents to move to private collection where satisfied that regular payments are likely to continue
. a parent may elect to end their administrative assessment where the Secretary to the Department of Social Security has granted an exemption
. a child support assessment or agreement may continue until the end of the school year if a child turning 18 is a full-time student
. information shown on an assessment notice in relation to children of a liable parent will be limited
. parents may object to all decisions of the Registrar made in relation to administrative assessments.

Introduction of a child support minimum liability including provision to withhold from income support payments will emphasise the primary responsibility of parents in caring for their children. The Registrar's power to reduce the minimum liability will be limited. However, if the liable parent is receiving less than $260 income, they may make an application to the Registrar to seek to have the liability reduced to nil.
The bill includes measures which will put greater onus on parents to notify changes in circumstances.
Flexible and streamlined administration
The bill contains improvements to streamline administration of the scheme and provides greater flexibility to meet parents' particular circumstances. These improvements include:
. removing retrospectivity in relation to the commencement of a liability
. enhancing payment options for liable parents
. providing flexibility in how information is provided
. allowing the Registrar to offset debts between parents.

The important reforms in this bill will represent the second stage of this government's response to the Joint Select Committee on Certain Family Issues. Other changes were introduced in 1997. In conclusion, as part of getting on with the job in this area, the government will establish a task force of government members to examine further proposed changes to the child support scheme. I commend the bill to the House and present the Explanatory Memorandum.

talk.start.para: â€”On behalf of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts and Audit I present the report No. 356: An advisory report on the Tax Law Improvement Bill (No. 2) 1997

speech.para: Ordered that the report be printed.

talk.start.para: â€”by leaveâ€”Mr Speaker, I take this opportunity, my first, to congratulate you on your promotion to high office. On behalf of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts and Audit, I present the committee's report No. 356: An advisory report on the Tax Law Improvement Bill (No. 2) 1997 . This is the third occasion that the committee has reported on a bill arising from the rewrite of the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936. The first tranche of rewrite legislation was reviewed during 1996, with the committee tabling its findings in August of that year. The second tranche was reviewed in 1997, with the committee reporting in March 1997. The committee looks forward to reviewing further rewrite legislation as it is introduced into the parliament following the return of the government at the next election. I expect to have the pleasure of tabling those reports in the next parliament.

speech.para: The rewrite is being undertaken by the Tax Law Improvement Project, TLIP, situated in the Australian Taxation Office and has the aim of simplifying and restructuring the existing law to make it clear. This should reduce compliance costs to taxpayers. The Tax Law Improvement Bill (No. 2) 1997 has attracted considerable interest from stakeholders as it contains the important capital gains tax provisions. The committee, because of its long involvement in the rewrite of the 1936 act, has recognised recurrent themes that have arisen during the review of this bill and has commented on these matters in the report.

The first recurrent theme is that stakeholders have been frustrated for some time with the inability of TLIP to address the issues of a small `p' policy nature. The committee has acknowledged this and, in report No. 348, the review of the second tranche of legislation recommended that TLIP's mandate be extended to encompass the consideration of small policy issues. Although the government has not agreed with this recommendation, the Assistant Treasurer (Senator Kemp) has put in place a separate mechanism involving stakeholders by which such issues can be addressed. The committee welcomes this initiative and believes this may satisfy the thrust of its earlier recommendation.

A second recurrent theme observed by the committee is a continuing perception among some stakeholders that TLIP defers to an Australian Taxation Office view when translating the existing law into new law. Several submissions have focused on this issue. The committee notes that the perception is strongly held by some stakeholders and has been rigorously defended by TLIP. The committee has discussed this matter in the report and provided some of the evidence as an appendix. The committee notes that, if individual stakeholders strongly disagree with the stance taken by TLIP on a particular matter, there are various other avenues to seek redress. This is entirely appropriate and forms a keystone of our system of government.

A third recurrent theme, and one which appears to have had a critical impact on this review, relates to the time available to review the bill. The bill contains the important and complex capital gains tax provisions but, unfortunately, the time allowed for stakeholders to respond to exposure drafts of the legislation has been truncated, and the time for the committee to review the bill after its introduction has been short, especially when compared to the complex issues upon which the committee has been asked to report. As well, there is evidence of undue haste in preparing the bill because it was incomplete when introduced. One division and several transitional provisions have yet to be released. The truncated consultation process and the incompleteness of the bill have led witnesses to express a lack of confidence in their ability to adequately review the proposed legislation and identify unintended consequences. They have called for the implementation of the bill to be delayed, or for a no detriment clause to be added.

The committee, in reviewing the bill, has found itself in a similar position to the stakeholders. The incompleteness of the bill and the short time for review has prevented the committee reviewing the legislation with the thoroughness it would like. The committee has therefore recommended that the implementation of two divisions and one subdivision of the bill be delayed pending its review by the committee. These provisions were released too late for the committee to review them or have not been released at all. The committee also notes the transitional provisions relating to 12 areas have yet to be released. The committee considers it inappropriate to go further, and has not agreed with calls to delay the entire bill. The committee acknowledges the imperative to maintain momentum in the progressive introduction of clearer law to replace the 1936 act, and is encouraged by the fact that witnesses have commented favourably on the clarity of the bill. Taxpayers should not be denied recourse to legislation which is designed to be clearer and which should reduce compliance costs.

The alternative to delaying the bill advocated by some witnessesâ€”the introduction of a no detriment clauseâ€”has also not been supported by the committee. Such a clause would prevent closing off the existing law. In reviewing previous rewrite legislation, the committee supported the view that the rewritten legislation should replace provisions of the 1936 act and should not operate in tandem with that act. The committee has not changed its view and believes it is more appropriate for taxpayers to rely on the existing section 1-3 and the traditional avenue of legislative amendment to protect against unintended consequences.

The committee, in reviewing individual clauses of the bill, has made a number of recommendations which relate to policy issues which are outside TLIP's mandate; major technical issues which are sufficiently weighty to require substantial review which may be beyond TLIP's capacity to undertake or be sufficiently broad in scope to impinge on policy matters; and minor technical issues of a non-policy nature which TLIP can address. The report also contains, as an appendix, comments on individual clauses of the bill made in submissions and by witnesses, together with responses by TLIP. The committee believes that this will be a guide to the evidence and assist the debate on the details of the bill.

In conclusion, and on behalf of the committee, I would like to thank all those who have contributed to this review. Many have provided submissions to the committee and appeared as witnesses at the committee's public hearing. In particular, I would like to thank the private sector representatives on TLIP and TLIP's private sector consultative committee. I am personally indebted to my colleagues on the committee who dedicated much time and effort to completing this review in a very short time frame. I would also like to thank members of the secretariat: Dr Margot Kerley, the JCPAA Secretary; Dr John Carter, who was the inquiry secretary; and Ms Tiana Gray, who was also involved in the inquiry. I also thank Mr Gary Martin, who was seconded to the secretariat to assist the committee and its secretariat with the review. I commend the report to the House.

talk.start.para: â€”by leaveâ€”I rise to support the comments of the Chairman of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts and Audit particularly on the review of the Tax Law Improvement Bill (No. 2) 1997 . As has been the case in the long history of the JCPAA, as it is now, this recommendation and report are unanimous across party lines. I am happy to make some remarks as I have had a long interest in capital gains tax particularly, as members would be aware, in the small business area.

speech.para: This bill, as outlined by the chairman, the honourable member for La Trobe (Mr Charles), contains important clarification of capital gains tax provisions. The tax law improvement project, commonly known as TLIP, was formed in 1993 to rewrite the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936 in plain English. In 1996, attention was directed to an important area of tax policy, that is, capital gains tax. Subsequently, the Tax Law Improvement Bill (No. 2) 1997 was introduced into this House. The bill was then referred to the Joint Committee of Public Accounts and Audit for its consideration. As usual, the government allowed little time for due consideration. This put stress on staff, committee members and, in particular, those wishing to make submissions. However, a number of public hearings were heldâ€”I was pleased to see that a round table format was adoptedâ€”in which all participants were able to raise their concerns or as many concerns as possible.

In February this year, a half-day public hearing was held to enable discussion of the material released as government amendments. All members of the sectional committee firmly believe that the tax law rewrite will undoubtedly result in better law for taxpayers, but members of the committee felt that there was a rising level of disquiet in the tax community of the TLIP team's inability to deal with policy issuesâ€”in particular, small `p' policy issues.
I will now turn to one of the recommendations which the committee resolved. Recommendation No. 4 states:

When the Joint Committee of Public Accounts and Audit is asked to review future Tax Law Improvement Project legislation, all of the proposed legislation and associated consequential and transitional provisions should be introduced into the Parliament together and the Committee is given adequate time for a thorough review.

There was some debate in the committee that the haste in introducing the bill had led to inadequate consultation. Whilst there is some strong merit in this argument, the committee did not support the recommendation that the bill should be delayed further. The committee firmly believes that taxpayers should not have to wait any longer for legislation which is designed to be clearer and which will reduce compliance costs.

I look forward to further developments to legislation which will assist the development of better law for the Australian taxpayers. Like the rest of the committee, I thank all those who have contributed and the staff for their contributions. I commend the report to the House.

talk.start.para: â€”by leaveâ€”I note the presence in the chamber of the previous chair of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts and Audit, the member for Fairfax (Mr Somlyay), as well as the current chair, the member for La Trobe (Mr Charles). The report we are considering today relates to the tax law improvement project process of the rewriting of the tax act, as has been mentioned by previous speakers. I will focus on a couple of issues on this occasion, given the shortage of time. The Tax Law Improvement Bill (No. 2) 1997 is the third bill that we have had to consider as part of this rewrite. It is a massive jobâ€”a job that is well overdue. It is a job which has been done, under the circumstances, in a pretty effective fashion.

speech.para: I will focus on a couple of points that have been mentioned by previous speakers. One is the question of small `p' policy issues which have come up continually during this rewrite. I congratulate the Assistant Treasurer (Senator Kemp) on finally having a process to consider these issues in-house. I say `finally', so I am damning him with faint praise. The fact is that this was a recommendation that came out of a report, I think some 18 months ago, from the JCPAA. It has taken the government that long to respond to it. Now that it has responded, I congratulate it. I hope the new process works. The proof of the pudding will be in the eating, though. It will take some time before we can establish whether the new process will be effective. It is a step in the right direction towards at least trying to consider some of these issues and to resolve them. There is no doubt that there is a range of things which could be addressed in the committee structure which has been proposed if the government embraces it.

The other issue which has been referred to by previous speakers is the time available to review this bill. I will make some general comments here which relate to the operation of the committee system under this government. Congratulations go to the governmentâ€”again, I suppose I am damning them with faint praiseâ€”for the number of pieces of legislation which have been referred to the JCPAA, which is a good thing in terms of the scrutiny of government and the consideration of legislation. I congratulate them on that front. However, one of the problems this committee faces in particularâ€”I think other committees also share this difficultyâ€”is having to do more reports and consider more legislation with fewer resources or unreasonable time lines for the proper consideration of bills.

Having a scrutiny system through parliamentary committees is a very important part of ensuring that bills are considered properly and that parliament is involved in that process. But not giving committees sufficient time or resources to do this is, in itself, an abrogation of the responsibilities that government and parliament have to ensure that job is done properly. Although I think that the secretariat and members of this committee in particular have done a sterling job under the circumstances, the fact is, on matters such as this, we are not being given sufficient time to properly consider bills. This particular bill is the third in the process of the continual review and rewrite of the original tax act. After complaints were made by the committee on previous occasions and a request was made to government that more time be given, what happened? We were given more timeâ€”two more weeks for what is clearly the most complicated component of that tax rewrite. As is noted by the report and by the recommendations, major components of what relates to this bill, to this section of the rewrite, are not available for consideration. In effect, we have been forced to consider an element of what is the whole in this issueâ€”if you like, several pieces of the jigsawâ€”and to make conclusions as to whether that is a good or a bad thing.

We have done that to the best of our abilities. But have we done it as well as we should have? No. Have we been given enough time to do it? No. Have we had enough resources to do it? No. Have the private sector and those who are interested in this particular issue in the community had enough time to consider these matters? No. Do we, therefore, have the best under the circumstances? My worry is that we do not. But time will tell.

Hopefully we will not face this situation again, because there will be more components of the rewrite coming through and they will be considered by this committee. On those occasions, I hope to not be standing here once againâ€”I am now, I think, for the third timeâ€”complaining about the time that we have available. However, I have doubts about that. I suspect that I will be, on a continuing basis.

If a government prides itself on saying that it values the work of parliament, that it sees it as a more important role than what it maintains others have in the past, I think there has to be more to that than the rhetoric. There has to be some action, and I do not see the action that is required. Having said that, I commend the report to the House as I think a reasonable examination of what was available to be examined, but I am sure I will be standing here again in the future on the same issue.

subdebate.1.para: Motion (by Mr Somlyay)â€”agreed to:

That, in accordance with section 5 of the Parliament Act 1974 , the House approves the following proposal for work in the Parliamentary Zone which was presented to the House on 2 March 1998, namely: Additional drinking fountains in the public gardens and on the tennis court pavilions of Parliament House.
Debate resumed from 11 March, on motion by Mr Reith:
That the bill be now read a second time.
upon which Mr Tanner moved by way of amendment:
That all words after "That" be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:

"whilst not declining to give the Bill a second reading, the House declines to give the Bill any further consideration until the Government provides guarantees to the Parliament that the sale of ANL will proceed on the basis that the company will continue to employ Australians in its operations".

talk.start.para: â€”The mere mention of a proposed sale of ANL set off a series of strikes by wharfies and seafarers that cost the government, according to one union estimate, up to $40 million. The deal brokered by the then Minister for Transport, the member for Kingsford-Smith, Laurie Brereton, did not reform the ANL; it protected ANL from competition, compounding the inefficiencies that already existed. Under the Brereton deal, international seafarers became tax exempt; ship owners could claim a greater depreciation on their vessels; foreign fleets were to be locked out of the Australian coastal trade; and foreign seamen were to be kept off Australian ships.

speech.para: The due diligence report considered the four sale options for ANL: first, minority or majority float of ANL; second, minority or majority sale of the Commonwealth's share of ANL; third, reconstruction of ANL to a domestic business;

and, fourth, the managed trade down of ANL and sale of its constituent assets and, where possible, selected businesses as a going concern. The report recommended that the last option, a managed trade down of ANL, was the only viable disposal option for the Commonwealth, yet neither the former transport minister nor the former finance ministerâ€”indeed, Australia's failed former finance minister Beazleyâ€”could adopt these policies. Worse than not being able to implement the recommendations of the due diligence report was the damaging comments made by the member for Kingsford-Smith about the proposed privatisation of ANL. In August of 1994, the then transport minister said:
It's not a case of privatising ANL; you couldn't give it away.

This statement, which drew strong criticism from the Auditor-General's office, was an act of economic vandalism by a minister of the Crown. Here was a minister who, on the one hand, was trying to sell a wholly owned government company and, on the other hand, was talking down the value of the asset to potential purchasers.

talk.start.para: â€”Who was that?

â€”Laurie Brereton. The former Minister for Transport then sacked the old ANL board and appointed a new boardâ€”a board stacked with Labor Party mates whose background in shipping was highly questionable. Labor mate Neville Wran was the board's chairmanâ€”well looked after on over $150,000 for working roughly a day a week for six months. In an interview on Meet the Press on Sunday, 1 October 1995, the member for Kingsford-Smith said one of two things would happen to ANL:

speech.para: Either the line will be sold to P&O or there'll be a very radical restructure to stop it losing any further money. I've always preferred the sale option.
The government shares that viewâ€”sell ANL. In the same interview, Brereton said:
This company lost $20-$25 million a year every year for five years. Someone had to put an end to that.
He is right. They should have, but they did not. By the time Labor left office in 1996, ANL's accumulated debt was over $224.7 million, and none of the initial recommendations had been implemented.

The ANL Sale Bill 1997 comprehensively covers the sale of ANL and sets out conditions for the government's divestment of its interest in ANL. Under the bill, the existing long service and maternity leave entitlements of ANL employees are protected. Adequate provisions are made in the bill to ensure that the Safety, Rehabilitation and Compensation Act 1988 continues to apply after the sale date in respect of injuries sustained by ANL employees covered by the act prior to the sale.

As part of the preparation for the sale of ANL, the bill amends the ANL Act 1956 to remove private provisions that would not appropriately apply in the case of a private company, such as the specific statutory protection of trading names. The bill extinguishes ANL's accumulated tax losses and ensures that these losses will not be able to offset for income purposes any profits or capital gains made by ANL after the sale. The bill also removes ANL from the operations of a number of acts that apply to the Commonwealth controlled entities. These acts include the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act 1977, the Director of Public Prosecutions Act 1983 and the Judiciary Act 1903. The bill also ends ANL's future liability under the Commonwealth Borrowing Levy Act 1987.

In an undertaking to sell Commonwealth assets, the usual debate emerges from the Left. Of course, they often say that there are problems in selling government business entities, but there are numerous very successful examples of privatisation and partial privatisation in Australia, including the Commonwealth Bank, Qantas and Telstra. We should remember, of course, that Labor were not going to sell the Commonwealth Bank. They promised not to sell it. They were not going to sell Qantas. Of course, we should have sold them long ago. We have done so, and Australians are very much involved.

The partial privatisation of Telstra conferred great benefits to Australians not only by increasing competition and service but also through the direct investment of 559,000 Australians who entered the share market for the first time to buy Telstra shares. The partial privatisation of Telstra dramatically increased Australia's private share ownership to 40.4 per cent, giving Australia the second highest share participation rate in the world just behind that of the US at 43 per cent.

It is important to examine the profile of Australia's newest shareholders. Many investors are younger people: a third of all Australian investors are aged between 25 and 34. Many investors are low income Australians: 45.1 per cent of Australian households investing have incomes of between $30,000 and $50,000. Many investors are women: 36.2 per cent of Australian women have some involvement in the share market.

Last year, Telstra reported a profit before tax and abnormals of some $3.8 billion. Last year Telstra paid $1.3 billion in taxes to the Commonwealth. Last year, ANL's accumulated losses were $211.2 million. We believe Australians should no longer have to subsidise ANL and we are taking the tough political decision to ensure that they no longer have to carry the burden of ANL.

talk.start.para: â€”I congratulate the member for Forrest (Mr Prosser) for a very good speech on the reason why this legislation is going throughâ€”that is, the sale of ANL. The ANL Sale Bill 1997 fulfils yet another election pledge by this government to sell a business which has no place in public ownership. Clearly, the litany of disaster in the sale process that was conducted by the previous government demonstrates that point.

speech.para: The role of government is to focus on core services which the private sector cannot or should not do, such as law enforcement. Most would agree with the principle that public money should not be risked in competitive business; that public money, that taxpayers' money, should not be risked in businesses that do not perform or do not belong in public ownership. Further, the government is much better placed to regulate and promote competition if it is not at the same time a competitor with those businesses.

The sale of the 100 per cent government owned company was announced in the 1997-98 budget. This bill has two purposes in particular: firstly, it enables the sale to proceed quickly once the government has announced a timetable and, secondly, it gives the government more opportunity to get the best value for the company. The sale could proceed without legislation, but this is a more efficient way to do the job. The bill removes ANL's accumulated tax losses for the year prior to the saleâ€”tax losses in the order of $80 million. I might add that these were tax losses that were quite conveniently going to be traded off under the previous government. It is amazing how government enterprises can trade off tax losses but private enterprises cannot.

ANL is not just a shipping company; it also has land transportation, container park and servicing interests. It employs about 240 workers and carries three per cent of Australia's trade by value. The importance of the waterfront cannot be exaggerated. In spite of the advent of cheaper air cargo, three-quarters of our imports and exports are con ducted by sea. Waterfront services account for a significant component of our export pricesâ€”indeed, about four per cent in the case of agricultural and mining commodities and about two to three per cent in the case of manufacturing. So it is a major cost factor for our exports. That is why waterfront reform is important for Australiaâ€”even Labor does recognise that begrudgingly. Labor's attempt at reform 10 years ago achieved very little and cost the nation $420 million.

talk.start.para: â€”An embarrassment.

â€”As the member for Parkes says, an absolute embarrassment. Labor was prevented from implementing durable reform by union bosses, just as it was humiliated by the MUA over the attempted sale of ANL in 1995. Labor has learnt its lesson and now it dares not to say or do anything that might get it on the wrong side of one Mr John Coombs. In fact, it opposes any change which will lead to an end of the MUA's labour monopoly. That was one of the principal reasons why the ANL sale did not go through in 1995.

speech.para: Let us look at a little bit of history. The Commonwealth has been trying to sell ANL since 1991, but Labor governments were dictated to by their union paymasters. Labor eventually put it in the too-hard basket along with balancing the budget, along with tax reform and along with waterfront reform. This was the boast of the Maritime Workers Journal in 1995:
The Keating Government has decided to extend the deadline for ANL rather than confront the unions and a second national stoppage.

Indeed, it was the member for Kingsford-Smith (Mr Brereton) who told the Australian newspaper on 24 August 1994: `You couldn't give it away; that's the reality.' The reality was that they did have a buyer. In fact, the buyer was P&O and it was willing to take ANL off the taxpayers' hands and it was willing to save the Commonwealth an enormous amount of money and to restructure ANL, which is Australia's only shipping line.

In fact, in 1995 P&O offered $19.5 million for ANL. More importantly, P&O was prepared to take $120 million of ANL's debt liabilities, which were part of $330 million. So the actual sale price was about $140 million. This was a good deal. It was a good deal because they realised that it was going to be difficult to sell ANL, which was hamstrung by draconian conditions placed on it by the MUA, but it was the MUA's phobia and paranoia of P&O because of changes in the industry in the UK that prevented the sale. Of course the Labor Party did absolutely nothing about it, even though they were advocating it. The then Managing Director of P&O Australia, Mr Richard Hein, stated:
In soccer terms, the decision not to sell ANL resulted in a score of Unions 1â€”Government 0. Although P&O paid more than a million dollars to be on the field, we hardly got a kick all day.

The reality was that there was a buyer, there was a process, but it was hijacked and derailed. Even when they brought in Mr Neville Wran, their head consultant, to sort it outâ€”and, as the previous speaker said, he was paid an enormous amount of money for six monthsâ€”he too recommended to the government to take the offer, but it was not accepted.

Over the period 1991 to 1997 ANL has continued to cost taxpayers well over $130 million. How responsible is that for a government? However, that loss was reduced to $1.6 million in the first year we came to power. In the first year the coalition was in office there was continual restructuring of ANL to save taxpayers an enormous amount of money.

The new management of ANL has taken on the coalition's positive approach, and they are to be congratulated for that. The member for Hume (Mr Sharp) should also be congratulated as he gave the momentum for the turnaround when he was the Minister for Transport and Regional Development. However, the downfall in Asian markets means that ANL may soon require substantial taxpayer funded injections of equity if it stays in public ownership. The time to sell is now.

The irony is that the MUA basically forced them to take up more Asian trade. There is an enormous amount of trade going between Australia and Japan. Most of those container movements to Japan are in refrigerated ETUs or 20-foot containers. They are full when they go to Japan and they are half empty on their way back. A lot of those strategic decisions were enforced by the MUA. The MUA tried to sell ANL to an American firm, but it was unsuccessful. Their job is not to dictate terms, and that is precisely what they have been doing.

This government, as opposed to the ALP, does not take its orders from union bosses. We will sell ANL by 30 June 1998. Any doubt about this government's ability to conduct successful privatisations was certainly dispelledâ€”and it is encouraging to see the Minister for Finance and Administration (Mr Fahey) in the chamberâ€”by the hugely successful sale of Telstra. The difference with the sale of Telstra was that the lion's share, 80 or 90 per cent, was used to repay debt and the remainder went to the very successful program, the Natural Heritage Trust. This is in stark contrast to the Australian Labor Party, who were the leaders of capitalism with the privatisation of Qantas, Australian Airlines, Commonwealth Serum Laboratories, our only aircraft manufacturer and the icon that they said they would never sell, the Commonwealth Bank. They all went to recurrent expenditure and that was the last that was seen of them.

I am pleased to hear that the opposition is offering conditional support for this bill, which is the least they could do since they tried unsuccessfully to sell the company themselves. It was a litany of disasters. However, their amendments relating to employees having to work under Australian awards does smack of the usual hypocrisy since it was the ALP which secretly removed the restriction in 1993. It is interesting that the more things change the more they stay the same. I urge all members in this House to support this bill. It is a good piece of legislation. It will get rid of a very uneconomic enterprise for Australia and put it into private hands so that it can do the job just as the National Farmers Federation are doing with waterfront reform at Webb Dock.

talk.start.para: â€”Probably no area of policy better symbolises the paucity of business acumen of the Labor Party than the handling of the sale of ANL, especially by the previous Minister for Transport, Mr Brereton, and the previous Minister for Finance, Mr Beazley. Their whole management of the sale of ANL has been nothing less than a monumental stuff up.

speech.para: The sale process was dragged out for years without result. It exposed the sheer incompetence of Labor ministers that tried to handle it, it cost taxpayers tens of millions of dollarsâ€”the previous speaker, the member for Richmond (Mr Anthony), spoke of a figure of $130 million in this regardâ€”and it showed how beholden the ALP is to the trade union movement in this country, especially the Maritime Union of Australia, the wharfies. Above all else, it contrasts how much more proficiently the coalition can handle these issues and, interestingly, it also contrasts how differently the press report on these events.

Imagine if the coalition had made errors to the degree that the previous government did. We would have been crucified in the media. They would have been calling for the ministers' resignations. There was not a whisper of this in the press. We were lucky to be able to get a paragraph forward on how they had dreadfully messed this up.

By contrast, we have the present Minister for Transport and Regional Development, Mr Vaile, and the present Minister for Finance and Administration, Mr Fahey, handling this so smoothly. Again, there has not been a mention in the press of how competent they are. It is well worth mentioning what an incredible job the present Minister for Finance and Administration, who is at the table, did with Telstra. It was oversubscribed by five times, I think. People were begging to buy the shares. It went through so smoothly and so successfully and is worth thousands of millions of dollars to the taxpayers of this country. I am sure that, come the next election, that will be recognised.

Contrast that with the previous government's record. It cost well over $100 million, it delivered a result which came to zero at the end of day and was an acute embarrassment. It shows how the Labor Party knows absolutely nothing about business whatsoever. It cannot handle money. It just does not understand the scene at all.

The saga of this sale goes back to 1991 when the Labor Party started speaking about it. They appointed Price Waterhouse in July 1991 to do a complete independent study of ANL. In August 1991â€”and this is running up to seven years ago nowâ€”they decided that they would sell 49 per cent of ANL. They announced that in the budget of that year. Price Waterhouse told them in the following year, `Look, it is not working, 49 per cent is not going to work. If you are going to sell the thing, sell 100 per cent for economy of scale reasons.' The Labor Party had not thought of it.

In the budget of the next year, August 1992, the Labor government again said that they would sell 100 per cent of ANL. They called for expressions of interest as soon as practicable, and in May 1993, when they were bringing down the budget for that year, they again said that they would sell it. That is three budgets in a row when they said they would sell it. But they suddenly brought in this new caveat that, even though they were selling 100 per cent, foreign equity would be restricted to 49 per cent. Then a year later, for heaven's sake, they announced the start of the due diligence processâ€”talk about dragging the feet; this is three years down the trackâ€”and in the May 1994 budget they announced that the due diligence process had started.

In August of the same year the Labor government suddenly announced that the sale of ANL was not practical and withdrew ANL from sale and appointed, as the previous speaker said, Neville Wran, Malcolm Turnbull and a couple of others to do an assessment of ANL. They were paid reportedly $150,000 each for 52 days work, with the Minister for Transport at the time, the member for Kingsford-Smith (Mr Brereton), who has just joined us, saying you could not give it away, even though they were giving taxpayers' money away to Neville Wran and Malcolm Turnbull. Let us hope that when the country becomes a republic it will be run better than that. They said they would be restructuring ANL for viability. In September 1994 ANL indeed sold its 25 per cent interest in Australian Stevedores Holding Pty Ltd for $28 million.

In May of the following year, 1995â€”the Labor Party were still in power then, amaz inglyâ€”P&O put in a conditional offer for 100 per cent of the shares of ANL. One would have thought that if the government had had half a brain they would have snapped that up. In fact, the ANL board, in August 1995, recommended that the sale be made to P&O. The board said:
ANL is simply too small to have a secure future in international shipping.

In other words, it should be sold off. But later that month the government announced that the sale would be subject to the veto of the Maritime Union of Australia, and the following month, September 1995, the ANL sale bill was passed by this House. I remember speaking to it.

In the following month, things had slowed down because the wharfies were objecting to this and the government put the thing on hold. P&O, bless its heart, agreed to a one-month extension of the sale. Those negotiations with the wharfies went ahead, and in November 1995 the government announced that they were withdrawing ANL from sale and, to try and save face, that they were going to restructure ANL and then sell it. When were they going to sell it off? In the 14th year of governmentâ€”like everything else they were going to do in the 14th year. They had been in power for 13 years, had these stop-start, on again off again sale situations and in the end delivered nothing. As we know, in March 1996 we had an election and the Labor Party were thrown out of office, not surprisingly.

We announced in December last year that we would commence the sale of ANL and it would be completed by the end of this financial year. We asked for expressions of interest, which closed at the end of February, and I can report to the House that the expressions of interest that have come in are very encouraging indeed. What greater contrast could there be in the way the government business of this country is handledâ€”us compared with them. It is chalk and cheese indeed. Probably no episode better demonstrates the competency of this government to be returned at the next election compared with them. You have only to see what is going on on the waterfront today. The former government is beholden to the waterfront. It did nothing about it for 13 years except waste $400 million in that area. We are not spending any taxpayers' money at all and have put in place legislation that will clear that up, as we will clear up the sale of ANL.

talk.start.para: â€”I thank all honourable members for their contributions in this debate on the ANL Sale Bill. It is a debate which is effectively a repeat of what occurred in this House in the earlier part of the 1990s, and of course the issue itself is a revisiting of that particular sale process that was initiated under Labor. As I indicated in the House yesterday, it was first suggested in 1991, it was announced in the 1991-92 budget and in 1995 it came to nothing. It fizzed out.

speech.para: One of the reasons that it did not eventuate, despite negotiations that occurred in those interim years from announcement up until the time of simply withdrawing, as Labor did in 1995, was the conditions that Labor was forced to put on the sale process at that time. Of course, in this debate Labor seeks to revisit that area. It seeks to reimpose the conditions that were deemed necessary, by the unions I suspect, back in the earlier part of the 1990s by moving an amendment, as the spokesman in this area, the honourable member for Melbourne (Mr Tanner), did in the course of his contribution to the debate.

I would like to come straight to that amendment and indicate clearly that the government will oppose the amendment. The reason for this is, as I have indicated, that it did not work in the earlier part of this decade; it will not work now. The simple fact is that the Labor Party when in government recognised that it could not work then. That is why we see some hypocrisy in this repeat, this revisit, this attempt now to bring back the golden share process, which the honourable member for Melbourne spoke of in the course of his contribution.

If I take the House back to Labor's attempt when in government, they proposed that there be a provision in the legislation that would allow the government to retain a share without voting rights, a share that really had no power. There is really no logic in why the government would sell yet retain a share. After considerable interference and considerable advice no doubt from the Maritime Union of Australia, the government were forced to acknowledge that the provisions in their legislation at that time would not work.

I note that the former Minister for Transport, the honourable member for Kingsford-Smith (Mr Brereton), and the former Minister for Finance, the current Leader of the Opposition (Mr Beazley), issued a joint release on 30 November 1995. That release contained inter alia the paragraph I shall read. The two ministers said:

However, the options in this regard were high cost and would have also involved industry and policy precedents which were not acceptable to the Government, and a sale has therefore not proved a viable option in the current circumstances.

In their sales legislation, there was just nothing in the provision that had been included. The member for Melbourne suggested that the golden share would protect the Australian Labor Party policy of Australian crewing and would enable, as it was supposed to have done in 1995, the government to continue to ensure that ANL employed Australians in its privatised operation. That simply did not work then and it will not work now. The very same government issued a press release acknowledging that at that time.

What we know occurred and what we know is the truth of the circumstances is that the Maritime Union of Australia and the preferred buyerâ€”P&Oâ€”could not strike an acceptable deal and the sale was dropped. In other words, the Maritime Union of Australia said, `Unless it is sold on our conditions, then it will not happen. We will prevent it from happening.'

This government does not sell its assets this way. The amendment would unnecessarily fetter the sale process which has been under way for some time, and the opposition has known of the sale for some months. The government has made it clear that it intends to sell Australian National Line. Despite that fact, it was only yesterday that we saw this attempt of new Labor to go back to the past. This new Labor, with its failed policies, is trying to repeat those policies or impose those policies on the government today.

This government's policy in respect of the sale of ANL is consistent with policies that we have adopted in respect of the sale of all other government assets. It includes the process of guaranteeing in legislation the rights and entitlements of all employees of any particular entityâ€”in this case, of Australian National Lineâ€”up to the time of sale. I shall move amendments to further clarify this in the consideration in detail stage.

As I have said, one underlying factor links together all of the Labor Party's failed attempts to sell ANL from 1991 to 1995â€”that is, the ability of the Maritime Union of Australia to impose conditions on the then Labor government and the then Labor government being incapable of resisting the union's call at that time. It is a shame that that is still around, still alive and still well. I note that the honourable member for Kingsford-Smith, who admitted that failure back in 1995 with that press release. has said that what Labor seeks to impose now did not work then. That is what the press release from the then Minister for Finance and the then Minister for Transport actually stated. It is just puzzling in the extreme to understand why currently there is an attempt to go back to that point, to go back to something that failed.

Australian National Line has not traded well for some considerable time. There has been an accumulated loss since 1990-91 of $204 million. It has not been as great in recent times, but that is because the board, through a restructure that has taken place, has been able to stem the flow of lossesâ€”the flow of losses that has always been picked up by the Australian taxpayers. My recollection is that, in the last three years, the losses have been something like $16 million, $11 million and $1.6 million last year. But the accumulated loss is $204 million.

I find it a little hard to understand why the honourable member for Melbourne puts such store in there being an Australian flag in shipping. The simple fact is that this company has reduced its operations yearly now for a long time. It is a competitive industry and that competitive industry allows anybody to come into the Australian shipping area. The bulk of Australian National Line's business has not been coastal shipping; it has been in the other trades area, as they describe it, the other zones of operation in the worldâ€”north of us in Asiaâ€”and of course it has to compete there.

The government is seeking to stop the drain on taxpayers' money. That is exactly what the Labor Party set out to do earlier in the 1990s. There is no argument: we need to get out of this business which Australia has no right to be in. We can talk about having a flagship in the shipping area. We could perhaps argue that there is still some reason to have a flagship in the airline industry. Labor did not seek to do that. It got out of having an national airline with the sale of the taxpayers' shareholding in Qantas. The same reason applies here.

There was no valid reason to be in the airline industry, and the reason is even more valid for shipping. Even though there was some prospect of profits in the airline, there is none in shipping in the foreseeable future. The losses will continue to mount and may well go back to some of the figures of the early 1990s. The shipping industry is very competitive now, and no-one knows what may occur in a year or two as a result of the currency crisis in Asia.

The government will not accept this amendment. It would be a nonsense to allow once again the interference of the union hand in what is a sensible decisionâ€”one which the former government recognised and which this government reinforces. This government seeks to achieve that objective through the legislative process. I sincerely hope that the parliament supports this so that the sale can continue.

We are now at the expressions of interest stage. Advertisements appeared in the domestic media on 29 January and in the overseas media on 12 and 13 February. Quite a number of domestic and offshore companies have expressed interest, and we will attempt to realise a sale which is in the best interests of Australian taxpayers. You cannot impose from the grave conditions on someone who takes over a process. When a business is sold, to put conditions on how it might operate in the future almost guarantees that you will impose another burden on Australian taxpayers. Why sell in the first place if you leave a burden which flows on after the sale has occurred?

This legislation will facilitate a sensible approach to the sale of this particular asset. It will give the government the best opportunity to stop the drain on taxpayers' funds, and it will enable us to go to the market with confidence. We will be able to attract those who have an interest on the basis that they are buying a business as isâ€”what they see is what they get. They will not come near us if the business for sale has a control factor built into it after the sale eventuates.

I ask the honourable member for Melbourne to spend some time with the honourable member for Kingsford-Smith and to ask the honourable member for Kingsford-Smith to fill him in on what happened in 1995 that caused the honourable member for Kingsford-Smith, along with the then Minister for Finance, to issue a release which said, `This is not what government policy can be aboutâ€”now or ever. We cannot have golden shares; we cannot have conditions. It simply would not work. We tried, but I am sorry, John Coombs, and I am sorry, Tony Papa, you cannot expect us to continue to keep this imposition if you want the sale.'

Unfortunately, the honourable member for Kingsford-Smith, who showed some sensible business acumen at that time, seems to have been rolled by Tony Papa and John Coombs then. It seems that his colleague the honourable member for Melbourne has simply been taken into that position and is under the control of the wine grower in Mr Coombs, and he is seeking to put forward the proposals Mr Coombs wanted then and wants again now. It did not work then and it will not work now.

Please be sensible. Let us see if we can get a sale that gives the shipping industry in this country a chance and enables the subsequent owner of the Australian National Line to keep shipping here. We cannot allow the drain to continue because it does not make sense; and this government will not allow that to occur. We oppose the amendment. I thank honourable members for the broad support that has been givenâ€”with the exception of the amendmentâ€”and I commend the bill to the House.
Question put:
That the words proposed to be omitted (Mr Tanner's amendment) stand part of the question.

para.inline: Division 2â€”Transfers of assets, liabilities etc. of ANL bodies

speech.para: (1) This section applies to an asset of an ANL body.
(2) The Minister for Finance and Administration may, by writing, make any or all of the following declarations:
(a) a declaration that a specified asset vests in a specified person at a specified time without any conveyance, transfer or assignment;

(b) a declaration that a specified instrument relating to a specified asset continues to have effect after the asset vests in a specified person as if a reference in the instrument to the ANL body were a reference to the person;
(c) a declaration that a specified person becomes the ANL body's successor in law in relation to a specified asset immediately after the asset vests in the person.
Note: An asset or instrument may be specified by name, by inclusion in a specified class or in any other way.
(3) A declaration under subsection (2) has effect accordingly.
(4) A copy of a declaration under subsection (2) is to be published in the Gazette within 21 days after the making of the declaration.
(5) Subsection (2) does not prevent the ANL body from transferring an asset to a person otherwise than under that subsection.
(6) If a share in a company vests in a person under this section, the company must register the person as the holder of the share.
(7) Subsection (6) has effect despite anything in the Corporations Law or any other law of the Commonwealth, a State or a Territory.

para.inline: 5D Transfer of contractual rights and obligations by declaration

speech.para: (1) This section applies to a contract to which an ANL body is a party.
(2) The Minister for Finance and Administration may, by writing, declare that the ANL body's rights and obligations under a specified contract:
(a) cease to be rights and obligations of the body at a specified time; and
(b) become rights and obligations of a specified person at that time.

(3) The Minister for Finance and Administration may, by writing, declare that a specified contract continues to have effect after a specified time as if a reference in the contract to the ANL body were a reference to a specified person.

(4) The Minister for Finance and Administration may, by writing, declare that a specified instrument relating to a specified contract continues to have effect, after the ANL body's rights and obligations under the contract become rights and obligations of a specified person, as if a reference in the instrument to the body were a reference to the person.

(5) The Minister for Finance and Administration may, by writing, declare that a specified person becomes the ANL body's successor in law, in relation to the body's rights and obligations under a specified contract, immediately after the body's rights and obligations under the contract become rights and obligations of the person.
(6) A declaration under this section has effect accordingly.
(7) A copy of a declaration under this section is to be published in the Gazette within 21 days after the making of the declaration.
(8) This section does not, by implication, limit section 5C.
Note: A contract or instrument may be specified by name, by inclusion in a specified class or in any other way.
(1) This section applies to a liability of an ANL body.
