(b) a declaration that a specified instrument relating to a specified liability continues to have effect after the liability becomes a liability of a specified person as if a reference in the instrument to the body were a reference to the person;
(c) a declaration that a specified person becomes the body's successor in law in relation to a specified liability immediately after the liability becomes a liability of the person.
Note: A liability or instrument may be specified by name, by inclusion in a specified class or in any other way.
(3) A declaration under subsection (2) has effect accordingly.
(4) A copy of a declaration under subsection (2) is to be published in the Gazette within 21 days after the making of the declaration.
(1) A declaration may be made under this Division, whether or not the declaration is associated with the giving of consideration.
(2) This section is enacted for the avoidance of doubt.

para.inline: Division 3â€”Transfers by the Commonwealth and Commonwealth subsidiaries

speech.para: (1) This section applies to an asset that has vested in the Commonwealth, or in a Commonwealth subsidiary, under section 5C.
(2) The Minister for Finance and Administration may, by writing, make any or all of the following declarations:
(a) a declaration that a specified asset vests in a specified person at a specified time without any conveyance, transfer or assignment;

(b) a declaration that a specified instrument relating to a specified asset continues to have effect after the asset vests in a specified person as if a reference in the instrument to the Commonwealth, or to the Commonwealth subsidiary in question, were a reference to the person;

(c) a declaration that a specified person becomes the Commonwealth's, or the Commonwealth subsidiary's, successor in law in relation to a specified asset immediately after the asset vests in the person.
Note: An asset or instrument may be specified by name, by inclusion in a specified class or in any other way.
(3) A declaration under subsection (2) has effect accordingly.
(4) A copy of a declaration under subsection (2) is to be published in the Gazette within 21 days after the making of the declaration.
(5) Subsection (2) does not prevent the Commonwealth or a Commonwealth subsidiary from transferring an asset to a person otherwise than under that subsection.

para.inline: 5H Transfer of contractual rights and obligations

speech.para: (1) This section applies to a contract where rights and obligations under the contract became rights and obligations of the Commonwealth, or of a Commonwealth subsidiary, under section 5D.

(2) The Minister for Finance and Administration may, by writing, declare that the Commonwealth's rights and obligations, or the rights and obligations of the Commonwealth subsidiary in question, under a specified contract:
(a) cease to be rights and obligations of the Commonwealth or the Commonwealth subsidiary at a specified time; and
(b) become rights and obligations of a specified person at that time.

(3) The Minister for Finance and Administration may, by writing, declare that a specified contract continues to have effect after a specified time as if a reference in the contract to the Commonwealth, or to the Commonwealth subsidiary, were a reference to a specified person.
(4) The Minister for Finance and Administration may, by writing, declare that:

(a) a specified instrument relating to a specified contract continues to have effect, after the Commonwealth's rights and obligations under the contract become rights and obligations of a specified person; or

(b) a specified instrument relating to a specified contract continues to have effect, after the rights and obligations of the Commonwealth subsidiary under the contract become rights and obligations of a specified person;
as if a reference in the instrument to the Commonwealth, or to the Commonwealth subsidiary, were a reference to the person.
(5) The Minister for Finance and Administration may, by writing, declare that:
(a) a specified person becomes the Commonwealth's successor in law, in relation to the Commonwealth's rights and obligations under a specified contract; or
(b) a specified person becomes the Commonwealth subsidiary's successor in law, in relation to the rights and obligations of the Commonwealth subsidiary under a specified contract;
immediately after the Commonwealth's rights and obligations, or the rights and obligations of the Commonwealth subsidiary, under the contract become rights and obligations of the person.
(6) A declaration under this section has effect accordingly.
(7) A copy of a declaration under this section is to be published in the Gazette within 21 days after the making of the declaration.
(8) This section does not, by implication, limit section 5G.
Note: A contract or instrument may be specified by name, by inclusion in a specified class or in any other way.
(1) This section applies to a liability that became a liability of the Commonwealth, or of a Commonwealth subsidiary, under section 5E.
(2) The Minister for Finance and Administration may, by writing, make any or all of the following declarations:

(a) a declaration that a specified liability ceases to be a liability of the Commonwealth, or of the Commonwealth subsidiary in question, and becomes a liability of a specified person at a specified time;

(b) a declaration that a specified instrument relating to a specified liability continues to have effect after the liability becomes a liability of a specified person as if a reference in the instrument to the Commonwealth, or to the Commonwealth subsidiary, were a reference to the person;

(c) a declaration that a specified person becomes the Commonwealth's, or the Commonwealth subsidiary's, successor in law in relation to a specified liability immediately after the liability becomes a liability of the person.
Note: A liability or instrument may be specified by name, by inclusion in a specified class or in any other way.
(3) A declaration under subsection (2) has effect accordingly.
(4) A copy of a declaration under subsection (2) is to be published in the Gazette within 21 days after the making of the declaration.
(1) A declaration may be made under this Division, whether or not the declaration is associated with the giving of consideration.
(2) This section is enacted for the avoidance of doubt.

para.inline: Division 4â€”Proceeds of asset transfers to be paid to the Commonwealth
5L Proceeds of asset transfers to be paid to the Commonwealth

speech.para: (1) The Minister for Finance and Administration may, by written notice given to an ANL body, direct that, if the body receives any consideration in respect of:
(a) the sale or transfer by the body of a specified asset in accordance with a direction under section 68A of the ANL Act 1956 ; or
(b) the transfer of a specified asset of the body under section 5C; or
(c) the transfer, under section 5D, of the body's rights and obligations under a specified contract;
the body must pay to the Commonwealth an amount equal to the consideration.
Note: An asset or contract may be specified by name, by inclusion in a specified class or in any other way.
(2) The body must comply with the direction.

para.inline: 5M Transfer of staff from a sale scheme body

speech.para: (1) This section applies to an employee of a sale scheme body.
(2) The Minister for Finance and Administration may, by written instrument, declare that a specified employee:
(a) ceases to be employed by a sale scheme body at a specified time (the employee's transfer time ); and

(b) is taken to have been engaged by a specified body corporate, to which shares in or assets of the sale scheme body have been (or are to be) transferred, as an employee of the body corporate at the employee's transfer time.
(3) A declaration under this section has effect accordingly.
(4) A time specified under subsection (2) must be a time that occurs:
(a) at or before the time that the transfer referred to in paragraph (2)(b) takes place; or
(b) within 12 months after the transfer takes place.
(5) A copy of a declaration under subsection (2) is to be published in the Gazette within 21 days after the making of the declaration.

(1) A person who is a transferred employee is taken to have been engaged by the specified body corporate in question on the terms and conditions that applied to the person, immediately before the emplo yee's transfer time, as an employee of the sale scheme body in question.
(2) A reference in subsection (1) to terms and conditions is a reference to terms and conditions that are set out in:
(a) a written contract of employment; or
(b) an award (as defined by section 4 of the Workplace Relations Act 1996 ); or
(c) a certified agreement (as defined by section 4 of the Workplace Relations Act 1996 ); or
(d) an Australian Workplace Agreement (as defined by section 4 of the Workplace Relations Act 1996 ); or

(e) a certified agreement (as defined by section 4 of the Industrial Relations Act 1988 as in force immediately before the commencement of Schedule 8 to the Workplace Relations and Other Legislation Amendment Act 1996 ) that continues to have effect because of Part 2 of that Schedule.

A person who is a transferred employee is taken to have accrued an entitlement to benefits, in connection with the employee's engagement by the specified body corporate in question, that is equivalent to the entitlement that the person had accrued, as an employee of the sale scheme body in question, immediately before the employee's transfer time.

para.inline: 5Q Continuity of service of transferred employees

speech.para: The service of a transferred employee as an employee of the specified body corporate in question is taken, for all purposes, to have been continuous with the service of the employee, immediately before the employee's transfer time, as an employee of the sale scheme body in question.
A transferred employee is not entitled to receive any payment or other benefit merely because he or she stopped being an employee of the sale scheme body in question as a result of this Division.

para.inline: 5S Variation of terms and conditionsâ€”transferred employees

speech.para: (1) This Division does not prevent the terms and conditions of a transferred employee's employment after the employee's transfer time from being varied:
(a) in accordance with those terms and conditions; or
(b) by or under a law, award, determination or agreement.
(2) In this section:
vary , in relation to terms and conditions, includes:
(a) omitting any of those terms and conditions; or
(b) adding to those terms and conditions; or
(c) substituting new terms or conditions for any of those terms and conditions.

designated matter means:

(c) the receipt of money by an ANL body, or by a person acting on behalf of an ANL body, in respect of a sale or transfer covered by paragraph (a); or

(a) a designated matter; or

para.inline: Division 7â€”Sale scheme body to assist the Commonwealth and ANL

speech.para: Without otherwise limiting the meaning of the expression, a reference in this Division to the implementation of this Part includes a reference to:
(a) the sale or transfer by the Commonwealth of an asset that has vested in the Commonwealth under section 5C; and
(b) the sale or transfer by a Commonwealth subsidiary of an asset that has vested in it under section 5C; and
(c) the sale or transfer by the Commonwealth of rights and obligations that have become rights and obligations of the Commonwealth under section 5D; and
(d) the sale or transfer by a Commonwealth subsidiary of rights and obligations that have become its rights and obligations under section 5D; and
(e) the transfer by the Commonwealth of liabilities that have become liabilities of the Commonwealth under section 5E; and
(f) the transfer by a Commonwealth subsidiary of liabilities that have become its liabilities under section 5E; and
(g) the sale or transfer of shares or assets of an ANL body; and
(h) the formulation of the policies and approaches to be adopted by the Minister for Finance and Administration in connection with:
(i) the implementation of this Part; and
(ii) any sale or transfer of a kind referred to in paragraph (a), (b), (c), (d), (e), (f) or (g).

para.inline: 5V Assistance given by a sale scheme body or director in connection with the implementation of this Part

speech.para: (1) A sale scheme body may, on the body's own initiative, assist the Commonwealth or ANL in connection with the implementation of this Part.
(2) A director of a sale scheme body may, on the director's own initiative, assist the Commonwealth or ANL in connection with the implementation of this Part.

(3) A sale scheme body must, when requested in writing by the Minister for Finance and Administration to do so, assist the Commonwealth or ANL in connection with the implementation of this Part. The assistance is to be given within the period, and in the form and manner, specified in the request.

(4) A director of a sale scheme body must, when requested in writing by the Minister for Finance and Administration to do so, assist the Commonwealth or ANL in connection with the implementation of this Part. The assistance is to be given within the period, and in the form and manner, specified in the request.

(5) The Minister for Finance and Administration may, by written notice given to a sale scheme body, give directions to the body about the exercise of the body's powers under subsection (1). The body must comply with the direction.

(6) The Minister may, by written notice given to a director of a sale scheme body, give directions to the director about the exercise of the director's powers under subsection (2). The director must comply with the direction.

(7) To avoid doubt, the giving of assistance as mentioned in subsection (1), (2), (3) or (4), the making of a request under subsection (3) or (4), or the giving of or compliance with a direction under subsection (5) or (6), does not result in a contravention of, or give rise to a liability or remedy under:
(a) a provision of the Corporations Law or any other law of the Commonwealth, a State or a Territory; or
(b) a rule of common law or equity (other than a rule of administrative law).
Note: The expression sale scheme body includes ANL (see section 5A).
(1) The assistance mentioned in subsection 5V(1), (2), (3) or (4) may take the form of:
(a) the giving of information; or
(b) the giving of financial assistance (within the meaning of section 205 of the Corporations Law); or
(c) the giving of a financial benefit to a related party (within the meaning of Part 3.2A of the Corporations Law); or
(d) the provision, by the directors or employees of a sale scheme body, of facilities, information and other assistance in connection with the conduct of:
(i) a due diligence procedure or a similar process; or
(ii) a market briefing or a similar process; or

(2) For the purposes of paragraph (1)(b), if section 205 of the Corporations Law is repealed and replaced by another provision of the Corporations Law that deals with the giving of financial assistance by companies, the reference in that paragraph to section 205 is to be read as a reference to the replacement provision.

(3) For the purposes of paragraph (1)(c), if Part 3.2A of the Corporations Law is repealed and replaced by another provision of the Corporations Law that deals with the giving of financial benefits to related parties, the reference in that paragraph to Part 3.2A is to be read as a reference to the replacement provision.
(4) Subsection (1) does not, by implication, limit the forms in which assistance may be given.

para.inline: 5X Use of information by the Commonwealth or an ANL body

speech.para: (1) This section applies to information obtained under section 5V.
(2) The Commonwealth, an ANL body or an associated person, may use the information for a purpose in connection with the implementation of this Part.
(3) The Commonwealth, an ANL body or an associated person, may disclose the information for a purpose in connection with the implementation of this Part.
(4) The Commonwealth, an ANL body or an associated person, may use or disclose the information for a purpose in connection with:
(a) the Commonwealth's capacity as a shareholder in a sale scheme body; or
(b) the ANL body's capacity as a shareholder in a sale scheme body;
so long as the use or disclosure does not involve giving the information to a person who is not an associated person.
(5) To avoid doubt, the use or disclosure of information as mentioned in subsection (2), (3) or (4) does not result in a contravention of, or give rise to a liability or remedy under:
(a) a provision of the Corporations Law or any other law of the Commonwealth, a State or a Territory; or
(b) a rule of common law or equity (other than a rule of administrative law).

(e) a director of an ANL body; or
(f) an officer or employee of an ANL body; or
(g) a person who performs services for or on behalf of an ANL body in connection with:
(i) the implementation of this Part; or
(ii) the ANL body's capacity as a shareholder in a sale scheme body.

Mr Deputy Speaker, I am pleased to introduce these government amendments to the ANL Sale Bill 1997 . As I indicated at the second reading stage, the sale of ANL is now under way. The government's preference is to sell Australian National Line as a whole and as an ongoing business. Our intention is to complete the sale of ANL by mid-1998. Advertisements seeking registrations of interest have been placed in the national and international press, as I have already stated, and we will continue with that process.

Honourable members will recall that when my colleague the Minister for Workplace Relations and Small Business (Mr Reith) introduced this bill, he foreshadowed the need for government amendments. The amendments that I am introducing today provide additional flexibility for the sale of Australian National Line. Generally, they are similar to provisions contained in other sale legislation, such as the AIDC Sale Act.

The amendments will provide for: powers to vest specified ANL assets, contractual rights and obligations and liabilities in specified persons; the transfer by the Commonwealth or Commonwealth subsidiaries of assets, contractual rights and obligations and liabilities that have been vested in the Commonwealth to specified persons; the provision of ANL assistance to the Commonwealth; use and disclosure of information by ANL or the Commonwealth; the power of direction to ANL; the removal of the availability to a buyer of ANL tax losses and other benefits; and provisions relating to the transfer of ANL staff to another employer body, protecting the terms of employment through the transfer.

The power to vest assets allows the minister or a delegate to have assets, contractual rights and obligations and liabilities of ANL transferred to a specified person. The creation of this power, which has been similarly used in other Commonwealth asset sales, such as AIDC, reserves the government's position on the final sales structure until all offers from potential buyers are considered. (Quorum formed) It will also facilitate the mechanics of completing the sale once the best outcome is determined, taking into account general sale objectives such as: optimisation of return to the Commonwealth; removal of Commonwealth exposure and liabilities; and the equitable treatment of staff up to the sale.

The ANL board and management have been providing every assistance to the sale, and I am very grateful for that. Legislative provisions will legally support that assistance and will place ANL in the same position on this issue as other recently privatised Commonwealth entities. Provisions relating to the use and disclosure of information and the power of direction are much the same as provisions in other Commonwealth sale legislation. These provide additional flexibility to the sale process.

The issue of ANL tax was addressed in the original bill. The amendments proposed strengthen and clarify these provisions. The goal is to ensure that the buyers of ANL will not have the benefit of ANL's favourable tax status. (Extension of time granted) Staff entitlement provisions similar to those used in other pieces of comparable legislation such as the airports sale and the Health Insurance Commission legislation are now also being proposed and should provide greater certainty for staff. I commend the amendments to the House and table a supplementary explanatory memorandum.
Amendments agreed to.
Bill, as amended, agreed to.

That the bill be now read a second time.

talk.start.para: â€”I move:

speech.para: That all words after "That" be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:
"whilst not declining to give the Bill a second reading, the House condemns the Government for:
(1) its cuts to child care ($820 million over two budgets, leading to increased fees and reduced Childcare Assistance, lower quality care, and closure of services);
(2) the chaos it has brought on the industry (particularly outside school hours care) by its mismanagement of the payments arrangements, despite many warnings from the industry;

(3) in particular, the uncertainty it has caused the industry, first by changing its mind on the payment arrangements, and then by bringing forward an interim measure, so that the only certainty is that the system will change again within 30 months".

Last night a woman asked me why the Howard government has made such drastic cuts to child care. She asked whether it was about budget cuts or whether it was the case that this Prime Minister (Mr Howard) wants women out of the work force. As I said to her last night, and I will say it to the House today, I think it is a combination of both. This government has cut $820 million over two budgets from child care and $500 million from nursing homes because it believes that families should look after themselves.

When I asked the Prime Minister a number of times last year where an elderly person would get the money to go into a nursing home, he said that their families could pay. This is the government's view, of course, about young people and children as well. If you have a young adult, 18 to 20 years of age, living at home and unemployed and your family income is $35,000 a year, as a result of this government's cuts your family will now be $55 a week worse off. If you also have a child needing child care, as a result of this government's budget cuts you could also be paying up to $20 a week more for your child in child care. This is a mean-spirited government that is removing the critical supports that families need when they are caring for children, supporting young adults or caring for their elderly relatives.

But when it comes to child-care cuts, there is no doubt at all in the minds of Australian women that this government has a different, additional objective: this Howard government wants them out of the work force. As one young mother in my electorate said to me last year, `There is just no incentive to continue two full-time jobs when it appears that we are penalised for doing the right thing, which is supporting ourselves and our children. Or is this the hidden agenda,' she said, `to get women out of the work force?'

It is no wonder that they wonder about this. It is no wonder that Australian women are facing very difficult choices as a result of major cuts to child care that this government has implemented. These cuts included: abolition of the additional income allowed for additional dependent children when assessing eligibility for child-care assistance; reduction of child-care assistance cut-offs for second and subsequent children; extending the range of fringe benefits for child-care assistance income testing; capping access to child-care assistance at 50 hours a week; freezing child-care assistance and child-care cash rebate fee ceilings for two yearsâ€”that means no indexation either last year or this year; reducing the child-care cash rebate; and removing operational subsidies worth $100 million over four years from community based child-care centres.

In a speech I made about six months ago I related that, at a meeting in Melbourne of 40 private child-care providers three weeks after the introduction of the 50-hour cap, almost all reported a reduction in usage, and those in lower income areas reported a drop of up to 25 per cent in full-time places. The evidence of community based long day care centres closing or losing considerable numbers of children because of fee rises is now rolling in.

Now, of course, we have a much clearer picture of what this government's policies mean for families who need child care. Last week the Queensland Child Care Coalition released a survey revealing that 3,255 children have been removed from 244 services in Queensland alone in the past year. More than 3,000 children have been taken out of child care in Queensland alone as a result of this government's budget cuts. This research reveals that families are now having to improvise with their care arrangements. Parents are having to reduce their hours of work, leave work altogether, or rely on their neighbours or backyard care for their child care.

This government do not seem to understandâ€”but Australian women certainly doâ€”that child care is a necessity; it is not a luxury. In the majority of families, especially those on lower incomes, women need to work to hold their family budgets together. If they do not have reasonably priced child care, they face the impossible choice: give up work or use substandard or unreliable child-care options.

What we see happening out there in the workplace is that women are now becoming what is called `discouraged workers'. There was a major article in the press this week that showed that more than two-thirds of those not looking for work anymore are women. More than 200,000 people have been discouraged from seeking jobs because they could not find or afford child care. What an indictment of this government's attitude to supporting families and particularly to supporting the choices women want to make about their lives. This is the reality of this government's attack on child care: 200,000 people discouraged from seeking work because they could not find or afford child care.

Now the cuts are impacting with their full severity. At the same time, surprisingly enough, the government have the election looming. That is why we are here today: the government have to bring this issue back into the House, because they know that if they push ahead with their plan to pay child-care assistance direct to parents there will be chaos out there in the child-care sectorâ€”in child-care centres, in family day care around the country. One thing this government do not want to doâ€”on top of all the discouragement to work, on top of all the increases in child-care feesâ€”is have additional chaos created in the child-care sector.

It is the same tactic that we have seen from this government as far as aged care is concerned. We had the deferral of the extra daily fee four times. No doubt, this will just be another deferral. No doubt, once the election is out of the way, if the unfortunate happens and this government are returned, parents will be saying, `What are they going to do next? What are they going to do next to my child care? How much more expensive will they make it? And what greater chaos will they bring on the child-care sector?' This is the way the government have gone about implementing their policies in relation to families. They have created uncertainty and confusion. At times, particularly as I will go on to demonstrate, in the out of school hours care sector, it has bordered on total chaos.

There is no excuse for this mess. It is the result of a government that do not consult and obviously do not do their homework. The government must not like to hear the facts from parents, child-care providers and child-care workers before they make their policies, because we would not be debating this bill in the House of Representatives today if the government had consulted the child-care sector and consulted parents before they went ahead with these changes.

These changes, as I said, are now going to extend to out of school hours care. As a result of last year's budget changes, we have had the extension of significant child-care cuts to out of school hours care. This government have taken operational subsidies away from out of school hours care. A representative from the National Out-of-School Hours Care Association said last year:
The reality is that there are some services that may close because they will no longer have a cash flow and that is of great concern.

The government's attack on out of school hours care shows that they have no understanding of how the services actually work, of how fragile they are and of how dependent they are on community goodwill, particularly the goodwill of parents.

These centres operate with part-time, casual and volunteer staff. In many cases they do not have permanent premises or storage space. They operate out of schoolsâ€”in my own younger child's school, it operates from a portable out in the yardâ€”out of scout halls and out of community facilities. The administrative work is often done by parents, who are the busiest people in our community. They cater to a shifting population of children. This is a critical issue that the government should have considered before they took the operational subsidies from out of school hours care. For example, a service might have 250 children on their books for 60 places. They need operational subsidies to help them run such complex and underresourced enterprises.

In my electorate we recently carried out a survey of out of school hours care services. We sent it to all the schools in the electorate where out of school hours care services operate. I think the comments that have come back from parents about the changes the government is putting in place are very revealing. They are very revealing because they show a couple of very fundamental facts about Australian society today which this government does not seem to understand because its whole approach is so stuck in the past: that is, that out of school hours care is now an essential resource for Australian families. Why is that? It is because both parents in the vast majority of families, particularly low income families, have to workâ€”that is the reality. They have to work, and that means they have to have access to decent, affordable child care, including out of school hours care. It is a reality that, unfortunately for the parents of Australia, does not seem to have registered with this government.

An increasing problem has been created as a result of this government's workplace relations legislation; a problem which has made life so much more difficult, particularly for part-time workers in industries where their jobs are vulnerable. Families in those situations have to conform to the demands of their employers or risk losing their jobs. They cannot just change their working hours to suit the needs of the out of school hours service or any other child-care service. As I said, we will look at some of the comments that have been made by these parents and at what the women are saying in particular. One woman said:
If the after school program is cancelled a lot of working mothers will have to give up work.
They understand the reality that they are confronting. Another woman stated:
I feel that the changes
are having a very negative impact on women's ability to participate in Australian life, which ends up costing the community much more than the child care subsidy!
Another parent says:
. . . I am very alarmed at the present Govt intentions towards working mothers with the funding arrangements for 1998 being onerous and punitive.
These are the views of Australian parents, particularly Australian women, about the changes proposed for out of school hours care. This is the view of a sole parent:
If OOSH Programs were not available I would be unable to work as I would have to provide the care necessary for my 7 year old child, and
as Social Security prefer us to work even part-time I am unsure how I would cope.
Another single parent stated:
I would be unable to work part-time in the City & would have to rely on my Sole-parent pension.

Surely it is not the intention of this government to send sole parents home to rely on their sole parent pensions, rather than their making the effort, as so many of them do, to hold down part-time jobs? The only way that they can hold down these part-time jobs is if there is decent and affordable out of school hours care.

There are also significant problems emerging for the services themselves, and this came through too in the responses from parents. As I said, the parents know that it is the parents themselves who are running these services. There are part-time people employed to care for the children for the hours before and after school, but those who do the admin istrative work, those who actually manage the services, are in fact parents. As one parent said:

Am very concerned at implications of the loss of operational subsidy for small programs . . . Parent committees are expected to become marketing experts & run the program as a `business' rather than be concerned about the quality of facilities for their children. If we can't make the grade, i.e. run it as an efficient `business' we should consider "outsourcing" . . .
That is, outsourcing the children to a different place. Of course, what it means for the parents is, as she said, that they will:
. . . lose control over staffing and activities provided for our children!
They are the realities. This is what will happen with this government's changes. These are comments by a parent about another school:

As someone actively involved in the running of our school program, I have had some first hand experience of what the changes to funding for OOSH, from operational subsidies to childcare assistance, might mean to our program. The prospect, is quite, frankly, an administrative nightmare.
That is what parents think about the changes that this government is imposing; it is imposing an administrative nightmare on Australian parents.

What do the changes mean for the children? We have talked about the particular impact on women, the impact on sole parents and the impact on the services themselves. What about the children? This is what the parents think will happen to the children. A parent stated:
. . . child would have to walk home to an empty houseâ€”something I would not be happy about.
That is what will happen if parents cannot afford out of school hours care. Another parent stated:

I feel very strongly that to remove funding to these services is to endanger children as they will be `home alone' or on school premises unsupervised. We have demonstrated a need for this service and John Howard's miserable agenda
to return women to domestic roles by forcing them out of the workforce through inadequate childcare arrangements . . .
That will be the result. Another parent said:
I think this would just increase the likelihood of children going home to an empty house.

These are responses that have come from so many parents. So many parents around the country are saying to us that these things will be the result of this government's changes to out of school hours care.
The next point is about job demands. As another parent said:
Try to change my working hours to fit into school hoursâ€”almost impossible really!
Another said:
I would have to changeâ€”find other employment to suit school hours.
Another said:
I would probably not be able to study . . .

These are the implications of the changes. So many parents have indicated to us that these problems will result from this government's removal of the operational subsidy from out of school hours care.

As I said, this is the reality that so many parents are facing. So many parents know they have to work to keep their family budgets together and, because of the cuts to after school hours care, because of the changes to the funding arrangements, because of the massive changes that this government has implemented to long day care and to child-care assistance more broadly, families in this country are facing an impossible choice: they must give up work, reduce their hours or seek what is going to be a much lesser standard of child care for their children.

The final issue I want to talk about today is the extraordinary disruption that this government has created for child-care centres around this country by continuously changing its mind about payment arrangements. That, in fact, is why we are here today. That is why this government is going to be reminded again and again by Labor members, all day today, about the damage that it has caused Australian families, both through the cuts to child care and through its incompetence in payment arrangements.

Let us go through the saga that this government has imposed on child-care providers and on Australian families over the last two years. In the 1996 budget, the government an nounced that child-care assistance would be paid, as it says in the budget papers, `from a shopfront agency', which we now know to be Centrelink, and that it would be paid from Centrelink to parents. That was supposed to happen in January this year. So child-care assistance would no longer be paid to child-care providers; it would be paid directly to parents. That is what it said in the budget in 1996. Last year, when we were debating another child-care bill, the government agreed to delay this change until April this yearâ€”a bit over a month away. In January this year, though, the government announced that it would not go ahead at all. That is why we are here in this place today.

For reasons which I am sure are very plain to child-care providers around the country, the government realised the chaos that was going to be created by implementing this change. So now we have had to come back into the parliament and face the fact that this government said in the budget of 1996, `Child-care assistance will be paid by Centrelink to parents.' Then it said, `No, no, we cannot do it by then, so we will delay it until April.' Then in January we had, `No, no, it is not going to go ahead,' and the minister has had to bring the bill back into the House to actually change the legislation.

The impact of all this changeâ€”the impact of the government continuously not knowing what they are doingâ€”has of course created enormous confusion and wasted effort in child-care centres around the country, and also in family day care. Any competent government would have gone about things in a completely different way. They would actually have worked the details out with the child-care providers before announcing major administrative changes, but not this government. They did not work it out beforehand. They said, `No, no, we do not need to talk to anybody beforehand, we will just announce this change, and as the confusion and chaos becomes more apparent we will change our minds.'

This Howard government, of course, has a record of incompetence both in child care and in aged careâ€”and when we debate the Aged Care Amendment Bill later in the day we will be bringing to the attention of the Australian public the gross incompetence of this government when it comes to aged care. But, for now, let us keep focusing on what this incompetence has meant for child care. This bill does not in fact fix the chaos in out of school hours care. Out of school hours care services will now be paid child-care assistance, Centrelink will do the income assessments of families, but the out of school hours care services themselves will have to work out what each family has to pay each week, minus their child-care assistance. That is a task that child-care centresâ€”long day care centresâ€”can do. They have the resources to do it. They are used to doing it. They have the administrative structures and the administrative support to do that task. They have been doing it for a long time.

But, as I have said already in this debate, out of school hours care services are not like that. They are run on a shoestring by parent committees. These parents, by definition, are parents who will be going out to work all day and in their evening hours will have to work out how many children came to the out of school hours care centre, for how many hours each day and what their child-care assistance entitlements are. The number of children attending these services, of course, varies markedly from day to day. The number of hours the children attend varies markedly from day to day. This government is creating a nightmare for out of school hours care services and for the parents who rely so heavily upon them.

As the parents in my electorate have so clearly put it, they need child care because without it they cannot work. Without it they cannot go to work. The alternative they face when it comes to out of school hours care is for their children to go home to empty homes. I know, Madam Deputy Speaker, that you would not want that for your child and I certainly would not want it for mine.

These are the real pressures that the government are putting on Australian families. They are making all of us face impossible choicesâ€”give up work, reduce your hours. These are the real things that are happening. This is what parents are actually doing. Parents are changing their hours, getting their neighbours to look after their children or asking their grandparents to do more of the child care. Even worse, what we are now seeing, which we have not seen for more than 20 years in this country, is a return to backyard care. We have the fear of seeing the return of latchkey children.

These are not things that should go past lightly in any debate in this House because it exposes our children, our young people, to such significant risk. It is a priority that any government should have as its most importantâ€”that children are supported and cared for in the best environment. This government's budget cuts mean that that is no longer the case. Parents can no longer afford decent child care. They also now face, as a result of this government's incompetence, enormous confusion and chaos in the services on which they rely so heavily. The government will be condemned by parentsâ€”I have no doubt whatsoever about thatâ€”at the next election. I strongly commend the amendment to the House.

talk.start.para: â€”Is the amendment seconded?
â€”I second the amendment and reserve my right to speak.

â€”You wonder at times where our country is going to end up. In one sense the things that have been said by the member for Jagajaga (Ms Macklin)â€”whilst they might have noble intention, apart from the misleading statements that are contained in her addressâ€”are simply unsustainable. We are living in a country that is growing at around 3Â½ per cent.
â€”It should be 4Â½ per cent.

â€”We have got the Asian currency and equity problem breathing down our necks. We do not know to what extent the growth in our economy will be affected by the Asian and equity currency meltdown. The Bureau of Economic Intelligence in London suggests it might be as high as one per cent. (Quorum formed) As I was saying, you wonder where our country is going to end up in the sense that we are growing at around 3Â½ per cent per annum and, as the member for Corio (Mr O'Connor) correctly said, we should be growing at around 4Â½ per cent.

speech.para: Members of the House and members of the public ought to remember that, because of our appalling savings record in Australia and the fact that the previous government left us with a government debt approaching 19 per cent of GDP, every time we went near four per cent growth the Reserve Bank had to increase interest rates to slow growth because people had to borrow money offshore.

The member for Jagajaga and those on the other side who continually oppose everything that we do forget how wealth is createdâ€”money that is spent on child care and on aged care. We cannot as a nation continue to finance essential social infrastructureâ€”health, education, pensionsâ€”on debt and asset sales. You cannot snuggle into bed at night on the one hand denying industrial relations, taxation and regulatory reform and then on the other hand saying, `Yes, but we must provide full, comprehensive and free child care and aged care to every Australian, irrespective of their circumstances.'

I have heard the member for Jagajaga oppose government attempts to make it easier for employers to employ Australians and young people in particular. I have heard her try to frustrate attempts to allow small business people to employ more Australians. I have heard her deny that Australia's taxation system is in need of some kind of reform. Unless we simplify the tax system and broaden the base, it will be increasingly difficult to create more wealth, and certainly any responsible government will not be able to finance essential social infrastructure unless it is borrowing more money.

I have heard the opposition oppose, of all things, a charter of budget honesty to actually require governments and oppositions to present their economic policies to the community. I have also heard them, in a climate of collapsing age dependency ratios, rail against any kind of user contribution towards residential aged care, of higher education reforms and of reforms to finding jobs for those who are unemployed. They also sought to oppose the attempts by government to see that we had differentiated targets in relation to greenhouse gas emissions. Had we succumbed to the views of the Australian Labor Party, then many Australians in regional working-class areas of this country would not have had jobs, nor would their children.

So it is in that climate that we then come to discuss reforms in child care. What was not said by the member for Jagajaga and others on the other side was in many senses the truth, the things that need to be heard. I would like to quote from a press release of 22 February this year from the President of the Australian Confederation of Child Care. This organisation represents over 1,000 child-care centres. It states:

We want to completely refute recent comments about Child Care which appear to be politically motivated, which suggest there have been substantial fee increases. This politically motivated campaign only serves to do long term damage to the Child Care Industry as a whole. This campaign is trying to blame the current Federal Government for reductions in attendance at Child Care Centres. Nothing could be further from the truth.

The current Federal Minister, Warwick Smith, has in a short space of time, shown more understanding and leadership in Child Care than any previous Minister in recent times. This Government has, for the first time, put in place a planning system for Child Care, it has removed inequitable funding practices such as operational subsidies, it has introduced a hotline for information about Child Care and it has recently announced a retention of the current system of allocation of Child Care assistance to families which will avoid complex and intrusive procedures for families. Without a doubt, children and families are the big winners under The Howard Government's Child Care Policies.

The House needs to be reminded that the form of support that is given by government to child care comes in a number of ways. The first is child-care assistance, which was formerly fee relief. This is a means tested payment allowing fees to be reduced for parents to have children cared for in long day care, family day care, occasional care and some preschools. This payment, which had been paid to providers, constitutes over half of the Commonwealth's commitments in this area. The second is the child-care cash rebate, which was introduced in 1994 and was non-means-tested. By 1996-97 it was $120 million a year of Commonwealth expenditure. In the 1996-97 year we saw the maintenance of a 30 per cent benefit for families earning less than $70,000 a year with one child, but those earning above $70,000 now receive a 20 per cent benefit.

To again put into context what the member for Jagajaga was saying, prior to the election I had a constituent whose husband is a quite prominent surgeon in a subspecialty ring me and say, `I am thinking about how I am going to vote.' She said, `If you means test in any way the child-care cash rebate, I cannot vote for you.' I thought what an extraordinary situation where you have someone who I know has a household income in excess of half a million dollars a year actually thinking about changing a vote on the basis of whether or not they will receive a non-means-tested child-care cash rebate. You have to ask yourselves, `Have we lost the plot or haven't we?' The whole point is any government needs to ensure that those who are most in need are the people who receive most of the benefits that government provides. What we have done as a nation over the last 20 years is taxed low income and low middle income families to death in order to return subsidies to them in all kinds of ways.

What was not said, for example, about the out of hours school care is that, whilst the government is redirecting operational subsidies from the providers of those services, it is actually putting those subsidies directly into the hands of parents and families who are the consumers of those services. But, more importantly, the government is making sure that most of that money goes to low income and low middle income families. I forget the figure, but I think it goes to families earning up to $67,000 a year.

I am going to have some of my constituents in a relatively affluent part of Australia criticise me for that. They will ask me to come down here and rail against thisâ€”perhaps the lady with a household family income of half a million dollars a year who rang me before the election will. I have to say to my constituents in relation to this issue, as I have said in relation to the closure of a Medicare office in my electorate, `Just remember that the national interest cannot be easily divorced from the interests of my electorate.'

I am privileged to represent the electorate of Bradfield, but I also have a responsibility to the nation, which is something that members of the Labor oppositionâ€”the member for Jagajaga in particularâ€”forget. Because people like me are prepared to support sensible reforms in child care and aged careâ€”to name just two areasâ€”we can actually ensure that more resources go to families who are battling in electorates that are represented by members who in some cases actually come from the Labor side of politics. That ought to be remembered.

The next thing is that we provide capital grants. We also provide operational subsidies. In excess of $150 million a year was paid out in operational subsidies in 1996-97 to community based long day care. Of course these ceased in July 1998 with the exception of occasional care, family day care, multifunctional and multifunctional Aboriginal children services.

Despite subsidising community based long day care, I think it was only something like $4 a week cheaper than privately provided care. In fact, a higher portion of concessional families have been using private care. Again, the member for Jagajaga said something ridiculous like, `The government has a responsibility to provide an operational subsidy to people who are providing complex services.' Does that mean that in some way the government should be providing direct operational subsidies to people providing private facilitiesâ€”people who have to meet all of the costs that any business person ought to meet? That is simply not a sustainable argument.

The government has provided substantial resources to long day care centres to help them adjust to working in a privately operated environment. It ought to be remembered in that context that it was the beneficence of the McMahon Liberal government that in the first place actually established community based care to support low income families and single parent families. The criticisms of our side of politics in this regard are a little misguided, to say the least.

There are a number of other points I particularly wanted to make about child care, but I have a couple that are perhaps of a more ethereal nature. There is one thing the member for Jagajaga said that I think is true, and that is the extent to which we nurture the idealism of our children and protect their vulnerable transition to adulthood are critical measures of a caring society. She did not put it in those terms, but I think that is what she meant. It might be said that a society that fails to cherish its children will fail. As I have pointed out, over the last decade we have seen a veritable explosion in the demand for and the use of formal child care. The child-care sectorâ€”I prefer not to describe it as an industryâ€”has become for 600,000 Australian children a critical part of their nurturing and development. The Commonwealth government is this year going to provide in excess of $1.2 billion in recognition and support of that fact.

In thinking about our future, child care is going to be critical and any emerging sense of national identity is going to depend on our capacity to rebuild a sense of community. Fundamental to the preservation of any sense of belonging and meaningful purpose is the resource of our personal relationshipsâ€”the recognition that, in a world of fundamentalist intolerance and vast ignorance of the impact of our actions on others, what we need most is one another. For 600,000 Australian children who spend much of their time in child care, whatever the views of those who think a family ought to be two parents, two kids and a golden retriever and one parent who stays at home to look after them, the fact is that child care has become a critical part of the development of children.

We need to ensure that child-care providersâ€”public, private, family day care, whatever you likeâ€”are seen to be a part of that mesh that is instilling values and nurturing in children. No matter how noble it may be to promote the ideal virtue of children being at home with one parent, that unfortunately is not the reality. Some may see it as evidence of a society that is failing.

When I visited a family day care centre in my electorate, one lady said to me, `We are very worried about these children because we should have a computer here and they should be able to play on the Internet when they are here.' I thought, `That's interesting, they are starting young.' I said to her, `Look, that's important, but what you are doing here is something far more important. You are connecting these children to one another. Just remember that you are blessed with a great responsibility and an opportunity to mould them and help them become the kind of children that perhaps care about one another more so than they do about communicating with a computer.' I realise that I have probably deviated from things a bit, but the member for Jagajaga did make me a bit hostile.

talk.start.para: â€”I rise to support the second reading amendment to the Child Care Legislation Amendment Bill 1998 moved by the member for Jagajaga (Ms Macklin). I think it is appropriate that I read that amendment so that the House is aware of what we are debating. The amendment states:

speech.para: "whilst not declining to give the Bill a second reading, the House condemns the Government for:
(1) its cuts to child care ($820 million over two budgets, leading to increased fees and reduced Childcare Assistance, lower quality care, and closure of services);
(2) the chaos it has brought on the industry (particularly outside school hours care) by its mismanagement of the payments arrangements, despite many warnings from the industry;

(3) in particular, the uncertainty it has caused the industry, first by changing its mind on the payment arrangements, and then by bringing forward an interim measure, so that the only certainty is that the system will change again within 30 months".

The second reading speech on this legislation by the Minister for Family Services (Mr Warwick Smith) reflects some public concern about the unfavourable impact that this government's child-care policy is having on young families. I believe the minister's opening remarks were:

Following the passage of the Child Care Payments Act 1997 last year, the government received numerous representations about the likely administrative impact on parents and on services which would flow from its full implementation in April 1998.

I bet they did. I have certainly received many deputations and phone callsâ€”and I am sure all members in this House haveâ€”from distraught parents telling me what hardships this legislation would cause to low income working families. This is no surprise when you realise that this government has cut $820 million from child care. These cuts are having a major impact on working families, particularly women. Women are being forced to reduce their hours of work or stop work altogether because they can no longer afford child care. In many cases, family members are being used as babysitters. This may be all right if the family member lives nearby, but in many cases it involves the parents travelling considerable distances to deliver their child to the family member's home. This creates additional stress on all concerned and adds to the time the parent is away from their home.

What is happening is that centres are closing and fees are increasing. To give some examplesâ€”these are real examples of some of the problems that have been brought to my attention by people in my electorateâ€”I had a visit from a single unemployed mother who was doing a course at a TAFE college to improve her employment skills. Her child-care bill has increased by over $36 since May. To clarify this figure, which comes in two parts: firstly, as a result of changes to the child-care assistance, the child-care fee for this parent went up from $28 per week to $43 per week, an increase of $15 per week; secondly, as a result of the removal of the operational subsidy, which took effect from 1 July, her fee per week for one child went up from $43 per week to $64 per week. This is an increase over that period of $36.40, which is quite outrageous. It is impossible for low income people, in the circumstances that we are describing, to keep their children in child care. This particular lady, unfortunately, was on a pension, so quite clearly the increase in costs would force her out of child care and may well have forced her out of doing her TAFE course.

In other cases, centres are operating with reduced standards and facilities. I had an approach from one community based child- care centre in my electorate seeking funding for the installation of some form of airconditioning to help overcome the severe heat problems we are experiencing this summer. The centre is unable to purchase this equipment out of its existing funds and it cannot increase fees. This request has been passed on to the department for its consideration. What this government does not understand is that many working class families rely on two incomes to exist and pay off their mortgages. The changes to child care have been so complex that many families are missing out on the benefits that they are entitled to. They have been introduced without adequate consultation with parents and operators.

I will give a few examples of the changes that parents and the child-care industry have had to contend with. Firstly, the government has removed operational subsidies from community based long day care and occasional care centres and put nothing in its place. This is $40 million a year gone from the child-care system. This decision means that fees will rise up to $25 per child per week. Secondly, the government has put a 50-hour a week cap on child-care assistance. Working parents can now get child-care assistance for 50 hours a week for each child, saving the government $30 million a year. It sounds reasonable, but it does not recognise the way child-care centres work in 11- and 12-hour days. For many families, it will restrict the child care they can afford to four days instead of five.

Thirdly, the government has abolished the additional income allowance for additional dependent children when assessing eligibility for child-care assistance. Cutting out the additional $30 a week income that families were allowed to include if they had more than one child when applying for child-care assistance is the harshest cut of all. It means a couple of dollars per week per child. It will save the government about $25 million a year at the expense of people who cannot spare it. It costs a family more to raise two or more children than it does to raise one. Fourthly, by freezing child-care assistance and the child-care cash rebate fees ceiling for two years, the real value of child-care assistance will go down.

The survey of the National Association of Community Based Child Care Centres, conducted in 1997, found that 73 per cent of families leaving existing care cited increased fees as the reason. This crisis in child care is Australia-wide. Last week, a coalition of child-care providers in Queensland released a survey showing that 3,255 children had been removed from 224 services in that state. Eighteen centres have closed in Western Australia in the past 10 months. In Tasmania, the home state of the Minister for Family Services, a number of services are under threat and could close by June. There is also a serious underutilisation in private and community owned day care centres around Australia due to parents being unable to afford the fees. The more children leaving child-care centres, the greater the cost for the centre, and the fees rise again. This is one way of reducing demand. As parents take their children out of child care because of increased costs, the government says that the demand is not there.
I would like to give some examples of the waste that has occurred as a result of the government's policy. I asked this question of the previous Minister for Family Services in September 1996:
Has the Government provided the sum of $8.3m to assist child care centres; if so, does the sum include funds to pay out the required legal obligations to staff forced to take redundancy packages?
The answer was:

Yes. $8.3m will be provided by the Government over 2 years ($6.3m 96/97, $2.0m 97/98) to assist services restructure their business to improve efficiency and minimise the flow-on to parents of the removal of operational subsidy from community based long day care centres.

Quite frankly, I believe this is a complete waste of money. That money could have been used to provide additional child-care places instead of providing an industry with additional finance. This view is also supported. I refer to an article in the Sydney Morning Herald of 26 July by Adele Horin, which was based on comments from the Network of Community Activities which represents before and after school and vacation care providers. It states:

The Federal Government's allocation of more than $12 million over two years for consultants to out-of-school care programs and for minor upgrading is a "scandalous" waste of money, the NSW peak body says.

Network of Community Activities, which represents 600 providers of before and after school and vacation care, has written to the Minister for Family Services, Ms Moylan, urging her to reconsider the decision on consultants.

In the latest budget, the government announced sweeping changes to its funding of services . . . Individual services will lose operational subsidies of between $24,000 and $41,000, but each will be eligible for a $3,000 government grant to pay a consultant.
The article also noted:
Network's coordinator, Ms Judy Finlayson, said it was scandalous that the money could not be used in a more cost-effective, collaborative way.

I think that is a clear example of where money has been misspent. With a bit better organisation and a bit more thought going into it, this money could have been used to directly assist the child-care industry and provide more child-care places.

I will just give another example of a child-care centre in my electorate of Greenway. I think this brings home quite clearly the point that the member for Jagajaga was making. As a result of the government's policy, there is quite an amount of disruption in the provision of child care. I asked the previous minister this question on 17 September:

Is it a fact that the Lalor Park Child Care Centre in the electoral division of Greenway (a) is located in an area of predominantly Housing Commission homes, (b) provides child care to (i) 93 families on the maximum subsidy of 83.4%, (ii) 26 families at varying levels of assistance and (iii) 10 full fee paying families and (c) will lose $75,000 operational subsidy.
The answer to that question was:
(a) It is understood that there are a number of Housing Commission homes in the area serviced by Lalor Park Child Care Centre.

(b)(i) According to the centre records provided to the Department for the April-June 1996 period, 20 families were on the maximum Childcare Assistance for two children in care and 34 families were on the maximum subsidy for one child in care.
(ii) 41 families were receiving partial Childcare Assistance.
(c) The centre will receive approximately $70,000 in Operational Subsidy in 1996-97. No Operational Subsidies will be paid from 1 July 1997.

The end of this story is that this child-care centre has now closed and the people who were using that service obviously had to go elsewhere. It closed at Christmas last year, but I am pleased to say that, as a result of the initiative of the Blacktown Council, which tendered to reopen this centre, it will now reopen. So that is some good news, and it was no doubt due to the efforts of the Blacktown Council. So I congratulate the Blacktown Council on what they have done to reopen this centre.

The point I am trying to make is the disruption that this government's policy has caused to these people, to these parents. What have they been able to do for the last two or three months? They have had nowhere to put their children and, more than likely, they may have had to give up their own employment. So this matter is quite serious and we do need some continuity in the government's policy. I will just make the point again of congratulating the Blacktown Council. They operate 20 child-care centres in their local government area and there are some 1,500 children in these centres. I congratulate the council.

We have been asked to restrict our speaking time and I assume there will be speakers to follow me. If not, I am quite happy to continue at this stage. I did want to draw attention to the real need in my electorate for child-care assistance. I have on previous occasions, and I will do it again, referred to the Quakers Hill Family Services, which operates from a complex providing family support, family counselling, multicultural programs and vocational care. This project is jointly sponsored by the Quakers Hill Uniting Church and Wesley Mission's Dalmar Child and Family Care.

Of the families currently utilising the premises, many are registered child-at-risk families and over 70 per cent are dealing with current or recent domestic violence issues. The area also has a high level of non-English speaking familiesâ€”25 per centâ€”many of whom are newly arrived migrants with minimal English skills. In seeking to provide a one-stop shop for these high need or vulnerable families, it is essential that this centre is granted child-care assistance in order to service these very needy families who have very limited finance and social resources.

Although the minister has left the chamber, I have written to him about this child-care centre and I would be very happy to get some assistance from the government on this. It is right in the centre of my electorate in the Quakers Hill area, where there is a lot of new residential development and a lot of young families. With the problems that arise from that, I would appreciate some assistance.

As I have indicated, we did agree to restrict our time. The government does stand condemned for all the cuts to child care. I am sure that, as other speakers on this side put their arguments, it will become clear towards the end of this debate that there is a lot of support for the amendment that has been moved by the member for Jagajaga.

talk.start.para: â€”Thank you, Madam Deputy Speaker Kelly, and how nice it is to see you in the chair today. In listening to the debate on the Child Care Legislation Amendment Bill 1998 , particularly the comments made from the other side, it has been interesting to note that we seem to get sidetracked so easily when talking about something like child care. The debate on child care in this place has largely been ideological and, inevitably, political philosophies have overridden the essential issues that we are talking about.

speech.para: In the context of child care, we hear a lot about what is best for parents, and parents of course deserve consideration on this issue. We also hear a lot about what is best for child-care centres, and it seems to me that this bill is largely focused on what is best for child-care centres. In other words, the tail is well and truly wagging the dog. The Minister for Family Services (Mr Warwick Smith) is at the table, and I am delighted to see him here so early in the morningâ€”

talk.start.para: â€”It's nearly lunchtime.

â€”It is, you are right. I want to let the minister know that I accept that because of the concerns in the industry there was a need forâ€”(Quorum formed) The member for Kalgoorlie (Mr Campbell), who called the quorum, must have had a bad night last night, or else he does not like children. I did not appreciate the interruption. As I was about to say, the key feature of the Child Care Legislation Amendment Bill 1998 is to defer some of the arrangements that parliament agreed to in the original bill that was debated some time agoâ€”the Child Care Payments Bill 1997.

speech.para: The opposition supported that bill at the time. The opposition has now realised that a few political points can be made at the expense of children and families and so, although it is not seeking ultimately to oppose the billâ€”and the amendment cutely says that the opposition is not actually opposing the billâ€”it is moving an amendment which seeks to criticise the government for cutting funding, as the member for Jagajaga (Ms Macklin) said.

Child care is vital. No-one in this place would disagree with that statement. What could be more important than the care we give to young Australians who are the future leaders, business people and parents of this country? As the care that children receive casts a lifelong shadow on them, whenever we have a debate on child care in this place the focus should be on what is best for children, and yet the debate always seems to focus on either what is best for parents or, in this particular case, what is best for child-care centres. The question that we ought to be asking is: what is best for children?

I accept that the changed arrangements in respect of the funding of child care were difficult to implement. I had meetings with child-care centre owners in my electorate and they explained some of the practical problems they have with the implementation of those changes. I believe that the government has acted quite properly in those circumstances by deferring the implementation of the changed funding arrangements.

talk.start.para: â€”They had to.

â€”I agree that they had to, for some very good reasons. To his credit, the present minister has taken a number of steps which obviously had to be taken, and that is what this bill is all about. I hope that the independent member for Moore (Mr Filing) will support the bill. I know that he is a family man and I am sure that he will support the bill when it is time to vote.
â€”He could be a Liberal if he was smart, too.

â€”Maybe! The industry has developed without regard to anybody giving fundamental consideration to the question of what is best for children. In the area I represent in south-east Queensland, the child-care industry has responded to the opportunity to make a profitable investment. I have no problem with the concept of profit and, indeed, I am a champion of free enterprise and profit, but the child-care industry has been driven largely by the system that was brought in by the previous Labor government. People have understandably responded to that. Why wouldn't they? That is what our system is all about. As a result, there has been haphazard growth of child-care centres, with no proper planning or control over the growth of the industry. What we now have is a product of Labor mismanagement in this area.

speech.para: The Labor Party, in its child-care philosophy, is ultimately driven by the ideology that it is committed to. As a result, child care has simply become, on occasions, I regret to say, a political football in this place. The debate has often been clouded by ideology. The feminist ideologyâ€”and I realise when I say this that I am being terribly politically incorrect; fortunately there are none of my female Labor colleagues in the parliament, although I notice the member for Bowman (Mrs West) is here, but she will be kind to meâ€”of making child care widely and freely available was all about freeing women from the shackles of motherhood. It is all about, in their estimation, we hear so often, helping women.

talk.start.para: â€”That's absolutely outrageous. Get out of the dark ages!

â€”But what about the many women in our community who do not want that sort of help? What about affirmative action in favour of mothers of young children to give them freedom of choice in the sort of child-care arrangements that they want to make? If we are to spend, as we do, over $1 billion a year caring for very young children, why not pay mothers to do it? I can never understand why that question has never seriously exercised the minds of people on the other side of the parliament. The fact is that a mother can be paid to look after somebody else's children but not paid to look after her own children. Isn't there something quaintly irresponsible about allowing that situation to continue?

speech.para: My bottom line in all of this debate is that ultimately we should be facilitating freedom of choice. In other words, in this particular area the government should adopt a neutral position. I believe the Howard government has moved towards that neutral position, which is ultimately about giving parents freedom of choice as to what sort of child care they want to haveâ€”not socially engineering the whole system, not skewing the whole system against that freedom of choice, as we put up with for years, but actually facilitating that freedom of choice. The Labor Partyâ€”driven as it is, as I said earlier, by that ideological bentâ€”is in favour of freedom of choice, but not freedom of choice if it is contrary to their ideology.

talk.start.para: â€”Exactly the same as you lot.

â€”I refute that. I take the interjection from the member for Kalgoorlieâ€”I do not think it is fair. We inherited a system which we are fixing and I believe we are genuinely committed to giving parents freedom of choice. It is not easy to wind back all of what has happened and arrive at that point, but I believe we have taken some obvious and very worthwhile steps towards doing that. So I refute the suggestion that we are acting the same way as the Labor Party did. In fact, we are trying to fix up the mess that the Labor Party made.
â€”Look at superannuation.

â€”Having said that, and taking the interjection from the opposition spokesman, the member for Corio, (Mr O'Connor), about some of the remarks I madeâ€”and I am used to hearing it from them whenever I say anything that is faintly pro-family or pro-childrenâ€”I am accused of being anti-women. That is what we have to put up with from the other side. If you are in favour of families in this place or you are in favour of getting kids the best deal, you are anti-women. There is no middle ground. You are either totally in the feminist bandwagon or you are utterly opposed to them.

speech.para: I believe in addressing the needs of mothers in this debate. My wifeâ€”and I will pay her credit anywhere, any timeâ€”has been a very good mother to our three children. For 12 years she stayed out of the work force and gave absolute priority to our children's needs, and she largely continues to do that. I applaud her. I put her on a pedestal. I think she has done more for our society in those 12 years than I have done in eight years in this place. She has done three times as much for our society in putting that time into our kids. Okay, people say, `You can afford to do it.' We can, and we have made that choice, but all the time the Labor Party attempted to take that choice away from us. They made it more and more difficult. If they were still running the show, they would continue to make it more and more difficult for families to make that choice.

So I say to the member for Jagajaga and her colleagues, `Get fair dinkum.' We talk about freedom of choice. Let us see the government take a relatively neutral position in this debate and give parents real freedom of choice. Then I think we would see some real solutions to the problems that we are experiencing in our society today. I believe in catering for the needs of mothers. Let us work for family-friendly workplaces. I accept the criticism that has been levelled in the past. (Quorum formed)

Madam Deputy Speaker, I am about to finish. I was making the point that I believe that consideration needs to be given to a mother's needs. I have made the point that children's needs are paramount, but let us look at the needs of mothers. Family-friendly workplaces are a great challenge. We have to encourage them. We have to realise the economic reality of life today is such that in many cases both the mother and the father have to go out to work. They do not do it by choice; it is because they have to, and, therefore, family-friendly workplaces I think are a priority for governments to look at.

The member for Kalgoorlie asked me about superannuation. This government has taken a step in the right direction. The government recognises that women, when they become mothers and stay out of the work force, are disadvantaged in the superannuation area, so they have taken steps to make superannuation available to mothers in that situation.

We also need to be aware of the social needs of mothers who make the choice to stay out of the work force and care for their children. Of course, these days many informal arrangements are in place to address those social needs. What about the idea of child-care centres opening their doors so home caring parents can access the facilities? There are all sorts of initiatives we have yet to grasp about how we can do what, in fairness, the opposition wantsâ€”that is, take account of the needs of women and mothers, but do so in an environment where we give priority in this debate to what is best for children.

And what is best for children? When you read the literature, I do not think there is any doubt that parent care is best for children.
