We have gone through years of trendy debate that somehow our society is moving away from parent care to state care or group care or whatever you want to call it, and I think we are now reaping the fruits of those years. Increasingly, I think it will be demonstratedâ€”and lots of the research coming through shows thisâ€”that parent care is what young kids need and what ultimately is best for them. We are starting to see the downside of a society that has moved away from that, so let us restore the concept of mothering, let us put that back on the agenda as something that is desirable and worthwhile, and as something that is to be applauded.

Mothers want to care for their children, Madam Deputy Speakerâ€”you know that. When they are asked, mothers say they want to be able to have as much time as possible with their children. I do not think that is surprising, and I think ultimately government policy ought to be facilitating that. The bottom line is to facilitate real choice for parents so that the best arrangements are put in place for the care of their young children.

talk.start.para: â€”Madam Deputy Speaker, I was interested to hear the address of the member for McPherson (Mr Bradford), particularly with the member for Bradfield (Dr Nelson) in the chamber because I am sure he agrees with every word. I can see he is almost speechless now. I suppose one of the advantages of being over here as an Independent is that you can actually represent the interests of your constituency, unfettered by party lines on particular issues.
â€”Oh, what a load of rubbish!

â€”Obviously, the member for McPherson is, because he is not happy supporting your legislation when it all boils down. He has been swamped by what he considers to be the trendies in his own party room. That is why I asked the member for Bradfieldâ€”
â€”That is what he said.

â€”That is what he said. I have no differences with the member for Bradfield because I think that may well be why he is on the back bench: he is a rebel without a cause. The member for McPherson often expresses views that are away from the majority view of the coalition parties. I am sure at times even you, Madam Deputy Speaker, in your capacity as a member of the National Party, would sympathise with the positions he takes. Often he takes views expressed by people who are considered to be the silent majority but, in the case of the electorate of the member for McPhersonâ€”given the demographic make-up of his electorateâ€”they probably do represent a large proportion of the people who elected him to this place, so he should be representing the views of his constituents. That is his purpose, and possibly one day he may have the opportunity to represent them as an Independent. Who knows.
â€”Fat lot of influence he would have then.
â€”I think we have a lot more influence than some of the coalition back bench members, as the member well knows, being the party whip.

speech.para: The Child Care Legislation Amendment Bill 1998 , according to the explanatory memorandum, follows the passage of the Child Care Payments Act 1997. The government received numerous representations about the likely administrative impact on parents and services which would flow from its full implementation in April 1998. As a result, the government decided to defer the implementation of the act until a child-care card or similar technology is available. This technology will allow the introduction of a system which is more efficient for all parties. So this bill seeks to implement this decision by deferring the implementation of the Child Care Payments Act 1997.

This bill also amends the Child Care Act 1972 and the Child Care Rebate Act 1993 to allow the implementation of the other decisions taken in the 1997 budget and reflected in the Child Care Payments Act 1997. These include a limit on child-care assistance of 20 hours a week for non-work related care; the introduction of a planning system for long day care places; a limit on the number of new places approved in 1998 and 1999; and the introduction of immunisation as a criterion for eligibility for child-care assistance and child-care rebate. The bill also facilitates the transfer of the payment of the current child-care assistance program to Centrelink in the interim period pending the commencement of the payments under the Child Care Payments Act 1997.

This all sounds well and good, but one also has to recollect that this reform of the child-care system comes from the same organisation which gave us the fiasco over the aged care changes. I hear a member opposite saying there is nothing wrong with those. The actual intent of the changes may be well founded, but the problem is in the implementation, in the practical application of the changes. Hugh Mackay's work Generationsâ€”which is an excellent book; I urge all members to read itâ€”points out that one of the fundamental problems or underlying themes in our community in the 1990s is the basic insecurity of many people in our community.

The two key points in a person's or a family's lifetime where insecurity is at its most serious point is at the point when people require aged care, either for themselves or for their relatives or loved ones, or at the point when families are raising young childrenâ€”or, for that matter, children of any age who are in their care. These are the two points of most stress in a family's lifetime experience. And here we are with a process that is contributing towards and exacerbating the feeling of insecurity in our community.

I said at the beginning of my remarks that the intent of the changes may be well based. It is clear that changes are required in the operation of child care within our community, as part of changes to the former arrangements, in community based and in private child-care arrangements. It is also clear that when these changes are mooted and then attempted to be implemented, they contribute to the biggest single problem in our community today; that is, that basic insecurity which is gnawing away at the foundations of what we should have and what the government was endeavouring to present as its modelâ€”a community that feels safe, secure and able to reap the benefits of the development of our great country.

Unfortunately we find, even two years after the election of a coalition government, even after some changes in the economic status that are obviously positive and contribute to people feeling perhaps better off in some sectors of the community, that there is still a very deep, underlying concern about the sort of changes that are going on in our community, which these changes go towards exacerbating.

These changes are based, like the aged care changes, on a desire by government to reduce its financial liability in an area of important social service. There are no two ways about this: these are financial changes. They are designed to reduce the pressure on the government's outlays and, of course, to try to reduce the pressure on taxation and all the other elements that go towards accumulating capital in order to pay for the government's services.

It is also notionally predicated on a concept of user pays, in the beliefâ€”and I am a supporter of capitalism and of private enterpriseâ€”that the private sector is the best source of service provision. But, of course, there will always be areas where this golden rule of private enterprise, capitalism, does not work in practice or perhaps does not work as effectively in practice as the theorists would like.

It is also a means by which government can disengage itself from an area of government outlays which is growing steadily as our population growsâ€”another common factor with the changes to aged care provisions. It, too, has had to be modified as a result of public outcry at the forms of changes, which have not met the expectations not only of the community but of the government itself.

There can be no doubt that there has been a need for reform in child care and that some of the government's reforms are positive, but as a package I have some very serious doubts about the Howard government's approach to child care. It is no wonder that we find an outcry from providers and users and the fact that the implementation of elements of the Howard government's philosophy has had to wait until technology catches up. One might think, from the explanation associated with this bill, that this government is at the cutting edge of marrying its policies to technological advancement and is only being held back because it has moved slightly in advance of what technology can support.

What happened in reality, though, was that the government came up with a plan to implement its child-care policy which could not actually work. In effect, its implementation would have caused such administrative problems that the industry would have been significantly and adversely affected. This amendment is an acceptance of this fundamental fact. The government has argued that case in supporting its own amendment.

It is surely evident by now to the people of Australia that, for all its ideas on reform, economic management and fiscal responsibility, this is a government that has had problems with following its policies through to actual implementation in the real world or in selling its ideas effectively to an increasingly wary Australian public. This is another problem indicated by Hugh Mackay in his workâ€”in the implementation of public policy, a government of any complexion now has to overcome what is, in essence, a very deep-seated cynicism in the community about the intent of the government and what its real interests are in implementing government policy.

People do not believe the promises of politicians any longer. They do not believe governments when they promise to make changes. They now talk about core promises and, presumably, expendable promises, as though these are an actual reality of election campaigns and the implementation of government policy following an election. So it is hardly surprising that people are deeply cynical about how governments work and how public policy can be implemented.

The Howard government is asking us to trust its reform agenda. It wants us to agree to trust its reforms in child care. Yet, based on its reputation for reform in Austudy, small business, aged care, dental care, pharmaceutical benefits, research and development and the initial stages of privatisation of the CES, there is a very good reason for people to be suspicious and to have their doubts. Of course, it is the role of members of this place to ensure that the concerns of the community are reflected in debate on these types of legislative reform pieces.

Working from basic principles, one of the fundamental roles of government is to create and maintain a suitable environment in which the people of this country can live happy, prosperous lives and strive to achieve reasonable ambitions. That speaks for itself. This includes the provision of a range of services that stimulate the economy or support people who are in genuine need. It also means encouraging the fair and equitable participation of all of our citizens in Australia's daily life.

A child-care subsidy can be viewed as a direct parallel to business grants, research and development or tax breaks to stimulate various sectors of our economy. I do not think the government can reduce the costs of business and industry in Australia without providing assistance, in some cases, to the people working in it. The reality is that if the government does not promote affordable child care the result will be a wages impost on employers to make it worth while for a considerable section of the employment market to remain in employment.

The overwhelming majority of workers who would be at risk of being forced from the work force are, in this instance, women. Adequate child care in a society like ours where reliance on extended family is reducing is one of the single most important things which empowers women in our community. The member for McPherson talks about choice, and this is a basic element in that choice. It allows women to pursue careers and supplement family income to an extent where they can make a positive contribution to a family's quality of life. To impose a system which reduces a woman's choice takes away power to influence a family's circumstances and, in my view, could well amount to a direct attack on women.

Australians want to have access to child care that is safe, affordable and easy to understand. All opinion polls, all surveys, point to that fundamental truism. I believe that elements of this legislation are acting against these objectives. Increased child-care costs will force some parents to seek cheap, unregulated, underskilled care providers as their only option if they are to maintain what they consider to be a reasonable standard of living.

For the growing number of single-parent households, disposable income is not a negotiable entity. Equally, many two-income families do not have the luxury of choosing to have one parent stay home and perform the child-care role. It is something that I consider to be worth promotingâ€”something that the government should be promoting as part of its family package, its bias to families. However, we understand that many families do not have that luxury. Economic insecurity and necessity mean that they must seek child care. If increased costs drive them to less safe arrangements for their children, then this government has failed a fundamental duty of care to its citizens.

The government has no good record in this regard, I am sorry to say. I believe that the unnecessary complexity of the legislation and administrative procedures it has sought to apply to so much of its reform agenda is a key reason for its inability both to implement it and, more importantly, to convince the Australian public that it is good reform.

In many instances, the Howard government has been perceived as a government that is committed to reform for reform's sake. In the first instance, it has cited the $10 billion black hole as the raison d'etre for reformâ€”something that I have spoken about and supported. Obviously, the government sees that as its fundamental principle.

Hugh MacKay's excellent work and other reputable national studies like the Klemenger report show that one of the key concerns in Australia today is insecurity. No-one in this place should be surprised at that, or even at the recent causes of public insecurity. I believe that a government devoted to change for change's sakeâ€”as this government is apparently perceived nowâ€”is contributing to this sense of insecurity. Insecurity is reinforced on a daily basis by comprehensive change which is poorly marketed and in some instances poorly implemented.

I think that making the member for Bass (Mr Warwick Smith) the minister in this instance was a good move. I happen to think that Warwick Smith is a very good minister. Given the circumstances in which he took over, when the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) made to his ministry, I think he has tried valiantly to overcome some of these problems. However, he is still charged with implementing a financial cut. There are no other ways of looking at it: it is a financial cut at the bottom of this that is the reason for the changesâ€”apart from other policy changes the government wishes to implement to encourage competition and choice in the child-care industry. They are something I would like to see encouraged as well.

The public is increasingly sceptical about the government's reform program. Again, this is something that is caused in some instances by the unnecessary complexity or the poor marketing of changes and particularly the need for those changes. One has to look at child care in the context of what I mentioned about Hugh MacKay's work and this basic insecurity. Particularly in the case of women, in many instances the principal carers in families, it is something that is constantly in the forefront of their minds when they are assessing how they are managing the care of their own families. This is something that is absolutely fundamental to a society like ours which is family based. I would have thought that these changes strike at the very heart of the issues that affect women in our community today.

Finally, I make a point about community services generally. I come from Western Australia which, over the last five years, has suffered something like a $760 million shortfall in state grants. Given the recent recommendation for another $27 million cut, we will lose even more. These are cuts that have affected community services that are available for the families in my electorate. They are caused by what is know by economists as vertical fiscal imbalance, which basically means that as the economy growsâ€”as the Treasurer (Mr Costello) keeps telling us it is doingâ€”in Western Australia we are not getting a fair share of the extra money being raised by the Commonwealth as part of its taxation. In fact, we are being cheated by the Commonwealth.

Funnily enough, on radio the other day there was a straw pollâ€”one of those populist pollsâ€”asking people if they thought Western Australia should secede from the Commonwealth because they would be better off. About 97 per cent rang in and said yes. It is quite clear from my contacts in my electorate that the people know that fundamentally we are being cheated in Western Australia. When I ask people in my electorate about the services or the things that most concern them, particularly in areas where there are families raising children, community service provisions are at the forefront of their minds then.

They want public transport. They want community services that we take for granted in some cities. They want the sorts of infrastructure that are part and parcel of a modern community. Yet, when I go back to the state government, for instance, asking when these services will be provided in the newer, developing areas of my electorate, I am told that, because of the vertical fiscal imbalance, because the Howard government is not giving us a fair share of the taxation revenue, we have to wait or we cannot have it. They say, `It is Canberra's fault. Do not blame us.'

So then I came here and asked the Prime Minister: `Why is this so?' He said there is no problem, yet his own members, the backbench members from Western Australia, have told the newspapers and elsewhere that they have been telling him and his senior ministers that this is a very serious problem. When the government whip was saying that Independent members are not able to do anything constructive in this place, I asked the question: what were the backbench members doing to influence their own senior cabinet ministers about the state of affairs in Western Australia where, as a result of vertical fiscal imbalance, community services are unavailable or provided at a reduced rate? We find ourselves in a situationâ€”certainly in my stateâ€”where, together with the types of changes being proposed and the way they are being implemented, they contribute more and more to insecurity, to a general sense of despondency in our community that I would have thought was anathema to the objectives of the coalition government when it was first elected. This government promised, for instance, that it would reduce red tape to small business by half, and it has failed to do so. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: â€”I rise to speak on the Child Care Legislation Amendment Bill 1998 which has come about as a result of the government deferring the implementation of the Child Care Payments Act 1997 until a child-care card or a smart card is available. Such a development will allow more efficient implementation of the child-care reforms.

speech.para: I sympathise with the previous speaker, the member for Moore (Mr Filing). I also am from a state that is a long way from any metropolitan centres, and I can quite appreciate the points that he has made. Those of us in far-flung areas of Australia produce more than our fair share of export dollars. I would simply say that in my electorate we provide six times the export dollars that the average Australian does. I know that there is a similar situation in Western Australia. I might be cheeky enough to suggest that he needs more National Party members over there. Nonetheless, I think he has made a valid point about the distribution of Commonwealth funds.

I move back to discussion on the bill. I apologise for digressing, but the point was well made by the previous speaker. The bill before us allows the implementation of other decisions taken in the budget, despite the deferral of some of the proposals. It allows a limit on child-care assistance of 20 hours per week for non-work related care, with some significant exemptions. It allows for the introduction of a planning system for long day care places, a limit on the provision of new places to 7,000 per year for the next two years and, as well as thatâ€”a very welcome innovationâ€”the introduction of immunisation as a criteria for eligibility for child-care assistance and child-care rebate. These are sound measures, carefully targeted, because of the spiralling cost of child care.

In 1996-97, approximately $1.5 billion was provided by government for child careâ€”$1.1 billion from the federal government and $400 million from the states and territories. The number of federally funded places has grown from 137,100 in 1988 to 396,700 in 1994â€”an increase of 31.5 per cent per year. By far the biggest item in child care expenditure is the child-care cash rebate, comprising $145.5 million. There is, though, a disparity in the distribution of child-care places in Australia: some areas have too few; others have too many. I think that the introduction of the planning and the cap on new places to 7,000 per year are welcome measures to ensure that places are allocated to those areas of need.

Another welcome measure is the 20-hour per week limit on access to child care for non-work related care. The definition of paid work is quite generous. It includes those looking for work, those in paid work, those studying and training, and so on. There is also an exemption for families where one parent is working and the other is disabled and unable to undertake paid work or care for a child.

There is a particular situation in regional areas with child-care centres, and this also has been recognised in the changes. In some regional centres where the child-care centre basically is the only Commonwealth facilityâ€”if one could put it that wayâ€”in town, an enormous number of children who come to the centre come, I guess one could say, from dysfunctional families. I do not like to say thatâ€”perhaps `loving but somewhat misguided families' might be a better way of putting it.

I specifically refer to a child-care centre in my area, the Rainbow Kids Childcare Centre at Sarina, run by Narelle and Snow Gerhardt and their daughter, Danni. They are the sole providers of child care and they deal with children at risk of neglect or abuse. I know that the owners of this centre put in a great deal of personal time and cost to assist children at that centre. One little boy, for instance, had a severe ear infection which would, in time, have rendered his becoming deaf. Narelle, at her own cost and time, took this young fellow some 900 kilometres to receive specialist treatment. His hearing is now excellent and he has started school happily. Another small child there also came from a very difficult family situation and, at the age of three, could not speak or walk properly. She is making good progress at the centre; she is starting to speak quite well and to walk as well. Recently, one of the staff there slept overnight with a distraught mother and her children. The mother was considering suicide because of difficult circumstances at home.

I welcome the recognition of the Minister for Family Services (Mr Warwick Smith) that there are special circumstances for families that have very difficult home lives, and that quite often centres that perhaps are the sole providers in isolated areas undertake roles that are probably far beyond the expectations of a child-care centre.

I would now like to speak briefly about the 20-hour a week limit. The previous government was going to set a 15-hour limit on child care that was not work related, so I think the government has been generous in restricting that to a 20-hour a week limit.

I am very pleased about the immunisation requirement for eligibility for child-care assistance and the child-care cash rebate. I am sure all of us saw the very distressing advertisements on television of babies with whooping cough. If somebody chooses not to immunise their child, that is their right, but they should not impose a risk on other infants in the same child-care centre who cannot be immunised. Obligation is a two-way street. If parents expect the taxpayer to subsidise and assist them, that is fine, but they should be responsible. If parents do not to immunise their children they expose other very young children under the age of immunisation to serious risk of infectious disease. I think this is a very sound measure which has also been supported by the opposition.

I want to speak very briefly about a rather insidious view that is gaining some currency amongst the economic rationalist group. It is best exemplified by a senior executive from one of the major business groups who addressed a committee meeting recently. He made a number of observations. One observation he madeâ€”I realise I have taken this out of context; nonetheless, it is symptomatic of a view that is growingâ€”was that for a mother, who is a doctor, to stay home with her children is inefficient. I presume what he meant was that she could employ somebody else to undertake the menial task of mothering, freeing her to go and do an important job with more statusâ€”and more payâ€”and that this would be economically efficient. It probably would be if children were guppies, but they are not. They are intelligent, loving little people, who need mothering and fathering. I would like to put on the record today that the most affordable, high quality child care that infants and young children can have is from their own mothers and fathersâ€”the exception being families with a lot of difficulties, as I have mentioned previously.

We all know that a woman's place is everywhere and that a mother's place is where she genuinely chooses it to be. But this was not always the case under 13 years of Labor government. I refer to a statement made by the member for Jagajaga (Ms Macklin) on 29 September 1997 in a debate on a related bill:
I am sure it is not the case that the ministerâ€”
then Judi Moylanâ€”
thinks that a woman's place is in the home.

We all know, as I said, that a woman's place is everywhere and a mother's place is where she genuinely chooses it to be. I believe that the government is giving genuine choice for mothers and fathersâ€”far greater than the previous government did. The Labor government were such poor economic managers that families paid an extra $4,000 a year in interest on the average mortgageâ€”a great impost on a familyâ€”and the average small family business paid an extra $2,500 a year in higher interest payments. They promised l-a-w tax cuts when they got into government and not only did they not deliver; they put up wholesale sales taxâ€”again, an impost on the average family. Families have had to wait until now for the coalition government to deliver $200 a year in tax cuts under the family tax initiative and health insurance rebates of $450 a year. I put it to you, Mr Deputy Speaker, that compassion and assistance for families come in many guises. Sound economic management is one way of assisting families in a real and productive way.

I would like to refer to some of the points that were made earlier by the member for Jagajagaâ€”firstly, the increased cost of care. I refer to a survey of child-care services undertaken by the Queensland Child Care Coalition. It is shown on a bar graph. The most common reason why parents change the child-care arrangements for their childrenâ€”42 per cent of parents list this as their reasonâ€”is a change to the pattern of work for parents. A private centre in my area of Mackay states:
Downsizing at the local mines has been the main factor in children ceasing to use our service, as families have left to work elsewhere.

That is a regrettable situation regarding the mines. It points out that the major factor there has not been cost but changes in the workplace for parents. The other most common reason listed in the survey is job losses and insecurity for parents. The third one is `Other reasons', which is not gone into in great detail in the survey but represents some 15 per cent of parents. The fourth reason is increased cost of care. Quite obviously, there are many other factors which are causing parents to change their pattern of child care. I put on the record that I refute the statements that were made by the member for Jagajaga.

I would like to speak very briefly about some of the ways in which we can encourage more affordable high quality child careâ€”the mum and dad care. I support the statements by the member for McPherson (Mr Bradford). I am grateful to Dr Peter Cook, a noted child psychiatrist, for some of the ideas that he has expanded on on how we can make our society a more family friendly society. He says that we should recognise parents, especially mothers and very young children, are a unique, valuable and essential group, with special needs for a few short years; that you can re-run a video, but you cannot re-run infancyâ€”how true that is; and that the government could lead the way by encouraging community respect and appreciation of home caring parents of either sex.

An article in the Age has worked out that the value of a mother's work at home is $139.4 billion. This is 17 times the value of the sports industry in Australia. Another statistic from an article in the same paper puts the real economic value of Australian breast milk production at $2.2 billion and states that this could be increased to $5.9 billion with some education. If Aussie mums can make an economic contribution like that, it makes Paul Keating's boast of bringing home the bacon look pretty weak. Congratulations to our Aussie mums. I think that affirmative action is needed in favour of mothers of young children to give genuine freedom of choice.

At school holiday time I take my son to meetings with me where I can, and I have discovered that other women with young children really warm to this. So many of them say to me, `Oh, can you do that?' Of course you can. I am really pleased that a number of women from the Friends of the Birth Centre in Mackay now bring their young children to meetings. It is great to see that mothers are not concerned about the opinions of others and that they are taking their young children along when they go out into the community and the workplace. I think we should all be tolerant of this. It is not easy for a young mother to take part in a meeting when she has a couple of little toddlers and perhaps a baby with her, but what a difference it makes to the self-esteem of that mother and for the opportunity of her children to mix with her in her work and community activities. So I certainly support the suggestions by Dr Cook.

The government has done a great deal to bring affirmative action for young mothers. Mothers need superannuation. It is very pleasing to see that the government on 1 July 1997 brought in a tax rebate of 18 per cent on superannuation contributions made to the account of a non-working or low income spouse. This was a great recognition that while motherhood is a labour of love it need not be a financial hardship.

talk.start.para: â€”I am very pleased to rise to join the debate on the Child Care Legislation Amendment Bill before the House. I am conscious of the fact that, by agreement, we have decided to limit our comments to 10 minutes each. It is a very lengthy topic that would need more than 10 minutes to do it justice, but I will just stick to a few specific points that I believe are necessary to raise.

speech.para: I have spent the last couple of days speaking to as many of the managers and coordinators as possible at the child-care centres in my electorate and to as many parents as I have been able to speak to who have got children at long day care and out of school hours centres, family day care centres and community centresâ€”privately owned, that is. In my electorate, some 3,000 children in some 76 centres and hundreds of staff are involved. They are all involved in one endeavourâ€”the only endeavour that is of any importance in this debateâ€”and that is the welfare of the children in the care of the centres.

The picture painted by those I have spoken to is cause for grave concern indeedâ€”a very grim picture. That is especially so in my electorate with one of the highest concentrations of people of non-English speaking backgrounds who are suffering grave hardship. I am gravely concerned at the major thrust of the changes and the removal of the operational subsidies. I am gravely concerned at the underlying philosophy and the criticism that is being levelled at the coalition government that this policy is a disincentive to mothers to go to work, if that is their choice. If that is the case, then I can only abhor such a policy.

What the coalition government has to understand is that child care to most of the mothers who want to send their children to child care is a necessityâ€”whether it be for financial reasons or for the mother's own needs to be part of the work forceâ€”a necessity that has to be acknowledged by any caring government and a necessity that not only has to be acknowledged but has to be assisted wholeheartedly. The coalition government, in my view, is doing the exact opposite.

Today's world has moved on from the 1950s and 1960s. Today's mothers are keen to rejoin the work force as soon as possible, if that is their choice. They are keen to participate in every facet of community life, including giving themselves every possible chance to rise through the ranks to positions of importance and decision making in the work force. They have had to pull out, for obvious reasons, from the work force while they are in the process of giving birth. Males and/or single women then replace them in the positions that the mothers have held previously. In other words, the cards are stacked against mothers, and we must do all we can to redress that imbalance. These mothers, to regain their position in the work force, if that is what they want to do, first have to find a suitable place to leave their children for the best possible care while they are at work but also have to be able to afford that care; and, thirdly, they have to have peace of mind in the knowledge that the arrangements for their children are well in hand before they commit themselves to the rigours and the competition that are part and parcel of the paid working environment.

I turn now to those in community long day careâ€”the children who are most affectedâ€”their parents and the staff at these centres. There are some 400 children in my electorate that are in community long day care, and they and their parents are affected by the cuts in the operational subsidies. Some of the statements that were made to me only yesterday and the day before are that there has been confusion, chaos and substantial fee rises. Many families have been forced to cut back the hours they send their children to the centres. I am told that one in seven families have dropped out. Many centres have had to reduce staff. Many centres have had to replace staff with lower qualified people. There is instability and uncertainty, not only for the parents but for the staff. Many other things were mentioned to me, including one particular centre, which wanted to foster music for these children to appreciate, having to do away with their visiting teacher of music, who was going to teach them what music is all about and an appreciation of music, even at that tender age, which I think is a very important part of the learning process for these young children.

Many other families are unable to meet the increased costs and they have resorted to sending their children to alternative types of care which, unfortunately, are likely to be unregulated and not required to meet the health, safety and quality standards of regulated careâ€”in other words, a return to backyard care and to latchkey children. There are about 1,930 children in my electorateâ€”that is, in addition to the 400 in long day careâ€”who are in out of school hours and family day care centres.

The managers and the coordinators I have spoken to in the family day care centres, whilst they have retained their subsidy, are worried sick that they will suffer the same fate as those in long day care. I am seeking as many of them as possible to sign a petition to present to the parliament to state how concerned they are and to try to ensure that there is a guarantee that they at least will not have the subsidy removed from them. No doubt, in summing up, the Minister for Family Services (Mr Warwick Smith) will make mention of that. I hope he will do that.

I would just like to mention two other things specifically with regard to what the member for Bradfield (Dr Nelson) said. It is the perennial question to governments: where is the money coming from? He made the points that there is going to be a downturn in the economy because of the financial crisis in Asia and that child-care requirements have grown substantially. Where is the money coming from?

When the coalition government came into office on 2 March 1996, it found that there was a budget deficit of $10.5 billion. It is a disgrace that the former government of Australiaâ€”the government of Australia representing the people of Australiaâ€”placed the people of Australia in that situation. I have acknowledged that, and I have spoken out against it on previous occasions.

The point is: is it that necessary and that vital for a government to come in and say, `We are going to turn that $10.5 billion deficit into a surplus of $2 billion'â€”or $1.7 billion, as I have heard on other occasionsâ€”`within 2Â½ years'? Is it that necessary to place such stress, pain and hardship on the Australian nation to produce a substantial surplus and to cut back the deficit in just 2Â½ years? In my view, it would have been better to have dealt with the pain and suffering over a long period of time at smaller doses than what is happening now and what has happened in the past two years.

Mr Deputy Speaker Mossfield, I noted that when you were speaking on this bill earlier this morning you made mention of visiting child-care centres and of the contacts you have had with parents and children. That is good to see, and it is important that all of us in this parliament get out as much as we can and visit our electorate communities.

I would just like to share with the House an experience that I had some months ago now when I was invited by a social worker to go and visit one of my local libraries. I was intrigued why she wanted me to visit a local library after school hours. What I saw there concerned me greatly. A lot of the children at that library after school hours were there not for any other reason other than their mothers and fathers had told them not to go home because there was no-one home. They do not want them out in the street or in the park, so they send them to the local libraries where they can sit, to a point, in airconditioned comfort and in a quiet environment and be safe from the streets. Consequently, the librarians who spoke to me said that they are now being used as child carers. That is a terrible thing to happen in our society.

In fact, the librarians are also being asked to intervene when children end up having a bit of a disagreement amongst themselves. In many instances, they have found that some of the children are, unfortunately, trouble makers. Who could blame these children for being in that situation where they are feeling left out from a normal life that one would have where that would be dealt with in a child-care centre that is operated in a way to specifically look after the needs of these young children.

I have agreed to limit my comments to 10 minutes, but I wanted to say a lot more about out of school hours care because it is a very large sector of our child-care industry, and it is feeling a lot of pain with the cutbacks. Admittedly, some adjustments have been made with regard to the payments made to the parents of the children at these child-care centres, but the fact is that everyone is feeling the pinch. It is unnecessary. It should have been done over a longer period. The young children and their parents are suffering, and that should not have occurred.

talk.start.para: â€”In addressing this amendment to the Child Care Legislation Amendment Bill 1998 , I would just like to say that this government is going a long way to meeting the needs of those in our community who require child-care assistance. Child-care assistance can come in a variety of ways, and there are many choices that parents have in the community at present.

speech.para: One choice is to stay at home, which I believe will always be the first and foremost choice. As the member for Dawson (Mrs De-Anne Kelly) has said, you cannot replay those early years of your children's life. Once passed, you have missed those very precious moments where children first talk, first walk and enjoy the warmth and security of their own home.

There are other choices available, such as the day care parent, where economic necessity means the parent has to go out to work. The day care parent reflects an almost parallel existence for the home situation. In the comfort of one's home, a child is nurtured and minded. If that is not available, centre based care is also an option. I might add, neither of these options were available to me when I was having my children many years ago. In fact, over the last 20 years there has been growth in the range of options for parents who utilise child-care assistance.

talk.start.para: â€”Not so many years.

â€”Not so many years ago. This government is committed to quality child-care assistance. In determining accreditation standards, we want to ensure that the level of child-care assistance is of a national standardâ€”the children are the first priority and the needs of the parents are met. I believe this amendment goes a long way to assisting parents in having those needs met.

speech.para: In the previous 13 years, we saw the wants of the industry blow out to an almost unbelievable level, which, as a consequence, led to a review of the situation. The previous speaker, the member for Lowe (Mr Zammit), said that certain adjustments had to be made. These adjustments have had an impact on the industry. However, I am pleased to say that those that are doing well will continue to survive and, as you will see from my evidence, the ones that are having difficulty with this period of adjustment have poor management skills and poor advice.

The issue of child care and the associated social benefit should never be underestimated. This amendment bill will see the deferral of the payment commencement date under the Child Care Payments Act, as announced by the Minister for Family Services (Mr Warwick Smith) in January this year. This deferral is necessary so that payments can continue to be made under current arrangements. The deferral, announced in January, saw the cessation of systems development which would have allowed the implementation of child-care assistance and the child-care rebate under the act rather than the current arrangement, and this will be enforced from 27 April this year.

The deferral of these payment arrangements is a result of representations made by the child-care industry wherein they raised many concerns with the government. The Depart ment of Health and Family Services is working towards simplified procedures, and this deferral will see maintenance of the current payment arrangements. In addition, this bill allows the introduction of budget measures that are to commence on 27 April 1998, and I would like to address some of these measures.

The government is planning to introduce the 20-hour limit for non-work related child care. I have been active in consulting with providers in Bowman and they have expressed concerns about the politically motivated comments conveniently surfacing as we consider this bill. Furthermore, the providers to whom I speak are indicating some reservation about the 20-hour, two-day limit. We needed to start with a limit of some type and the industry indicated between 14 and 18 hours as the preferred option, if a limit was to be imposed. The average use of time for parents is around 14 hours, and the level of 20 hours, as proposed, is an attempt to focus non-work related child-care assistance on the appropriate users. As always, the government will monitor the effect, and I am sure any necessary adjustments will be made along the way.

It is my belief that the industry itself has taken some of the flak over the matter of limits because as the level of assistance decreases so too does the level of enrolments at the child-care facilities. This is particularly noted at the community based and `not for profit' style of centre. It is these centres whose users have a greater reliance on assistance programs. As the assistance declines, so too will the enrolment levels of children who are most likely either disadvantaged or in `at risk' circumstances. However, it is most certainly the case that we have more than adequately addressed the industry expectation by the initial recognition of the 20 hours as against the hours preferred by them, mentioned earlier. The out of school hours option has also improved choices and expanded opportunities which parents can avail themselves of.

Some child-care centres have management practices which are also counterproductive. Conversely, some of the community based and not for profit providers are very efficient in the day-to-day operation as well as the management of their individual human resource requirements. Most of the better managed centres are enjoying good enrolments, and they pursue the business in the newly created competitive environment very well. Despite this, it was interesting to note that the restructuring and management training funds of $10 million made available last year by the minister and his department were not fully drawn on. Another interesting sideline to this arrangement involves a decline in enrolments at one of the not for profit operations in my electorate of Bowman.

The Queensland Council of Social Service, QCOSS, was contracted to a number of child-care centres throughout Queensland to implement the restructuring and management training process. This involved an outcome of recommendations, and one of the recommendations saw a centre in question increase the fees. The fee increase compounded the problem of competition for this centre, and they have suffered a downturn in enrolments or retention. That was poor advice.

It would appear that the fee charged by QCOSS of $3,000 per centre was money poorly spent in light of the recent bleating from the industry about alleged cuts. I have to wonder about QCOSSâ€”its ability to objectively review the performance of these operators and to make subsequent recommendations of an unbiased nature and its agenda on behalf of the people it represents.

The private providers have another factor affecting their commercial viability. These small businesses are funded without capital funding or operational support from the government. They also employ qualified people and need to meet strict accreditation criteria similar to the community based ones. This accreditation comes at a cost not only in getting the appropriate staff but also in the physical infrastructure of the centre.

The industry employs people within workplace agreements, and minimum hours of work form an integral part of these agreements. These costs need to be recognised as a real cost to industry. As a result of these additional imposts, private operators could suffer a similar downtrend in enrolments. With the ethic of being a for profit small business, it should be noted that the private providers suffer a greater cost to their businesses under these situations than those endured by the non-private sector.

Another issue addressed by this amendment is the matter of age appropriate immunisation. It is significant that we in Queensland have had significant success in this area. On Monday, the Queensland coalition government announced through its health minister, Mike Horan, the nation's highest immunisation rate of children at 12 monthsâ€”a resounding 81 per cent. Not wishing to stop at this level, the Queensland government has targeted 95 per cent by the year 2000.

In releasing this information, Mr Horan identified this innovation by the coalition government as a key factor in seeing improved immunisation rates across Australia. The Labor Party opposition in Queensland stated that `Labor had pushed the early 1990s to lift rates'. This is 1998, and statements such as this are indicative of the lack of follow-through demonstrated by Labor across all issues once they have achieved a vote.

The Howard government has allocated $4.9 billion to child care over four years. We have established a program capable of creating an extra 83,000 places in child care over a four-year period. Our program has better planning, and it will ensure the growth of child-care services in places of greatest need. This government is committed to quality. We support quality assurance in long day care services and the development of systems for family day care and outside school hours care.

It would be remiss of me if I did not take some time to highlight some recent untruths about the child-care industry which have been spread by a group called the Queensland Child Care Coalition. This group have recently released questionable data, the result of questionable research conducted on their behalf. The research findings were highly critical of this government's action in attempting to clean up the mess left to us after 13 years of Labor blundering with this very important area of community welfare.

This is the part that should discredit the bleating by QCCC. The QCCC is an organisation with clear lines of operational alliance and alignment with QCOSS, the group who took $3,000 off each of the centres it allegedly represents. The particular research document is released on paper clearly identifying QCCC links with the LHMWU. The spokespersons for the QCCC are Mr Peter Walsh, Director of QCOSS, and Ms Grace Grace, Assistant General Secretary of the ACTU. This is clear evidence which flaws the research data as having a bias. Unfortunately, this welfare lobby, with clearly defined links with the Labor Party, is out in the marketplace spreading the usual untruths and fear amongst the Australian community.

I am pleased to see the recent comments from the Australian Confederation of Child Care, representing over 1,000 private child-care centres, stating that `Australian centre based child care is the world's best and still affordable'. The confederation president, Mr Martin Kemp, said:
The message we want to make clear to families is that centre based child care is very high quality and very affordableâ€”ring your local centre today.

I am on Mr Kemp's team in this matter. I believe the Howard government is committed to the continued quality assured care reflected in this comment. This is the basis for the very sensible and timely changes proposed here, resulting in the delivery of quality child care to Australian families.

talk.start.para: â€”The member for Bowman (Mrs West) and other government members speaking before her want us to believe that the Child Care Legislation Amendment Bill 1998 is about improving child care in this country. Let us have a very quick look at what this bill does in the area of child care.

speech.para: It limits child-care assistance, a saving to the government in this current financial year of $33 million. It involves the cessation of indexing the child-care assistance fee ceiling and the child-care cash rebate ceilings, a saving of $31 million to the government this current financial year. It involves the reduction of the child-care cash rebate benefit to 20 per cent for high income families, a saving of $11 million.

The changes to assessing eligibility for child-care assistance will save the government $24 million. The changes to new growth strategies for long day care centres will be a $25 million saving. The new payment arrangements for child-care assistance and the child-care cash rebate mean a $20 million saving. Reforms in the area of school aged care will be a $5 million saving, paying child-care assistance in arrears will be a $32 million saving, covering the cost of child-care participants in the work for the dole scheme will be a $100,000 saving and an increase in the number of family day care places will be a saving of $1.7 million.

The total savings are $184 million. If you add to that the savings from other areas, such as the abolition of the operational subsidy for community based centres, we are talking about a saving to this government of some $820 million. The member for Bowman and other government members want to stand in this place and tell us that this is about improving accessibility to child care and improving the quality of child care in this country!

I was disappointed that I missed the contribution of the member for Lowe (Mr Zammit). I did hear his last few words. He is now an Independent in this place and that gives his contribution on a range of issues new status. He has a new freedom. He can speak freely on these issues, and I understand he has done that today. He has expressed grave concerns about the impact of this bill and the Child Care Payments Bill 1997, which attaches to it, on families in his electorate and families right throughout the country.

I did hear the contributions from the member for Bradfield (Dr Nelson) and the member for McPherson (Mr Bradford). I have a great deal of respect for them both. That is why I listened so intently. But I was most disappointed by what I heard. The member for Bradfield said that sometimes he wonders where this nation is heading. I often wonder too. The conclusion I always arrive at is that under this government the nation is heading down the gurgler. There exists few better examples of how wrong this government has it in a range of policy areas than what it is doing in child care. There are some good examplesâ€”aged care, the unemployed, employment services and the rest. I could go on all day, but I am committed to keeping my contribution to this bill short in order that this bill can be dealt with before question time.

The member for McPherson's main point seemed to be that he was charging the Australian Labor Party for being ideologically driven with respect to these issues. I say: guilty as charged. We believe government is about making for a more equitable society. That is what governments do. That is our ideologyâ€”making a better and fairer society. So I say: guilty as charged.

Both the member for Bradfield and the member for McPherson demonstrated a total lack of understanding of child care as a policy tool. Child care is not just about giving away a pinch of money to very low income families who really need to have both parents working; it is about much more than that. But the member for Bradfield just wants to apply the economic rationalist tag, the narrow thinking, the very approach the Australian community is so sick and tired of.

It is much more than a little handout to help those who really need to have both parents working; it is a social policy tool. It enables women in this country to participateâ€”to participate in industry, to participate in education, to participate in the formulation of policy, to participate in the administration of government policy, and indeed to participate in this place. I know that probably not too many women in this place rely on child care to be here each dayâ€”the arrangements are more complex than thatâ€”but I bet they did when they were working toward becoming a member of this place. That is why child care is much more than a small payment; it is a social policy tool.

Why shouldn't we have women participating more actively in society? They do represent more than 50 per cent of the population. I genuinely believe that Australia will be a better place as a result of a more expanded female participation in those areas I have mentioned. But the member for McPherson has a different view. He wants to go with John Howard back down the road to the white picket fence. The member for McPhersonâ€”I hope I understand him correctly; I apologise if I am misrepresenting himâ€”wants women to go back to the family and look after the kids like they always did in the days of the white picket fence. That is the society the member for McPherson has in mindâ€”the one where the ladies stay in the kitchen and the men go out and make all the important decisions. That is his vision for Australia. If I am correct about his vision, I certainly do not share it with him.

The government also says that this bill and their approach to child care is about introducing competition into this sector or, as I heard one member on the other side describe it, this industry. It is just an industry to them. You get the micro-economic textbook out and apply the cost curves, et cetera, in the same way you do in other areas of public policy.

What happens in rural and regional Australia? There is not any profit motive in rural and regional Australia. The numbers just are not there. In the regions we rely heavily on the community based sector, the non-profit organisations. But what has the government done? It has removed their operational subsidies. How do they survive? In the bush only two or three kids need to leave a particular centre to completely undermine its viability. The result is that it just closes down. Kids are going to be leaving the centres because, as a result of the abolition of the operational subsidy, fees are going up by up to $45 a week. For a family with two kids that is $90 a week out of the pay packet. What happens? The parents have no choice but to withdraw the children. Again, the centre loses the critical mass necessary to make it viable and it closes down. I can just see the private sector running in to fill the void. You must be joking! So this bill is about much more than what the government is doing with fees.

I am pleased the shadow minister, the honourable member for Jagajaga (Ms Macklin), has moved an amendment to allow us to have a more broad ranging debate on this because you cannot talk about these new fee arrangements without talking about the other issues such as operational subsidies. I rise in support of the amendment put by the shadow minister. I implore the House to consider what we have said and to consider what people like the member for Lowe, in his new Independent role, has said. I implore the House to support the amendment put by the member for Jagajaga.

talk.start.para: â€”It is not all that often that I have the opportunity to express such glowing praise for the oratory of the speaker who preceded me, but I do so on this occasion for the honourable member for Hunter (Mr Fitzgibbon). He made a number of very good points. He distinguished between the Labor Party's position on these matters and the government's. The Labor Party is about creating a sense of community, a sense of society. The government's policy in this area is directed towards attacking, gutting, indeed decimating the community sector and introducing this element of the hallowed turf of the free market.

speech.para: Hence, as the member for Hunter pointed out, there is no longer talk of a child-care sector or child-care service but a reference constantly to the child-care industry. It is amazing that if you look at what this government has done you will see that the prime focus of its attack has been on the community sectorâ€”the sector where parents and interested members of the community come together, often with the support of a local council, to develop child-care facilities, whether they are community based long day care centres or out of hours school care centres.

It is this attack on the community that they are so determined about. For some reason they just cannot comprehend that people would be interested in doing something for their community, particularly when the service they are providing is for children in the community. They just cannot comprehend this. Their only comprehension of motivation for human beings is the profit motive and hence the world will be set right because the only motivation, according to them, is to make a quid. Their whole regime is to open up opportunities for people to make a quid, but they are making a quid at the expense of our children.

We are no longer talking about a relationship between teacher and child or carer and child; we are now talking about a relationship between a business proprietor and a consumerâ€”the consumer often being less than five years old.

The focus of my points today will be in respect of the outside school hours care sector. Before I go to that, I place on the record just what this government has done. In 1996, they had a two-year freeze on child-care assistance payments. In 1997, the following occurred: a cap on child-care assistance to 50 hours a week; lowering the cut-off point for child-care assistance with families of two or more children so that families earning over $91,000 a year, by combined income, are ineligible; abolition of additional income levels for each dependent child; reduction in child-care cash rebate for families earning more than $70,000 a year from 30 per cent to 20 per cent; and the abolition of the operational subsidy to community based day care centres.

In 1998, they have abolished the operational subsidy for outside school hours care, resulting in increased fees across the board and restricted access to child-care assistance for non-work related care. In addition, I can recall that block funding to states for vacation care was cut out all together overnight. We will be coming up to vacation care in April and many centres will have been forced to close because of this government.

What they have done in respect of the outside school hours care is an indictment of how you should not govern. Since July last year a number of changes have been made to their policy. With each change the government has gone back to the printers with new glossy promotions espousing their propaganda, and most of that has been scrapped or altered fundamentally.

What is going to happen on 27 April this year for term 2? Outside hours school care centres are going to lose their operational funding. The centres are being compelled to act as agents for Centrelink to administer child-care payments directly to eligible par ents. Yes, there will be a number of parents on lower income levels who will be entitled to this child-care assistance but the centres themselvesâ€”the committees consist of members of the community, usually parentsâ€”will have to become administrators of a very complex structure. They will be bogged down in paperwork. They will also have untold correspondence. Indeed, they will have to purchase computers and computer programs to administer all this.

It will be a very complex system based on the number of hours a child is in care. If the child is away for reasons of being sick, for instance, they will have to chase up a medical certificate from a parent. It is about as neat and tidy as my kelpie's dinner bowl after she has got stuck into it. It is a horrible mess. What are the resources that are being given to these outside school hours centres? They are being given the equivalent of two months of their operational funding to facilitate their transition. What will happen after that two months? They will be bogged down in this additional paperwork without assistance.

It may be necessary for them to look for additional staff because parents who, by the very nature, have children registered in these outside school hours centres have other commitments, usually working commitments. They will not be able to devote their time to it. They will need computer hardware and software. They are not charities, so they will not get any sales tax deductions. They will be paying full freight for this additional equipment. It is going to be a complete and utter mess and an extremely expensive one.

The government says that from January 1999 we are going to have a smart card system. Kids are going to start bundying in and bundying out when they arrive and leave. I know that when my wife phones me at the office to say that she is caught up and asks me to pick my kids up I will be asking, `Where is the smartcard? She will be saying, `I have the smartcard.' It is going to be bedlam.

talk.start.para: â€”We wouldn't waste it on you!

â€”You don't think it would be administered so smartly? The situation will eventuate whether it is me, who, I concede, is perhaps not so organised, or whether it is my parentsâ€”the grandparentsâ€”going down.
â€”That would be all right; they wouldn't lose it.

â€”They would not lose it. That is true. It will be a horrible mess nonetheless. There has been no indication as to what technology will be introduced, who will pay for the technology, or just what will happen.

speech.para: As the member for Bowman (Mrs West) said in her comments earlier, there is no doubt that as assistance declines to these centres the numbers will decline. Experts are predicting that outside school hours centres of less than 20 children will most likely fail because they will not have the numbers to support the infrastructure and equipment that I have been speaking of, which is necessary to cope with the additional administration. That is going to be a real problem.

What happens when the centres do close or, indeed, as a result of the additional fees that will have to be charged to compensate for the loss of operational subsidies, parents cannot afford to pay for the care? What are their options? One option is to move their child to a school or an area where there is an outside school hours centre and that in many cases will mean moving the children away from their existing school or from the support of their friends and neighbours.

talk.start.para: â€”Or lock them in cars at the casino.

â€”The member for Hunter mentions instances of neglect. Unfortunately, that occurs. The newspapers, not members of the opposition, are giving reports of many children having to go to empty homes after school. The member for Lowe (Mr Zammit) spoke of his trip to the local library. Children went to the library instead of going home. That is preferable to going home to an unattended home, but it should not be happening.

speech.para: We have to remember that in the 1970s, when these outside school hours centres were developed because, as women increasingly entered the work force, children were going home to empty homes, there were often neighbours around. In this day and age when so many parents are both working children will be going home to an isolated home or unit without neighbours or relatives around. It is a real indictment of the government.

While, yes, child care is expensive and indeed has been an increasing part of governments' budgets, at least up until this present government, the costs of not providing child care in terms of the problems that happen down the track well and truly justify the investment.

The government has another agenda, one fears, in not investing in child care: it is the desire for social engineering to drive mothers in particular out of the work force and back into the homes to look after children. There are also issues as to whether they are massaging the unemployment figures by forcing more and more women out of the work force.

It is regrettable that we are now talking about business plans, marketing plans and experts being provided to these centres to advise them on cost cutting, and no-one is talking about the children. They are all talking about what is in the interests of the business in this new industry.

talk.start.para: â€”Price driven.
â€”As the member for Banks says, it is price driven, market driven, but no-one is talking about the welfare of the children. That is fundamentally where we should be focusing our attention.

â€”I acknowledge the contribution from the previous speaker, the honourable member for Barton (Mr McClelland). We have had quite a number of speakers on the Child Care Legislation Amendment Bill 1998 this morning. There will not be time for me to completely sum up. At 2 o'clock I will seek leave to complete my remarks after question time, before this bill goes through the parliament again.

speech.para: There is a second reading amendment from the Labor Party. Keep in mind, however, that the Labor Party did support the child-care legislation when it came through the parlia ment last year, and they are continuing to offer support to the fundamental underpinnings of what we are attempting to do in child care in this country.

What we are attempting to do is redress the problems that we inherited and which have been acknowledged in the primary bill debate by the opposition in that there was an unplanned procedure that applied in the child-care industry and that there was the provision for far more places and we were funding to a level that was unsustainable. What the legislation does, with the support of this place and the support of the Senate, is to make sure we put in place a proper structure to deal with planning.

One of the misleading elements, hypocritical elements, in the amendment put forward by the opposition relates to reductions in the outlays. Reductions in the outlays are a direct consequence of the planning proposals which the Labor Party themselves approved only last year. I believe it is totally hypocritical to be moving this second reading amendment. We are spending $4.9 billion, nearly $5 billion, on child care over the next four years, providing an additional 83,000 places. We are concerned about quality child care for Australian families and access in an affordable way for families to ensure that they have a range of choices from family day care to after school hours care, and also from the community care sector and the private care sector.

Providing families with choice and the opportunity to exercise that choice with the strong support of Australian taxpayers is the design of this legislation. With $1.2 billion this year and an additional 18 per cent over two years, there have been real increases. To hear from the opposition, as we did this morning, about a range of these matters was totally and completely hypocritical. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

talk.start.para: â€”I inform the House that the Minister for Defence will be absent from question time today. He will be speaking at the launch of the submarine Dechaineux . The Minister for Defence Industry, Science and Personnel will answer questions on his behalf. The Minister for Regional Development, Territories and Local Government will be absent from question time today. He is in Queensland attending a funeral. The Minister for Transport and Regional Development will answer questions in his absence.

â€”My question is directed to the Prime Minister. Prime Minister, did Senator Parer tell you that his 16 shares were worth more than $2 million and that he and his wife totally control the private company holding those shares? Did he tell you that, through his $2 million shareholdings in Queensland Coal Mine Management, he also held beneficial interests in 100 per cent of Advanced Queensland Resources and Mining, 100 per cent of Jellinbah Mining and 70 per cent of Bowen Basin Coal? Did he inform you that the company had increased its net capital value from $15 million to $153 million in the first year he was minister? Prime Minister, if he did tell you this, why didn't you tell him to divest himself of the shares?

â€”I made a statement last night regarding the allegations contained in the questions asked by the member for Hotham. The member for Hotham is involved in muckraking. The member for Hotham, along with the Australian Labor Party, is disinterested. It is very, very interesting that, on the day on which unemployment in Australia is at its lowest level for five or six years, the first question contains a personal attack on somebody, without foundation and without substance. It would appear that there are a number of things that the Labor Party opposes and one of those is successful businessmen.
â€”Mr Speaker, I rise on a point of order. It was a very specific set of questions asked of the Prime Minister. He is way irrelevant to those questions.
â€”Relevance is a matter of addressing the whole of the question and the context in which the question has been presented.
â€”I addressed the issue raised by the honourable member for Hotham. He is muckrakingâ€”avoiding issues of interest to the Australian community.
â€”A point of order!
â€”The honourable member for Hotham will resume his seat. Prime Minister, wait until I call you.
â€”Mr Speakerâ€”
â€”The honourable member for Hotham will resume his seat. The Prime Minister has the call.
â€”Point of order!
â€”I have ruled on the point of order. Resume your seat!

â€”On the day that unemployment has fallen to its lowest level, what does this character do? He muckrakes. I say, on behalf of the Australian public, that they are fed up with your muckraking. They are far more interested in real issues.
â€”Mr Speaker, I rise on a point of order. Is it appropriate for the Prime Minister to allege that those allegations are without foundation when all of the information is on the public record?
â€”The honourable member for Hotham will resume his seat. That is not a point of order.
â€”I have finished my answer.

â€”My question is addressed to the Treasurer. How is the government's disciplined fiscal and monetary policy helping to create jobs for Australians? Is the Treasurer aware of alternative policies and the effects that they would have on Australia's employment prospects?

â€”I thank the honourable member for Lindsay for her question. Today the Australian Bureau of Statistics reported that there are 8,529,000 Australians in jobsâ€”the highest number of Australians ever in work in Australiaâ€”and that employment increased by nearly 15,000 jobs in the month of February. What that means is that the unemployment rate in the month of February of 8.1 per cent is the lowest unemployment rate in Australia since December 1990. It is the lowest unemployment rate for more than seven years. I think all Australians will welcome the fact that unemployment is now at the lowest level in Australia for the last seven years. It is the lowest unemployment rate since Mr Keating called the recession `Australia had to have' and put Australia into recession in 1990.

answer.para: We do not rest on those results. We do not say that having the lowest unemployment in the last seven years means that we can stop. There was a lot of damage done to this country by the Keating Labor recession of 1990. The fact that it has taken seven years to get back to where we were before then means that we as a government have to keep on working to get more Australians into jobs. What does that mean? It means that we need to have a disciplined approach to the budget position. Any political party, and the Labor Party is one of them, which believes that you can enter into unfunded promises and run up deficit and debt is pursuing a policy of higher interest rates and throwing the economy into reverse.

People should understand this: Labor's policy to increase the deficit and run up interest rates is a policy to lose jobs in Australia. That is why this government works so hard on getting the budget settings rightâ€”because it means that we can keep interest rates low. People should also understand that this government's determination to lock in low inflation is part of our strategy to have low interest rates. It is low interest rates which have been driving economic growth in Australia. To keep those economic growth rates upâ€”as they now areâ€”amongst the highest in the developed world is consistent with continuing the creation of jobs here in this country.

As we look back from this vantage point of February 1998, we see that we have finally got back to the best employment position since the Labor Party threw us into recession with 17 per cent interest rates in 1989-90. My message to the parliament and my message to the Australian people is this: we have to continue to keep working in a disciplined way to produce these results, to give job opportunities to young Australians and to create employment prospects in this country.

talk.start.para: â€”My question is addressed to the Prime Minister. Prime Minister, are you aware that the shares in Queensland Coal Mine Management were not issued 28 years ago but in 1993? Are you aware that they were issued as $1 shares? Are you aware that they were issued at a meeting held in Brisbane and that the share issue was immediately followed by a dividend for Senator Parer's shares, fully franked at over $210,000? Is the Prime Minister aware that at the time Senator Parer was chairman of the company? Prime Minister, how could Senator Parer have failed to declare such a substantial interest?

â€”Nothing newâ€”just muckraking again. Let me say again that apparently it is now, in the eyes of the Labor Party, a crime to have owned some shares in 1993. What possible relevance is there? I simply say to those who sit opposite: you made allegations yesterday. I answered them last night. You are producing nothing new.

â€”My question is also to the Prime Minister. Can the Prime Minister inform the House of comments reported in this morning's press by the international ratings agency Standard and Poors concerning the Asian currency crisis and its likely impact on Australia's credit rating?

â€”I might observe, in thanking the member for Wannon for that question, that one might have thought that question might have come from the opposition; but, no, they are not interested in the number of people in work in Australia. They are not interested in Australia's international financial reputation. They are only interested in tearing down the reputation of decent menâ€”
â€”Muckrakers; that's all you are.

â€”Muckraking. Well may the Leader of the Opposition look just a little bit uncomfortable, because I think he understands that the Australian people are a bit tired of all of this muckraking and that they really want a little bit of commitment to issues that affect mainstream Australia.

answer.para: I am pleased to say that this morning's press reported that the international ratings agency Standard and Poors did not expect the Asian currency crisis to affect Australia's long-term foreign currency credit rating. That is very good news indeed for the Australian economy. It is very good news for the Australian people because it is further evidence of the fundamental strength of the Australian economy.
