talk.start.para: â€”We had to stop this debate just before question time, and I had only one or two minutes to try to sum up the debate. I will resume by saying that I thank the colleagues from both sides who spoke on this matter. There was a range of contributions, some particularly good and some vested with emotion, as you would expect and as we see sometimes when we have discussions about child care.

speech.para: Fundamentally, the proposals that we are dealing with in the Child Care Legislation Amendment Bill 1998 relate to some changes to make child-care assistance easier for families. Our research conducted last year showed that the arrangements envisaged under the Child Care Payments Act would be difficult to families and services during 1998, and the changes that we have made try to address those problems.

That has been met with acclaim from across the child-care sector. I am grateful for that. I particularly notice the press release from Mr Kemp from Australian child care centres, who was indicating that they were very pleased with what had been done by the government in responding to their concerns. There are other groups: the Australian Federation of Child Care Associations, the Care Bear Child Care Centre in Mornington, the Uniting Church Children's Services Forum in New South Wales, and the National Family Day Care Council in New South Wales as well and many others. All indicated that they appreciated the changes that had been made. The changes that are made have been made to the primary actâ€”the child care bill of last year, which the Labor Party supported. Fundamentally, it addresses the needs of establishing a sustainable planning process for child care in this country.

The arrangements also put in place some other additional matters which we probably should not discuss at length today, but there is a continuation and a commitment to the arrangements with regard to immunisation. Age appropriate immunisation proceedings will become a requirement for payment of both child-care assistance and child-care rebate. The link between that immunisation and child-care payments will involve some changes which are picked up in this amendment bill. All of us in this place understand the importance of furthering the need for immunisation of our young people in this country, and this is a very positive way of dealing with it.

There is the issue of the 20-hour limit for non-work related child care. There is a limitation there, and that continues on in this amendment bill. I know there were some concerns about this issue, and I have indicated to the industry I certainly will listen to the views that they put to me on that particular matter. This amendment bill covers only long day care centres and the corresponding changes for other services, including outside school hours care services, will be implemented administratively.

I might make some other comments about some of the remarks, and I am going to curtail my remarks because there is not much time today. There is a second reading amendment which was moved by the Labor Party, which I understand they want to divide on. Obviously I can say on behalf of the government that we reject the amendment. It is possessed of politics and does not further the debate about enhancing quality or dealing with the administrative arrangements for the changes in child care, which will start on 27 April.

I might just make the point with regard to outside school hours care, because that has been the focus of some of the comment from colleagues today. It should be understood that there are about 2,000 out of school hours care services in this country. About 70,000 families have been using those services but, after 27 April, some 51,000 families will have access to child-care assistance for the first time. I think that is a fact that is escaping the attention of many people. There will be changes in administrative arrangements. The arrangements will be done primarily by the service provider, but they are provided with an amount of some $20 million to make the administrative load that much easier. They are funds that they have asked for. I have said that I will keep that under review, and I am in continual discussion with them.

Out of school hours care is a very important service. It is an addition to the choice that is available to families as they pursue their work and study options to have that broader range of choice: family day care, community care, private care and outside school hours careâ€”all very important. We want to ensure that that choice is there, and it is a meaningful choice. We also want to ensure that the assistance that we are providing to child care in this country reaches the parents. This is what has been done.

The changes in outside school hours care follow a two-year study as to how best we might advantage families that are using these services. This was a study commenced by the Labor Party, as I pointed out in question time during the week, and they would have reached the same conclusion that we did: that this was socially and equitably the far better way for us to proceed to provide this assistance. I think that needs to be taken into account as well. The administrative burden that the outside school hours care providers will be feeling will be ameliorated by the extensive support that they will receive from these additional funds and the training and support from the department officers right around the country. I hope that they will make the commitment to ensure that, when we come to the change point on 27 April, we will be able to have a smooth change.

We have established 1800 numbers for access by parents. I think that, when they make inquiries about their entitlements of child-care assistance and child-care rebates and about the locations of relevant services, they will find that the system is working particularly well. We have high call numbers now. I feel confident that, on testing the systems, parents will find that the child-care system we are putting in place will be more than adequate for their needs and the aspirations that they would have for their children.

Finally, I indicate that the level of support for child care in this country is very extensive. We will spend in the vicinity of $5 billion over the next four years. There will be 83,000 new places, additional places, over the next four years. Nearly 600,000 children will be involved in some form of formal child care. We have had an 18 per cent increase over the last two years in outlays in child care, yet we find in this amendment a reference to forward estimates that were pre-existing. The Labor Party cannot have it both ways. They commit themselves to the need for planning, which was the feature of the primary bill and which the Labor Party in the Senate supported, but at the same time as a consequence of putting in a planning regime that limits a sustained growth in child-care centres, which is supported by the child-care industry, there obviously will be those savings to the broad range of taxpayers.

I think that needs to be seen for what it is. I understand politics, and this is a political issue. We have seen circulars sent around the country by the LHMU, the union that covers some of the child-care workers. Really this is just another distortion, a scare campaign, that we have seen in other areas. I think it is regrettable. I do not think it is necessary to scare the parents of this country in the way that it has been done.

The facts should be known. The service providers know the facts and they also believe that, following 27 Aprilâ€”and this bill gives effect to that changeâ€”the administrative arrangements will be that much easier for the child-care providers and for parents, and we can proceed with delivering better quality child care to this country. With those few remarks, I again thank all colleagues for their contribution to an interesting debate and indicate that the government opposes the second reading amendment.
Question put:
That the words proposed to be omitted (Ms Macklin's amendment) stand part of the question.

subdebateinfo.title: Minister for the Status of Women

talk.start.para: â€”I am extremely disappointed to see how the Minister for the Status of Women (Mrs Moylan) is tackling her portfolio. I imagine she was disappointed at her demotion in the ministry. After all, she had done what was asked of her. She was the minister responsible for cutting $800 million from child care. She was the minister responsible for cutting $500 million from aged care. For a government driven by the dollar bottom line this should have been an applauded outcome. At least we thought that with her appointment as Minister for the Status of Women some consideration would finally be given by this government to the concerns of Australian women and that she might even realise what her actions in child care and aged care have meant to Australian women given that appointment.

speech.para: What do we see? Since parliament has resumed this year this minister has taken at least two questions I can recall from her own side seeking advice on the government's initiatives that have assisted Australian women. All she has done in answering those questions is attack the Labor Party and refer to some preselection process over which the minister has somehow taken offence. I take this opportunity to inform the minister, if she is so offended by what we happen to be doing in our preselection process, about six safe seats. The new candidates are: Lalor, Julia Gillard; Gellibrand, Nicola Roxon; Shortland, Jill Hall; Charlton, Kelly Hoare; Fowler, Julia Irwin; and Sydney, Tanya Plebicek.

A lot has happened since this government took office which has affected Australian women. There is much this minister should be concerned about and of far more importance than the personal offence she seems to have taken to the ALP preselection process. Since the Howard government came to power in 1996, Australian women have found it harder to find jobs, harder to get wage increases, harder to pay for child care, harder to pay for health care, harder to pay for their children's education and harder to pay for aged care.

It is Australian women who have paid the ultimate price for the Howard government's deep cut to health, education and community services. The message from the Howard government to Australian women is clear. When it comes to balancing work and family responsibilities you are on your own.

In the work area, over 300,000 women are currently unemployed and 86,000 of these have been unemployed for over one year. Less than 30,000 new jobs have been created for women since the government came to power. I asked a question in the House yesterday about the 50,000 married women who will be denied free access to employment services because of this government.

In the pay packet the gap between what men and women earn is widening. Child-care costs have risen as much as $20 a week in some centres to make up for the $820 million this government has ripped out of that system. The Prime Minister has increased the maximum cost of a prescription for families from $17.40 to $20. For a pensioner that price has gone from $2.70 to $3.20.

Fees for university have more than doubled under this government. University places have been cut by 21,000. Now that young people, those who can afford it, can buy their way into university the principle of merit has been thrown out the window and women attempting to get benefit from education expansion in the 1980s are now denied it.

In nursing homes, women live longer than men and are more likely to need that sort of care. Under the Howard government, all nursing home patients with assets of over $22,500, including the family home, will have to pay an annual fee of up to $4,380 a year for five years. Should families decide that they cannot afford this nursing home fiasco, it is usually the woman in the family who takes on that caring role. Women are really doing it tough under Howard. Most Australian families rely on two incomes to make ends meet. When jobs cannot be found or child- care costs are simply too high, it is the family income that suffers and the women have to find a way to heal that. These issues urgently need the attention of the Minister for the Status of Women. I suggest very strongly that she turn her attention to them accordingly.

subdebateinfo.title: Sydney Gay and Lesbian Mardi Gras

talk.start.para: â€”I hope that the member for Chifley (Mr Price) does not object: I actually gave a bit of thought to this adjournment speech and wrote a few notes. Now that the emotion is starting to settle down in relation to the Gay and Lesbian Mardi Gras that is held in Sydney, I would like to make a few comments about it. I confess to not pulling on my orange lycra shorts to go to the mardi gras.

speech.para: I would like to preface what I have to say, though, by making a couple of serious remarks. My mother lost one of her two sons to AIDS. She did so having done everything she could to instil in both her sons a deeply imbued sense of what was right and wrong. Such is the nature of society that my brother lived with this virus for six years until, in 1990, he summoned the courage to first let me know of his problem and then his parents. It was in that context that a couple of months ago, like most members of the New South Wales community, I became aware of the fact that the police, at that stage at least, had been advised that they would be able to march in the mardi gras and to do so in uniform, and that they would be paid. Subsequently, of course, that decision was changed.

There are a couple of points that need to be made. I think that society, in an environment where we are not leading up to the mardi gras, needs to have some serious and perhaps sober discussion about what this event is really all about. I find it a near impossible task to teach my own children what the difference is between what is right and what is wrong. I question whether it is made any easier by having gay and lesbian men and women making quite hurtful parodies of some of the most caring groups in the communityâ€”the Sisters of Charity for oneâ€”and the state appearing to endorse this kind of behaviour, which under most circumstances we would not accept, whatever the sexuality of the participants. We see politicians from all political parties falling over one another to endorse the mardi gras, to embrace and encourage the gay vote or the gay lobby, and this is seen to be an end which justifies the means.

I question whether that is the right thing for us to be doing. As parentsâ€”and I am one of themâ€”struggle to explain the difference between what is right and wrong to children in their early teens, I ask: how is this near impossible task assisted in any way by the state appearing to condone a form of behaviour that most of us find difficult to understand, let alone tolerate?

At issue, to me at least, is not the sexuality of the participantsâ€”it has nothing to do with thatâ€”but the hurtful parodies of some of the most caring and sincere groups in the community, public nakedness that borders on indecency, and the performance of acts that few adults could explain to the inquiring minds of children. Were this a dignified parade to protest the cruel injustices and prejudice faced in day to day life by homosexual people, I would be prepared to not only join it but to lead it. In that regard, I must say that I have considerable sympathy for what I understand will be a private member's motion to be brought on by the member for Grayndler (Mr Albanese) in relation to superannuation entitlements for same sex couples.

Insteadâ€”to me at leastâ€”the gay mardi gras stands alongside gambling, drug use, escalating suicide rates, and debates about euthanasia and race, as further evidence of a society that is seriously failing. There is in the end a difference between right and wrong. Homosexual people are our brothers and sisters, our aunts and uncles, our sons and daughters, and some are even parents, and they should be able to live in a society that is free of intolerance, persecution and hatred.

Yet they should also understand and respect a societal view that any moral and economic priority should dictate that police andâ€”dare I sayâ€”politicians and others who profess to lead should be anywhere other than at a parade such as the mardi gras. I realise that I am probably alienating some of my constitu ents and many others who will now make me a parody and a subject of abuse. But I believe in what I have said and I think that there is a time that many of us who profess to lead stood up and said, `Hang on, why don't you hose yourselves down a bit and behave in a different way?'

subdebateinfo.title: Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction

talk.start.para: â€”I rise this evening to present this extremely disturbing issue surrounding the Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction, which dates back to 1980. One of my constituents, Maria Acanfora, migrated to Australia from Italy in 1974 as a 10-year-old girl. She is being harassed and pursued by her Italian husband via the state central authority nominated under the terms of the conventionâ€”in this case the Victorian Department of Human Services.

speech.para: Maria, an Australian citizen, resident in Australia for more than 20 years, left Australia for a holiday to Italy in 1994 where she met an Italian man whom she decided to marry. They were married in Italy on 5 May 1994. They lived in Bologna in Italy until July 1995 when they moved to the Honduras. Their son, Francesco, was born there on 12 October 1995. They both returned to Australia in December 1995, then went back to Bologna in February 1996. Unable to find work in Italy, the couple returned to Australia in November 1996 to start up business and to settle in Australia permanently. The marriage broke down.

In order to stop her husband carrying out his threat of taking their very young son back to Italy, Ms Acanfora took out a court order on 17 March, which was served on the husband on 18 March 1997. Her husband did not attend the hearing, scheduled for 19 March; instead, he packed his bags and went back to Italy. Between 19 March 1997 and 2 December, the only contact attempted with the child by the father was three faxesâ€”which was pretty hopeful given that the child was between 17 months old and two years old during this time and therefore not able to read.

On 1 December last year, an ex parte writ under the Family Law (Child Abduction Conventions) Regulations applying to have the child returned to Italy was issued in the Family Court of Australia for hearing. Why it was served and considered ex parte is a mystery to me, as the respondent, Ms Acanfora, was quite readily contactable. She was in fact living in the home that she had always lived in and, indeed, the home that she had lived in with her husband during their time together in Australia. She was so easily contactable that the next day, 2 December, she was visited at her place of residence by three Federal Police officers and two social workers, and both the mother and child were taken to court. Her passports were retained until the outcome of the hearing, and the child is still residing with her in the family home.

My concern about this issue is that, apparently, according to the convention, the taxpayer is to pay the legal expenses for the father, who is living in Italy, yet the expenses of Ms Acanfora, who is my constituent and an Australian citizen, will not be picked up by anybody. She has applied for and has been denied legal aid.

I am also most concerned that the initial hearing was heard and held ex parte for no legitimate reason as the mother was directly contactable. I do not believe this is an appropriate way for Australian citizens to have access to the law and for their rights to be heard. I believe that ex parte hearings should be only in extreme circumstances, where someone flees the country to avoid justice and so on. They should not be for a case like this where she was quite easy to find.

This is a misuse of a convention that was designed honourably and with good intent to protect the lives of abducted children across international boundaries. It would appear in this case, however, to be the means by which an Australian citizen of longstanding is not being given fair treatment. You have to question the sense of a convention that provides the international challenger with the might of free legal representation while an Australian citizen gets none. There seems to me to be something quite wrong about this. I will just refer to the latest letter that she has received from Victoria Legal Aid. It states:
Your matter does not come under the Family Law Act, the Child Support (Assessment) Act or the Child Support (Registration and Collection) Act.

Therefore, she cannot receive legal aid. What we appear to have is a situation where foreign nationals can pursue family law matters with the assistance of legal aid but we do not have legal aid for Australian citizens.

I also add that it is highly doubtful that the son should be regarded as an Italian citizen, given that he was born in the Honduras and his next place of residence for a considerable time was Australia. There seems to me to be some very unsatisfactory features about this case which warrant further consideration.

talk.start.para: â€”I would like to point out tonight that Labor's newest recruit, Cheryl Kernot, intends to be in my electorate next Monday and Tuesday. I would like to take this opportunity to point out a number of things about the would-be member for Dickson, who I believe has no hope of winning. The people of Swan should know about this pin-up girl from the ALP. Laurie Oakes described her as a `demo-rat'. I thought the Labor Party did not like rats, but she is described well and truly in this arenaâ€”I do not have notes here, Mr Speaker, just a few pointsâ€”as a `demo-rat'.

speech.para: Can you believe her? Can you believe anything that Cheryl Kernot says? What I want to say is that, during the South Australian election campaign, she was running around saying, `You've got to support the Democrats, they're the only party that will keep the bastards honest,' and this sort of thing. We know that is the mantra that she was using. But what did she do one week later? After all those election ads, et cetera, she joined the Labor Party. Arm in arm, she joined the Labor Party. Can you honestly believe this woman? She misled the South Australian people. She misled the Australian people.

talk.start.para: â€”Not for the first time.
â€”Absolutely, it was not for the first time.
â€”And only 30 people turned up to hear her speak in Adelaide.

â€”Yes. She is a dishonest person. I must move on because I have a fair bit to say about this duplicitous, disingenuous person called Cheryl Kernot. I would like to point out also that this person has said she is going to shift into the electorate of Dickson. She has not shifted into the electorate of Dickson. She has not bought a house there. She went to rent a house and a truck went through it, so then she said she was off to rent somewhere else.

speech.para: My information is that she may have rented a place there, but she does not live there. I am reliably informed that she lives in an inner city penthouse in Brisbane called Admiralty Towers. This is a great commitment to the people of Dickson, isn't it? She will go and be their member, but she will not live in their electorate. She is not going to live in a nice little house in the electorate; she is going to live in a penthouse.

This is the sort of person who would represent the workers of Australia, according to the Labor Party. This is the sort of disingenuous, dishonest behaviour that you are getting from a would-be Labor Party member of parliament. She is a member of the Labor Party, but she is certainly not a member of parliament and, in my opinion, she will not get that four per centâ€”she's got Buckley's.

Let us also talk about another one of her great qualitiesâ€”because you cannot believe her. Where is her loyalty? She certainly had no loyalty to her staff. When she went, what did she do? She did not tell them. She told the Labor Party. She sat around with Gareth, Kim and these sorts of people telling them that she loved them, wanted to join them and wanted to nurture them. But her own staff found out via the media. Not only that, one of her staff, I am told, was lying on the beach on maternity leave and she was shocked because she found out that the job she intended to return to was not there any more. That was the way she found out. I also happen to know that some of these people have mortgages to payâ€”but there was no job the next day. They have mortgages to pay. They have feelings. They had been loyal to her, and she had not returned the loyalty.

How about her loyalty to the ALP? She went down to the conference in Hobart. She claimed compliments for the resurrection of the ALP. She was this marvellous person who she wanted to hold up in shining light as the person who had got the ALP resurrected in the polls, but Kim and the heavies came in and told her that she could not do that.

I was a teacher and I can assure you, Mr Speaker, that if I had had an affair with someone 10 years younger than me I would have been in trouble. I can tell you it should apply equally, because it seems to be okay for a female to have an affair with a younger person but for a male it is taboo. Does this affection extend to the member for Holt (Mr Gareth Evans), we often wonder. Is she honest? She is about as honest as Christopher Skase and Nick Bolkus, she is about as loyal as Benedict Arnold and she has the morals of an alley cat on heat. The people of Swan and Dickson should be aware of the real Cheryl Kernot and reject her. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: â€”I rise to put on record my disappointment and anger on behalf of my constituents in Sydenham in Sydney. When Mark Vaile became the Minister for Transport and Regional Development, to his credit, he visited my electorate on 31 October 1997â€”something that his predecessor, John Sharp, had failed to do, despite a number of promisesâ€”to look first-hand at the impact the airport noise issue was having in the area closest to Sydney airport.

speech.para: During that visit, we walked around with Joe Hockey, the chair of the Sydney Airport Community Forum; Barry Cotter, the Mayor of Marrickville; and other community representatives. We wanted to show the minister first-hand what the issues were and how they needed to be resolved. Unfortunately, just before parliament came back, we received replies from the minister which were all in the negative.

On the issue of small businesses in Sydenham, as the House would be aware, as a result of the decision to build the third runway a whole section of Sydenham was deemed to be unliveable inâ€”that is, above 40 ANEF. Some 151 houses were bought and demolished in that area. This had an effect on the local shopping centre, not surprisingly. Of the 17 businesses there, a majority have closed. It is not surprising that when you take away the houses from a community the local paper shop, milk bar, takeaway, florist, and hardware store are forced to close. That was a direct result of a decision of government.

While other people closest to the airport were eligible for insulation, these small business owners got exactly zero. The shops were not insulated, yet many of the shopkeepers live above their shops. These are working people, mainly of migrant backgrounds, who settled in Australia and have worked hard to build up their businesses and support their families. Those businesses are today not worth a red cent. I believe that they have a legitimate claim for compensation, especially from a government that says that it cares about small business.

These people got nothing from the minister. He did not even bother to write back to them. Instead, they got a letter through the Chair of the Sydney Airport Community Forum which said that, while the minister had some sympathy for them, he was not able to support their claim for compensation. Sympathy will not feed the children of those hardworking families. The Sydney Airport Community Forum is a government appointed body which, in spite of being stacked with representatives from the North Shore of Sydney, has carried resolutions unanimously supporting the demands of these people. People like Joe Hockey, the member for Lowe (Mr Zammit), state Liberal members and Liberal mayors, people like Kerry Chikarovski and others have all supported these claims, yet the government says that it is not going to deliver on it. That is a disgrace.

We also visited weatherboard houses which had been insulated. That insulation had had a minimal impact on noise reduction. Spending $47,000 insulating the walls of weatherboard houses is a complete waste of money. The government should have just handed over a cheque. We had a plan for the voluntary acquisition of those homesâ€”a plan which was once again unanimously supported by the Sydney Airport Community Forum. Once again, that unanimous support meant nothing when it came to the minister's decision.

It is a very poor performance indeed from the minister when government members are saying, `You've got a case. We agree with you unanimously. We think this is an issue of justice,' but the government will not pay a minimal amount of money, an amount which would not have come out of taxation revenue but from the airport tax on each ticket. These people deserve better. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: â€”It is a mark of a mature politician that he has the sensitivity and wisdom to admit an error of judgment, a lack of understanding and a failure to properly read a situation. Many great politicians have demonstrated these qualities. They have recognised mistakes. They have said sorry. They have responded. Political life is a difficult and complex one. Some would say that modern political life is almost unbearable, with its constant pressures from either side of an issue.

speech.para: However, it is important to remember that the people of Australia, the ordinary people, are our ultimate mastersâ€”not political parties, not unelected officials, not pollsters, not the politically correct elite and not the juste milieu who seem to dictate what we are supposed to say, do and act upon. That is why we must be strong in this gameâ€”strong enough to stand up to those who purport to tell us what to do, especially some of the revolting media outlets which want to run the country from an office in New York or some other remote locality.

I could not help but be moved by a letter to the Sydney Daily Telegraph which was published on 10 March 1998. It is critical of the government, but I believe that we should all listen to it, no matter what side of politics we are on. It says:
Mr Howard's political agenda is further evidence of how out of touch he is with those who go through the pain of divorce and settlement.

I started my superannuation fund before I was married. During my divorce settlement I was placed in the position of closing down a business or handing the business over in exchange for keeping my superannuation.

Selling the business as part of my divorce settlement would have benefited me little. Handing this over to my ex-wife saved my superannuation, it kept her self-employed and while it operates, it provides a great livelihood. My superannuation left something for me to pass on for our son.
John Howard may know the price of milk but does he know the anguish that a father also goes through when a marriage ends?
It is not only the woman who has to endure this trauma. Is he aware that male rights for joint custody is still a major battle for some?
Is he aware of how difficult it is to re-establish one's life when 18 per cent of your gross incomeâ€”
for one childâ€”
goes towards maintenance? My divorce settlement left me the equivalent of what I started with before my 10 years of marriage.

If we have to give up our superannuation will this enable males the same rights in divorce hearings? Will males be entitled to an ex-wife's superannuation? Let's change the Family Law court system, before we create more turmoil in divorce settlements.
I have watched our son grow, but I have had limited opportunities at tucking him into bed every night and picking him up and taking him to school or holding him in my arms when he is sick.
I would give up my superannuation tomorrow for the chance to be with my son.
Name and address supplied but withheld for legal reasons

Those words moved me. Not only do they echo the pain of my constituents but also they stir inner personal experience. Last Sunday I saw my nine-year-old son walking down the street. I had not seen him for a yearâ€”a separation not caused by a deliberate choice of mine. As I spoke to him and adjusted my eyes to the fact of the changes and his growth, the pain of loss was indescribable.

I feel for the writer who understandably withheld his name for legal reasons. I have seen the shocking excesses of the Child Support Agency that leaves people broken, penniless and suicidal, and the failure of the Family Law Act to address marital breakdown. I listen daily to my constituents and to many others from all over Australia who have been blighted by the iniquitous system.

Despite the heading in the Sydney Morning Herald after the government's announcement, women will not win. Dividing people means no winners but bitter losers. Neither money nor slogans can ameliorate the heartache and pain of separation and alienation from your kids and the loneliness.

My electorate is demanding fairness in the family law system and major changes to the Child Support Agency and I am listening to it. Nothing will deter me from doing my duty and representing my constituents.

talk.start.para: â€”I rise to speak about the Howard government's lack of performance on the second anniversary of its election with respect to jobs. In doing so, I also refer in passing to a media release by the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs today which states:

speech.para: The Government's policies have laid the foundation for continued jobs growth this year.
It then refers in passing to the participation rate:
The participation rate was steady at 63.2%.

It is appropriate that we place the real facts on record this evening, and what a terrible record this government's performance is on the jobs front. In doing so, I refer to the Prime Minister's statement exactly two years ago. This is what he had to say on the eve of the last federal election at the National Press Club:

I will be a very disappointed man if I have not made very serious inroads into the level of youth unemployment in this country because I would like to see our performance in that area as being the mark of what we have been able to do as a government.

Two years on, I would have thought that there is something to talk about this afternoon. Where are we two years on? It is interesting to note, on the second anniversary of the election of the Howard government, on the second anniversary of what I suppose was a core promiseâ€”I doubt it is a core promise any moreâ€”youth unemployment remains static at 26.4 per cent. I suppose he will be revising a few other promises as we move towards the next election: the concepts of core and non-core according to performance and non-performance.

Let us deal with the comparison of the first two years of this government on the jobs front with the last two years of Labor in government, the most readily available comparison as to performance. Let us deal firstly with the issue of total jobs growth. There are a range of indicators that we can consider this afternoon. Concerning total jobs growth, John Howard, the Prime Minister of Australia, in his first 24 months of government has achieved 193,100 jobs. In their last 24 months, the Labor Party achieved 521,100 jobs.

I now go to the issue of full-time jobs growth. John Howard in his first 24 months as Prime Minister: 75,700â€”a staggering performance. The Labor Party in its last 24 months: 322,700. I would hate to think what he was achieving if the jobs growth was not on target at this point in time. Part-time jobs growth: 117,400â€”a real achievement for John Howard. Labor's part-time jobs growth in the last 24 months: 198,400.

Then we go to the staggering reduction in unemployment that has been achieved in John Howard's first two years of government: 0.3 per cent. Youth unemployment is stuck at a national level, the overall level of unemployment is down 0.3 per cent. What did Labor achieve in our last 24 months? Not a bad result: a reduction of two per cent.

Now we go to the participation rate. In many ways the participation rate is, in people's minds, a statement of their view or their sense of confidence in their capacity to get a job based on the performance of the economy and the performance of the government. It is interesting to note that people have actually given up hope of finding a job. The participation rate has dropped in the two years from 63.8 per cent to 63.2 per cent. I suppose he has achieved something. He has driven men and women out of the work force and placed barriers especially in the face of women who want to make a contribution to the development of Australia and, in so doing, try to secure and create better opportunities for their families in the future.

I believe that the Prime Minister is trying to hide these stark figures of his fudge on the employment front. He is trying to point the finger at the underprivileged in the Australian community and he stands condemned this afternoon for his failure. Worse still, the changes in the delivery of employment services is an absolute disgrace. To deny married women whose husbands are working, to deny the spouses of defence personnel an opportunity to get a job, to deny young people who are not on benefits but seeking to pursue training, be it in TAFE or universities, the opportunity to use the old CES to get a jobâ€”a leg up the ladderâ€”is an absolute disgrace.

This government is not committed to jobs and job security. Its first two years of a lack of performance show that. On all the indicatorsâ€”full-time jobs growth, part-time jobs growthâ€”the question of what you do with respect to the participation rate and youth employment are an absolute failure and disgrace. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: â€”Given the late hour, I put my prepared text to one side and take this opportunity to congratulate you on your appointment and elevation to the position of Speaker. I am sure that you will continue to hold that office in the very good light in which it has been held in the last two weeks and show the oppositionâ€”
â€”He hasn't got a vote in your caucus.
â€”how they could perhaps mend their ways, particularly the member for Batman (Mr Martin Ferguson) who is a very rowdy and vocal member of the House.

business.start.para: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER(Mr Nehl) took the chair at 9.40 a.m.

talk.start.para: â€”In last year's federal budget the government announced a new $16 million immunisation program for combating rising levels of hepatitis B in Australia. The program was designed to be delivered to all prepubescent school children. In the budget papers, the government stated:

speech.para: Vaccinations are normally delivered to adolescents through GPs and health clinics. The level of coverage of the target group would be expected to be low if these were the only delivery mechanisms used as adolescents do not use these services frequently.

This measure provides specific funding for the delivery of HBV in the school setting, which is expected to result in better rates of immunisation. It will involve the Commonwealth working with the states . . . and the states being responsible for the delivery programme as well as the provision of additional funding.
That is what they told us they were going to do, and then the federal Minister for Health (Dr Wooldridge) bathed in the publicity about his new immunisation program.

The Victorian state government has advertised the scheme as being available in all schools. They even had glossy letters and leaflets and a web page to tell us about the scheme and how wonderful the government was. It is a shame they could not find the money to pay for the injections for the kids.

What the state government did was to pass the cost on to local councils. The councils had to go to the schools to immunise the kids but they were not given enough money to run the scheme. Staff at the city of Casey, for example, claim that they have been unable to secure sufficient funding to vaccinate kids at their schools. I have been informed that the council was going to be short-changed $27,000 by the state and federal governments if it implemented the scheme the way the governments wanted it to be done. Casey claims it does not have that amount of money just lying around. So, there are now 2,000 kids whose only option is to attend the Casey Council after school hours health centre to get the three shots they need to be protected against hepatitis B.

That delivery mechanism was rejected by the federal government. They even say in their budget papers that it is not good enough. School based immunisation is the only place where you get a high enough level of immunisation. But it is not just the 2,000 kids in Casey who will suffer, it is the whole immunisation program. The government has told us it is committed to getting immunisation rates to 90 per cent. This is another empty promise. When it has come to the crunch, Dr Wooldridge has failed to find the money to deliver on his promises to the kids of Australia.

The Municipal Association of Australia and the Australian Local Government Association have informed me that there is growing disquiet amongst many councils about the way governments are funding immunisation programs. Councils are being forced to carry the high cost of federal and state government programs of immunisation.

Victoria is the first state to implement the hepatitis B immunisation of school children program. I sincerely hope that the other states are not facing the same sorts of funding problems as Victoria is facing.

talk.start.para: â€”Today I rise to congratulate the University of the Third Age in Redcliffe on its 10th anniversary and say that I had the extreme pleasure of enjoying the celebrations there with the students on Saturday of last week in my electorate of Petrie.

speech.para: The University of the Third Age provides an opportunity for older people to learn new skills and to learn in a motivated environment. The people who were there seemed to have an incredible new lease of life. They were older members of our community and they had an incredible hunger to learn and a desire to be there. It was just wonderful to be enriched by their motivation and their high spirits.

Whether it is astrology, the Internet or needlework, the members and those who participate in these courses were passionate about this self-help approach to learning. They have taken to this concept with both hands and are using their retirement as a kick-start to learn new skills, and many of them have rejuvenated former skills. For example, the Internet is now not seen as confusing or too technical for older people but rather it is seen as a very interactive learning tool, and many of them have embraced it wholeheartedly.

The first University of the Third Age was founded in Toulouse, France, in 1972, and the first campus in Australia was established in Melbourne in 1984. The University of the Third Age in Redcliffe was founded by a remarkable woman, Olive McKee, way back in 1987, and it was incorporated in 1988.

Some 500 people are enrolled in courses at the University at the moment and members of the Redcliffe U3A come from a number of areas in Brisbane, including the suburbs of Bracken Ridge, Sandgate, Deagon, Brighton, Lawnton, places like Deception Bay, Burpengary and in fact from all over the Redcliffe Peninsula. Each University of the Third Age determines its own curriculum and its demand in the use of its skill. It uses a great number of unpaid tutors and they come from all walks of life. They provide tutorials, seminars and workshops for the members of the university. In fact it is not uncommon for a teacher in one class to be a student in another. I had the pleasure of meeting people from some outstanding academic backgrounds the other day.

One of the qualities of the Redcliffe University of the Third Age is that it does not rest on its laurels. It is particularly grateful for the support given by the Redcliffe Library, local newspapers and the local radio station 99FM and it also contributes and provides valuable assistance to the local cardiac rehabilitation unit. With the slogan of `Learning for the joy of learning', the members have the right frame of mind and join together to share experiences, skills and learning.

I was greatly honoured to be with the executive and the members of the University of the Third Age and I particularly was pleased to join them for their celebrations last Saturday. I wish them great success and I wish them well for all their endeavours in the future.

talk.start.para: â€”In the same fortnight in which Australian attention has been attracted by Mr Roudeâ€”the successful tenderer whose total ability to provide employment help to people in this country seems not to be the availability of computers, not the availability of any previous background experience, but the fact that he could buy a few books on management for the television when they came to interview himâ€”the highly respected and fairly high profile Greater Western Sydney Regional Chamber of Commerce and Industry wrote to 10 members of this federal parliament with a three-page indictment of this government's processes in regard to job help. It is worth noting the questions they raised about the way in which various providers were told in advance that they would be successful, a process demoralising for other companies. As I say, it is a three-page indictment.

speech.para: I want to raise another issue from that period, that is, the government's preoccupation with certain ideological requirements rather than good practice and good government. That is the question of adult migrant English in this country. In New South Wales we had it tendered out in five separate regions. What has occurred is that this 50-year-old organisationâ€”with a record in regard to curriculum development; with a record in the provision of counselling to refugees and humanitarian entrants to this country; and with a reputation for having trained psychologists and teachers to help these peopleâ€”has disappeared in three of the New South Wales regions. Quite frankly this government talks about choice; it says it is widening choice for people. The fact of life is that in most of Sydney now you have to travel 20 kilometres for an alternative. There is no alternative in Western Sydney to the recently established private provider, which to my knowledge has no trained teachers. Quite frankly the bottom line here is the government's desire to reduce 60 to 65 per cent of funding in this area. Unemployment, particularly in the municipality of my electorate, far exceeds the national average because of the reality that people are recent arrivals and lack English. This organisation that has provided this service over five decades is basically going to collapse. I put on record the effort by the local community from people of all political persuasions two years ago. There were massive public meetings and council resolutions, et cetera against this decision.

I want to note the efforts of the Fairfield Migrant Inter-Agency Association. The points they make about the collapse of this organisation include the failure to recognise long-term knowledge and understanding of migrants, a committed and extensive service working with DIMA clients, bilingual assistance, responsiveness to client needs and the ability to provide flexible programs. All these things are going out the door. All these people that depend on the free provision of English in this country for their job success in the future are being told that there is only one alternative now, a newcomer on the block with no previous experience, and that they have to travel 20 kilometres if they want to get an alternative to that option.

talk.start.para: â€”This morning I take the opportunity to rise and speak about the late Roger Shipton.
â€”He was a person of very high principles.

â€”Mr Deputy Speaker, as the member for Cowper, I am quite sure that you would join with me this morning in paying a tribute to Roger, who was a parliamentary colleague of yours for a number of years. Roger was first elected to the federal parliament in 1975 and retired in 1990. During that period, I had met him in the Northern Territory a number of times. He was a frequent visitor to the Northern Territory. He was a great bloke. He also took his work in parliament very seriously. On the number of times that he visited the Territory, he really visited it to find out as much as he could about Aboriginal affairs, because he was on that committee for a number of years.

speech.para: While in parliament, he was an opposition spokesman on Aboriginal affairs from 1984 to 1985. That gave me the opportunity of meeting Roger. He was a frequent visitor. The last time I saw him in the Northern Territory was at a function in August last year with his wife, Susie. He looked in very good health. I then had the good fortune of seeing him again in Melbourne in November. I was quite surprised when he was tragically taken in January of this year.

Roger was awarded a medal of the Order of Australia in 1991 for his services to politics. As you move around the federal parliament and ask people whether they knew Roger Shipton, everybody will say he really was a good bloke. The honourable member for Fisher (Mr Slipper) interjected at the beginning of my remarks to say what a nice bloke he was. His wife, Susie and his son, James, and his daughter, Kate, will certainly miss him. I would also like to say that the people that he worked with at Philip Morris will certainly miss him as well because they enjoyed the spirit of cooperation that he had with them.

I often used to bump into him in the corridors of the parliament here and, from time to time, we had the opportunity of having a cup of coffee. He will be sadly missed. He was a great bloke. I would like to say once more I offer my condolences to his wife, Susie, and to his family.

talk.start.para: â€”I thank the Honourable Member for the Northern Territory for associating me with his remarks about my friend, the late Roger Shipton.

â€”Three times within the past seven days I have raised the deplorable climate of industrial relations which is beginning to engulf this nation. There is an undeniable climate of fear, intimidation, confrontation, division and harassment being actively promoted by this government. This government, through its workplace relations legislation, is harbouring bosses who want to mug workers. The workplace relations legislation actively works against the workers and the trade unions workers choose to represent their interests.

speech.para: On Monday I outlined a dispute at the New South Wales grain cooperative pivot facility at Port Kembla in some detail. I do not propose to repeat those remarks, except to say that the rock solid guarantee legislation has failed them.

I also raised an allegation that a woman had appeared at the picket line on numerous occasions during the six-week dispute. She was involved in the video and other surveillance of activities there. This mystery woman has boasted about her history as a private detective. She boasted about stalking claimants for workers compensation. She boasted about having been involved in the video surveillance of activities at the Hunter Valley Rio Tinto No. 1 mine picket. She also claimed to have been engaged in a contract with a government department to spy on people who were legitimately protesting their inexcusable sacking by a ruthless picket management.

The Minister for Workplace Relations and Small Business (Mr Reith), in response to a question from me in question time on Tuesday, demanded of me that I apologise to the Office of the Employment Advocate. I do not express regret for raising this issue with the minister. This is an important matter. It cannot be brushed aside.

I reveal today, through detective work of my own, that the woman who slunk around the picket line at Port Kembla, spying on sacked workers and their supporters as late as Monday, is a Ms Angela Dahm. I am informed that she has been employed directly or indirectly by Rio Tinto. Ms Dahm has a great deal of explaining to do. She must explain why she boasted about having been engaged in a contract to undertake video surveillance of picketers by a government department. She must also explain what she intended to do with this video surveillance. She must explain how much taxpayers' money she has been paid, by whom, by which government department and for what purpose. The whole issue has a rather putrid smell about it. I strongly suspect that this is the Illawarra's own Dubai scandal. There are questions I have put on the record and there are questions I expect answers to.

In two years, this government has turned a century of industrial relations on its head. The only thing I deeply regret is that 1998 is appearing no different from 1898. It is a scandal and I will pursue this.

talk.start.para: â€”I rise today to talk about a frustrating and disheartening plight faced by many in our veterans community, particularly the Vietnam veterans. A number of them have gone through what they have described to me as their biggest battle: working with the Department of Veterans' Affairs to secure TPI benefits.

speech.para: Having done that, they then approach their insurance companies and, under the terms of their superannuation policiesâ€”the death and disability provisionsâ€”they make an application to see whether that disability payment can be made. I remind those members present that, in most insurance companies, the disability provisions relate to an `incapacity to such an extent as to render the person unlikely to ever engage in or work for reward in any occupation or work for which he is reasonably qualified.' That sits alongside the TPI definition, which is very similar but talks about an incapacity, because of war caused injury or disease, that prevents a person from continuing to undertake remunerative work that he or she was undertaking, thus suffering loss of salary and the like.

The definitions are very similar but, in practice, the experience of the veterans is quite different. After going through the process with the Department of Veterans' Affairs to exhaustively examine their eligibility for a TPI entitlement, they then approach their superannuation fund. A superannuation fund or insurer arbitrarily makes a decision, often having only ever inspected or assessed the veteran for one 40-minute interview, that the veteran is capable of working, thus denying the veteran access to that disability element under their superannuation policy.

It is extraordinarily disheartening for veterans, having gone through the exhaustive DVA processes, to have an insurance company engage psychiatrists or doctors to assess them, at one interview, and tell them that all the assessments that the Department of Veterans' Affairs have arrived at are wrong, that they are indeed capable of working, and that the DVA conclusion is inaccurate. I would hasten to suggest that this may have more to do with the insurer or superannuation company being a little less prepared to pay out on the superannuation policies held by the veterans than with a very genuine assessment of their physical condition.

I call upon the government to work with the ISC, the Insurance and Superannuation Commission, to reconcile the definitions of a person's incapacity to work; so that the veteran knows that, once they have gone through the Department of Veterans' Affairs process, it is almost automatic that the superannuation companies will take account of that exhaustive assessment and indeed share the conclusion that the person is incapable of continuing to work, thus granting them the disability payment under their superannuation insurance policy.

I would like to briefly mention and acknowledge the excellent work of the Frankston, Seaford and Mornington RSLs and, in particular, their welfare officers, who keep me well briefed on what is being experienced by the veterans within my community. I will continue to work for their interests.

talk.start.para: â€”Order! In accordance with sessional order 275A, the time for members' statements has concluded.

subdebate.1.para: Debate resumed from 5 March, on motion by Mr Williams:
That the bill be now read a second time.

talk.start.para: â€”In the absence of the honourable member for Banks (Mr Melham), I will go ahead of him. He may well arrive before this debate is concluded.

speech.para: The Legislative Instruments Bill 1996 [No. 2] is a very important piece of government legislation. The government has a clear mandate for the changes introduced and included in the bill, as it was part of coalition policy prior to the last election. In our policies on law and justice and a new deal for small business, we said that the government would introduce these provisions. Consequently, this bill has a clear and unequivocal mandate from the Australian people.

The bill seeks to reform the processes for making, publication, scrutiny and, most importantly, sunsetting of Commonwealth legislation. The bill acts in a gatekeeper role by preventing the unchecked proliferation of delegated legislation. We all know, as members of parliament, how frustrating it is for our constituents when they come to us, time and time again, complaining about regulations which are outdated and yet which remain in force and effective.

This bill has a long history, going all the way back to 1994 to the time of the former Labor government. The former government introduced what was then called the Legislative Instruments Bill 1994 and, owing to the election in 1996, it simply did not pass. It lapsed and consequently this government has introduced this later piece of legislation.

I am pleased the honourable member for Banks has arrived, because he was the chairman of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs. I can see Ms Middlebrook next to you, Mr Deputy Speaker, and she was the secretary of the committee at that time.

Our committee was privileged to have referred to it the Legislative Instruments Bill 1994 for consideration. We looked at it very closely, as a committee; we believed that it was important; and I think it is sad and tragic that the Labor Partyâ€”and the Democratsâ€”in the other place, represented in this place by the honourable member for Banks, have decided to overturn what was strong support for the principles outlined in this bill.

As I said, the chairman of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs in the last parliament was the honourable member for Banks, and I must say that he was a particularly good chairman at that time. The recommendations that the committee brought forward in its report are largely those included in this legislation, and included amongst those recommendations is one that there should be a sunset provision on all new regulations. The Attorney-General (Mr Williams) stated in his second reading speech:

This is the same bill that was introduced into the House of Representatives on 24 June 1996 and passed by that House on 11 September 1996. This bill was introduced into the Senate on 8 October 1996 and, notwithstanding the strong general support of the Senate for the bill, finally passed on 25 September 1997 with 18 government and 35 other amendments. A large number of the non-government amendments emasculated the stringent consultation principles and processes and removed the sunsetting regime.

The House subsequently considered the Senate amendments and returned the bill, accepting the government amendments and rejecting the others, and some additional government amendments were added by the government in the House of Representatives. On 5 December last year the Senate reconsidered the bill and insisted on its previous amendmentsâ€”most regrettably. The government is therefore reintroducing this important bill for consideration by the House of Representatives.

I would like to make a couple of comments about the attitude of the Labor Party in relation to this piece of legislation. They really are indicating yet again how completely and totally out of touch they are with the Australian people. We have a clear mandate. The Labor Party ought to recognise that they were reduced to 49 seats in the House of Representatives at the election two years ago. We had 76 Liberal Party members and 18 National Party members elected, a government majority of 94 to 49 which is a strong mandate for this policy announced prior to the election; it was clear we would be introducing a bill into the parliament.

talk.start.para: â€”Legislative instruments wasn't a mandate at the last election. Come on!

â€”We included in two of our policies the fact that we would be introducing a bill before the House. In effect, we are aiming to reduce unnecessary regulation. We believe regulations should be sunsetted, and so the honourable member for Banks ought to backflip again. He should support the recommendations of his own committee, the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs in the last parliament, and he should back the position taken by the Attorney-General in this bill.
â€”The government isn't picking up our recommendations.

â€”My friend, you ought not to interject. You should be telling your colleagues in the Labor Party that they ought to support this bill. The honourable member for Banks is often heard to say in the parliament that the Attorney-General is rolled in the cabinet. The Attorney-General is a very effective Attorney-General and I believe that, largely, the cabinet would support his recommendations. In this matter my colleague opposite has been rolled by the troglodytes in the Labor Party. The Labor Party is not actually representing the personal views of the honourable member for Banks who, I believe, would want to see his party support this particular legislation.

speech.para: Mr Melham interjectingâ€”

talk.start.para: â€”Order! The honourable member for Banks should have been speaking now, but he was late. He is not speaking now, so he should be quiet.

â€”He was so late that we almost had to call a by-election in Banks. The government has broad support from the parliament for this bill and backing from the Australian community. Regrettably some people in the Labor Party think it is appropriate that small business should be entangled and enmeshed forever in regulations which are never removed from the statute books.

speech.para: I believe that the parliament ought to be a cooperative place. Where legislation that is fair, reasonable and sensible is introduced, it is vital that both sides of the parliament support it. The obstruction of the opposition in relation to the Legislative Instruments Bill is most disturbing. It seems as though the opposition is determined simply not to recognise our mandate, and in the other place to frustrate sensible and fair reform. Both houses have, in principle, passed the legislation. They have considered it, but they have been unable to agree on the actual clauses to be finally included.

This is a classic case of the Senate playing politics. This is a classic case of the Labor Party seeking to frustrate the very effective work of the Attorney-General and the government. There are many other matters where the Labor Party has taken the same approach, and this is eminently regrettable. I do not want to digress from the billâ€”

talk.start.para: â€”Then don't.

â€”but the Wik legislation is another instance where the honourable member for Banks ought to have supported the government's determination to restore certainty and fairness for pastoralists and the general community, as well as for our indigenous Australians.

speech.para: To go back to the Legislative Instruments Billâ€”I know you will be pleased, Mr Deputy Speaker, that I am continuing to do thatâ€”the hypocrisy, backflips and inconsistency shown by Labor, and in particular by the honourable member for Banks, are absolutely amazing. One would think that the honourable member for Banks is one of the fittest members in the chamber: the backflip that we have seen in relation to this legislation is outstanding and quite regrettable.

The sunsetting of delegated legislation is a very important part of the government's policy on regulation review. It will ensure that business regulation is reduced to the minimum necessary for effective accountability and control. The member for Banks has no sympathy for small business, he has no empathy with small business and his actions in this place are undermining the capacity of small business to be run without unnecessary red tape and regulation.

talk.start.para: â€”Where did you get that from? I've been verballed.
â€”The member for Banks's tongue is flapping with too much force.

â€”The member ought to keep quiet; the member ought to support this bill. I believe that, had the member been more persuasive, had he been a better advocate in the Labor Party, then the Labor Party would have been supporting this bill.

speech.para: Those opposite, Mr Deputy Speaker, as you personally know, do not care at all about small business. Their actions on this bill and on other bills are proof positive of the fact that they have lost touch not only with the Australian community but also with the Australian small business proprietor, who supplies so much employment to Australians.

This bill, in accordance with government policy, will ensure that all new regulations are subject to a five-year sunset clause. This is an important policy that the government cannot and will not back away from. We have a clear mandate. This bill has been considered by the parliament over a period of five years. It has received general bipartisan support. In opposition we supported what the Labor Party was doing with respect to this matter, but now we find that they are seeking to undermine the effect of this bill.

The amendments moved in the Senate by the Labor Party and the Democrats amount to legislative terrorism. They have really lost the plot and are playing a very base level of politics. They are completely, utterly and totally pathetic.

We make no apologies for reintroducing this legislation to this place. This is a good bill, it is fair legislation and it is legislation which received the strong mandate of the Australian people at the last election. It is not too late for the Labor Party to do yet another backflip and support this bill so that the very worthwhile reforms contained in the Legislative Instruments Bill can become part of the law of this land. I commend the bill to the Main Committee.

talk.start.para: â€”At the outset, Mr Deputy Speaker, I apologise to you and the Main Committee for coming late. I had my times mixed up. I should have known better.

speech.para: A couple of things that the honourable member for Fisher (Mr Slipper) said need explanation. True it was that in the last parliament, when I was chairman of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs, we did an inquiry into the Legislative Instruments Bill 1994 and we brought down a number of recommendations. But what is also true is that not all of those recommendations have been picked up to the letter. Arising from that committee report, it became obvious to me that there were also different views within the various departmentsâ€”within the Attorney-General's Department, within Prime Minister and Cabinet and within other bureaucraciesâ€”as to what the appropriate legislation should be.

There is no doubt that this bill has a chequered and long history, and there has been a lot of consultation. But this bill has been the victim of politics within the bureaucracy, within Prime Minister and Cabinet, Treasury and Finance, because I know that those bureaucracies have a different view from various offices, for instance, within the Attorney-General's Department. That is all a matter of record, and it is a matter of knowledge as to what happens behind the scenes; that is all part of the process. What it means is that there is no idealistic view, there is no one right view. You have got people on all sides acting in good faith as to what they believe is the best way forward.

In relation to the Legislative Instruments Bill 1996 [No. 2] , this second bill that has been returned to the House, it is in substantially the same form as the first bill that was introduced by the government last year. But it is also once again worthy of note that the government has refused to accept a single one of the amendments proposed by the Senate. For us that is extremely disappointing, because the Senate does have a role to play and individual Senators have a role to playâ€”members of the Democrats, the Greens and, indeed, Senator Harradine.

There are a number of problems with this bill that the Senate's amendments sought to remedy. In particular, the government's proposals for sunsetting seek to fundamentally alter the relationship between the executive and the Senate, to the executive's benefit and for no good reason. That is the view of the Senate. Despite this genuine concern, a concern that has been clearly unacceptable to the Senate, the government has made no attempt at this stage to address either this or any of the other matters in contention. This includes the seemingly innocuous requirement that legislative instruments not be written in sexist language. With even a modicum of goodwill on the part of the government, these issues could, and can still, be resolved to everyone's satisfaction.

In this regard, I note that discussions are continuing between the government and the opposition in relation to this bill. For the record, I note the opposition's willingness, as it has had all along, to compromise on this bill, provided our genuine concerns are met. Yet despite these meetings having occurredâ€”

talk.start.para: â€”Were you rolled by your colleagues?
â€”Order! I would encourage the member for Fisher to set an example for the member for Banks and be quiet.

â€”I repeat that I note the opposition's willingness, as it has had all along, to compromise on this bill, provided our genuine concerns and the genuine concerns of the Senate are met. Yet despite meetings having occurred, and whilst the office of the Attorney-General (Mr Williams) has made some positive noises, the opposition and other players in the Senate are still yet to see any substantive offer of compromise from the Attorney's office on any issue. That is what I have been informed, that there have been some positive overtures.

speech.para: I say to the Attorney and his office that the opposition, and I would also take that to mean other senators, are looking to see what is back on the table. I say to the Attorney and the government that the concerns that the opposition, the minor parties in the Senate and Senator Harradine hold are genuine and should not be ignored. The Labor Party will not be walking away from them, nor, as I understand it, will the minor parties and Senator Harradine in the Senate.

These issues can be addressed, we believe, in ways that are consistent with the government's policy objectives. What we ask is that the government shows some goodwill in these discussions. If the government wants a train wreck on what is ultimately a non-contentious piece of legislation, then so be it. If the government wants to explain to the Australian people why we are having a $60 million double dissolution on these issues, then I, for one, look forward to the campaign. The nonsense that the member for Fisher was spruiking earlier about this being a mandate for this government as a result of the last electionâ€”

talk.start.para: â€”We said we were going to do itâ€”
â€”Produce one person who voted on legislative instruments in the last election. The government does not have a mandate in relation to this specific issue.

speech.para: There are many parts of this bill that are non-contentious and are agreed with by all sides of the parliament, and with a modicum of goodwill we will get there. The government's lack of commitment to accountable and responsible government will be exposed if they continue down this path.

If they are genuine about getting the legislation through, then I suggest to the Attorney and his office that they come forward with some proposed amendments and the opposition will look at them. I have not been the negotiator between the government and other players. I am the spokesman in this House for the shadow Attorney-General. One of the reasons that I do not have my fingerprints all over this is that this is not within my portfolio. I have not been involved in the negotiations, and I put that on the record. I am here as the spokesman for Senator Bolkus who has carriage of the matter in the other place.

As an indication of our dissatisfaction with the current bill, I can indicate that we will be voting against it on its second reading in the House today. I hope that we will be in a position to support an amended bill in the Senate. I repeat, I have been advised that at the Attorney's office there have been discussions behind the scenes. The opposition are waiting to see if there is room for compromise with goodwill and whether that can be done. The trouble is this is not a bill that will receive high priority in the Senate. It really should not be part of a double dissolution trigger. But the opposition for our part will not be intimidated into capitulating with a threat that we will have a double dissolution on this issue. This will not even be argued, per se.

The broad principle that I have got is about separation of powers and empowering the parliament and the Senate to be a check on the executive. I, for one, believe in the separation of powers. I believe in the role of parliament as a check on the executive. I believe in scrutiny of the public service by the parliament and I am sure the Attorney does, as well. We are not the only ones on this side. These are principles that are espoused by us all.

This is a complex piece of legislation. I do not believe that the government needs to be as intransigent as it is. The debate in the Senate occurred last time, and I am not going to go through those issues. I am advised that there are genuine concerns by members of the minor parties and Senator Harradine in relation to this, and I do not believe that those concerns can be swept under the carpet. With a modicum of goodwill, and if people go away and exchange notes on this, then I think we will get through. We will not get through if the government is not willing to come to the table in good faith.

I am not saying that they have not at the moment. I am not saying that there has not been good faith. I have not had the minute carriage of this matter from day one, so I cannot speak on behalf of others. I have been advised that the opposition is willing, once they see some proposals coming from the Attorney's office, to talk through this with the government and with the other players so that we can have a piece of legislation that enjoys a broad support of the parliament. The last thing we want is a legislative instruments bill getting through the Senate one way or the other by one voteâ€”one vote for the government's position, or one vote for the combined opposition position. It is just absurd.

I will leave it there, but I indicate that we will be dividing on the second reading of this matter. There are no amendments that we will be putting forward because the government has got the numbers in the House of Representatives. I can see that.

It reminds me of going to the New South Wales ALP conferences in my early days, as I continue to do now what I did then in being a warrior against the NSW Right. They did not worry about the arguments; they had the numbers; they could pass whatever resolutions they wanted. That did not make it good policy, no were they necessarily good resolutions.

The Senate is a different ball game in relation to this. That is where the debate will occur. The government is not the repository of all wisdom. The minor parties and the Independent Senator Brian Harradine, have got a role to play. Their genuine concerns should be met. A lot of this, maybe, is perception. Maybe the government has met their genuine concerns, but not yet explained it well enough for them to show that their genuine concerns have been met. I do not know. That is a debate for a later day.

talk.start.para: â€”in replyâ€”It is a very long time since this bill, the Legislative Instruments Bill 1996 [No. 2] , or its predecessor, was first put on the table of this parliament and it is an extremely disappointing situation that we are in at the moment. We have just had a speech from the spokesman for the opposition, the member for Banks (Mr Melham), as to the opposition's position on the bill. He mentioned two points of substance in relation to the bill: the first related to sunsetting and the second to sexist language. He did not indicate in any way what the problems are that the opposition has with the bill, except to say that the sunsetting regime empowers the executive as against the Senate.

speech.para: He did not say what the opposition would like to see in the bill. He did not propose any amendments. He did not really speak to the bill at all, he just called on the government to exercise goodwill. The government has a capacity to exercise goodwill but in this case this bill went up to the Senate and 35 non-government amendments were made, emasculating the bill and eliminating the sunsetting provisions. There was no discussion with the government prior to the debate in the Senate as to what was proposed. There were actually amendments made on the floor of the Senate at the whim of the individual senators.

This bill has been around since late 1993, I think, and certainly since early 1994. It has been the subject of intense scrutiny by a committee chaired by the member for Banksâ€”something he seemed to gloss overâ€”and has been strongly supported by both sides of politics. The 1994 bill was introduced by the previous government. We have now got the situation where the opposition is going to vote against the bill, a bill that in broad terms it supports, a bill that in the previous parliament it actually introduced.

The situation really exposes the opposition as being simply obstructive. If there is a genuine belief that the sunsetting provisions are of such a drastic nature as to generate opposition to the bill as a whole, one would have thought that there could have been an amendment of some sort suggested, but there has been none.
